column3: (Social) Afternoon Coffee at Mary's Coffee & Steak

column4:
Mary’s Coffee and Steak diner sit just off the town center on 2nd street. It was just after 5pm and the small diner was just starting to see after work crowd. A few of Naukati’s locals streamed in for coffee, a chat or one of Mary’s locally famous steak. 

It’s been one week since the children were filled missing and a dark cloud covered the mood of most of the town. However even with the burden of such news, the heartache to locals, and the new Federal agents in town, life in Naukati goes on.

The diner is big enough to seat roughly 50 individuals  the overal disgn of the place feels unchanged since the 60’s,however numerous memorabilia line the walls and counters dating from the 60’s all the way into the late 90’s. Record sleeves, posters and pictures of the few notable individuals who have passed thru Naukati, no one big mind you, third tier or local names mostly.

Game Aspects: 

Anger and Pain over the Missing Children, Federal Marshals Investigating The Town, A Freehold divided.


Scene Aspects: 

Small Local Diner.

Shadow of Current events.

Characters:
Jamie Horn
Vernon ""Old Jack"" McGill
Cal Grenwell
Halcyon Pearson
Oona Marlowe

NPC's:
Tori Walsh 

This top post will be updated with scene aspects, characters and scene notes. Check back for updates and reference as needed.

Ding Ding!

The front doorbell chimed as the glass door swung slowly open. Jamie removed her ranger hat setting it on a hook by the door. She ran her hand thru the hair matted from the hat. Turning she raised a hand in greeting to those in the diner.

“Evenin’ folks. Tori the usual please, extra sugar tonight”

Jamie moved to the bar and sat down in her usual seat, two in from door with a view out on to the main street. She collected the cup with a thank you to Tori. Before glancing down at the local paper on the counter.  

Charlie, Laura, Rick.

The faces of the children plastered on the front. It made her stomach twist, slowly she pushed it away as she took a sip of her coffee.

You don't often see Old Jack inside of Mary's. Oh sure, you'll see him around. Sat on the sidewalk outside the doors. Rummaging through the dumpsters. Asleep in the alley. But every once in a while winds up inside. Sometimes with loose change and crumpled bills to pay for a cup of coffee or a sandwhich. But other times, relying on the kindness of other people. It's the latter in this case. 

At an out of the way table, he sits with Oona. One of the smaller tables, just for two, against the wall. On his own, Jack would take the seat facing the door and most of the windows, but today he's yielded it to Oona. Everything about him says 'old and worn,' from his duct-taped sneakers, to his many-patched jeans, to his worn old flannel, to his wrinkled winter coat. And he smells. Not exceptionally badly, not like urine and rot, but like he hasn't seen the inside of a shower, nor his clothes the inside of a washing machine, in a while. 

But he and Oona are out of the way. Where, hopefully, Old Jack won't bother the other customers too much. ""S'not the same,"" Old Jack is saying to Oona, looking at the tea bag in his mug with dissatisfaction. He's got a deep voice, low, and kinda mumbly and grumbly. ""Should be loose-leaf."" A sadly common complaint. He grunts in disappointment, but none the less circles his hands around the mug, stealing what heat he can from the ceramic into his scarred, worn fingers.

Cal walks in, looks around, and takes a seat beside Jamie. He has enough money for a coffee, which he orders, with fifteen cents left for the tip. He glances at the paper Jamie'd pushed away. He shakes his head.

""Haven't seen track nor sign. You?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Cal walks in, looks around, and takes a seat beside Jamie. He has enough money for a coffee, which he orders, with fifteen cents left for the tip. He glances at the paper Jamie'd pushed away. He shakes his head.</p><p>""Haven't seen track nor sign. You?""</p>

Jamie glanced to Cal as he sat down next to her. She adjusted to give him some room, her mein ears twitching slightly at the thought.

""Nothing yet.""

She sips her sugary coffee glancing towards Oona and Old Jack in their booth. It was rare enough to catch Old Jack in here and having Oona show her face publicly with him, the two were certainly a few drawing eyes.


""We are going to try again in the morning, I hear the Sherif called in some out of town help.""

Just what we need, outsiders. She thought to herself.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Jamie glanced to Cal as he sat down next to her. She adjusted to give him some room, her mein ears twitching slightly at the thought.<br><br><span style=""color: rgb(118, 146, 60);""><span style=""color: rgb(155, 187, 89);"">""Nothing yet.""</span></span></p><p>She sips her sugary coffee glancing towards Oona and Old Jack in their booth. It was rare enough to catch Old Jack in here and having Oona show her face publicly with him, the two were certainly a few drawing eyes.</p><p><br><span style=""color: rgb(118, 146, 60);""><span style=""color: rgb(155, 187, 89);"">""We are going to try again in the morning, I hear the Sherif called in some out of town help.""</span><br></span></p><p><em><span style=""color: rgb(54, 96, 146);"">Just what we need, outsiders</span>. </em>She thought to herself.</p>

""Hm?"" Cal grunted inquisitively. ""Maybe they'll be putting me on payroll for a bit. Not that I don't mind volunteering for this cause, but money is always tight.""

Cal isn't exaggerating. He hunts most of what he eats, and tends to sleep in tree form, not being able to afford a house, let alone regular meals.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Hm?"" Cal grunted inquisitively. ""Maybe they'll be putting me on payroll for a bit. Not that I don't mind volunteering for this cause, but money is always tight.""</p><p>Cal isn't exaggerating. He hunts most of what he eats, and tends to sleep in tree form, not being able to afford a house, let alone regular meals.</p>

""Maybe,""  Jamie said glancing to Cal.

""I am sure we can pull something from the parks department to get you paid...you know Hawkins resort could maybe use a groundskeeper""

Jamie didn't know much of Cal's personal life but knew he lived on tough times. Then again she was never sure if he liked it that way, being an elemental and all. 


The thought of living in the woods cause her skin to crawl and her hand idly went up to sweep her hair to the side, feeling the antlers for a moment. 

""Pay or not...FBI just going make life harder if you ask me""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><span style=""color: rgb(118, 146, 60);"">""Maybe,"" </span> Jamie said glancing to Cal.<br><span style=""color: rgb(118, 146, 60);""><br>""I am sure we can pull something from the parks department to get you paid...you know Hawkins resort could maybe use a groundskeeper""</span><br><br>Jamie didn't know much of Cal's personal life but knew he lived on tough times. Cal exhales a long breath. ""FBI? Of course. I wasn't thinking. I figured you meant people from nearby parks when you said 'outsiders'. But kidnapping's a federal crime, isn't it?""

He begins to imagine how keeping the rites will go, with FBI in the way.

Then he imagines all the trouble an FBI agent going missing could cause.

""Maybe I could get assigned as local guide.""

But kidnapping's a federal crime, isn't it?""</p><p>He begins to imagine how keeping the rites will go, with FBI in the way.</p><p>Then he imagines all the trouble an FBI agent going missing could cause.</p><p>""Maybe I could get assigned as local guide.""</p>

The big house was so empty. Nothing but pictures of strangers I used to know all over the walls, books and trinkets overflowing their designated places. 

Lived in, but previously. Loud and lonely.

No less lonely than my place in Seattle but at least at home I knew all the sounds.

And the fridge was full of things that had either grown new life long ago or wasnt enough to really cook anything. I could go to the store but then that meant I intended to stay around. A statement I wasnt ready to make...even in the short term.

And so I was here. File under my arm and phone in my hand. I find a booth thats empty and a bit apart from the current diners, and I sit so that I can see the door. People will whisper, for any number of reasons, and I might as well get it over with.

Elbows propped on the table around her coffee, Oona's hunched shoulders allowed a curtain of lank hair to fall between her and the rest of the room. Old Jack's courtesy did not go ignored or unused, her pale eyes skittering back to the door regardless of whether or not it had opened. It was always a risk, being out and about; or at least it always felt like one. Plenty of people showed their disdain for her fetch's actions with silence, dirty looks, or the occasional snide comment, which she had learned to live with. But there was always the chance someone would be gunning for a fight, or at the very least someone they felt justified in being unpleasant to.

Today seemed okay, though, and she'd offered to buy Old Jack lunch so at least the company was good, even if he was sometimes riper than a person might like. Glancing down to his mug as he spoke, Oona made a sympathetic noise in her throat. ""Could you... tear the teabag?"" She kept her voice low, not quite a murmur, and felt a little silly for suggesting it. If it was that easy, surely he would've done it already. He also didn't seem like the kind of guy who would mind filtering tealeaves through his teeth.

Her eyes flicked away to register Cal joining Jamie at the counter, and lingered on the woman who came in shortly after, documents under her arms. Picking absentmindedly at a peeling callous, she took a sip of coffee and leaned against the wall. ""Coffee's good today, pretty strong. Oh, 'm working on a new project, only just got started last night. It's one of those conceptual wedding rings, I'm etching their partner's fingerprints onto the inside of the band. I tried to explain they're going to wear off a lot faster than you'd think, gold is soft, but it's a nice enough thought I guess."" It was a nice routine, having someone to tell these little details to.

""I'll pass that along to my boss. I am sure they will need all the help they can-""

It was at that moment Jamie noticed Hal across the room.  Pausing she sort of nodded in the woman's direction hoping the Wood Elemental would pick up the cue and not make a scene out of it...never could tell with their type.

The woman looked familiar in a way that Jamie was unable to place, just familiar enough to feel like a nagging at the back of her head, but strange enough to be noticeable in a dinner filled with locals. 

Wonder if she is part of the investigation...or maybe just passing thru. she thought to her self.


The beast nose twitched a bit as she took a sip of her coffee before she glanced to Cal to see what his reaction was.

Cal waits patiently for Jamie to finish her sentence. When she doesn't, he looks at her to make sure she's all right. She doesn't appear injured, poisoned, or choking. Her simple nod doesn't register as he looks for signs of damage. Her nose twitch does catch his attention. He knows her Beast-nature sometimes caught things he didn't. He waits a moment, then stretches a little, twisting his neck as if trying to get a crick out of it. He recognizes Oona and Old Jack, but they were there when he'd come in. The woman who came in shortly after him looked sort of familiar, like someone he'd seen around before, but he couldn't place her.

Looking at Jamie, Cal raises both eyebrows in silent question. Whatever she's trying to signal to him, he's missing completely.

Whatever she's trying to signal to him, he's missing completely.</p>

A woman with a name tag reading Tori slides a menu in front of me and asks if she can start me off with a drink. I order water and a coffee with cream and sugar and then go ahead and get whatever the special is. And pie. 

There isn't much I miss about places like this, but pie is one of them. 

And then I open the folder and read over the notes. It's whatever was assembled and sent to the main office, nothing new or updated and I haven't checked in with the local LEO's yet but I want to be sure I'm prepared.

Conversation stalled when I walked in, and some people are still casually looking at me when they think I don't notice. But that's ok. What I really want is to over hear what they're talking about. Everyone knows everyone in places like this, and how many pieces of toilet paper that they use when they take a shit. 

Sometimes I hear more when they talk to each other than when they talk to me directly.

Jamie turned back toward Cal who obviously missed her cue.  She chuckled shaking her head before asking for a refill across the counter before turning to Cal speaking in a low voice.

""Woman, sitting in a booth. Seems familiar but haven't seen her around. I bet she's part of the backup the sheriff called for"" She stated softly.

Please don't make a scene cal, please don't make a scene. Her mind raced as she observed the elemental and his reaction to Jamie thoughts.

I bet she's part of the backup the sheriff called for"" </span>She stated softly.</p><p><span style=""""><span style=""""><span style=""""><i style=""color: rgb(75, 172, 198);"">Please don't make a scene cal, please don't make a scene.</i><b style=""color: rgb(75, 172, 198); font-style: italic;""> </b>Her mind raced as she observed the elemental and his reaction to Jamie thoughts. </span></span></span></p>
""Hmm. Could be. Or could be coincidence."" Cal shrugs. ""How's your mother doing?""

column2: ""S'not the same,"" Jack echoes at Oona's suggested tea-solution. You couldn't say the old man is pouting, but he's certainly disappointed. Well... at least he's used to it. None the less, it's steeped for long enough, so he lifts the bag out, sets it aside, and takes a long sip, letting the hot beverage warm his bones. ""Project..."" he echoes Oona this time, instead of himself, to show his interest, lifting his eyes from the tea to focus on her. ""Hmm..."" He rumbles, a sound deep in his chest. ""Soft. Gold. Gold for the rings... Maybe..."" He taps a finger lightly on the table, ""Maybe make the print outta somethin' harder. Then put it inside? What's the word... insert, inset... something like that?"" He offers. Old Jack's had some experience with the arts of making, but it pales in comparison to Oona's expertise, and he knows it.

He glances up as a newcomer comes in. Old Jack's been around and about Naukati Lake for decades. There's hardly a face he doesn't know. And though it's been many years since he last saw her, and Old Jack's mind may not be a steel trap, something makes the connection. ""Hal,"" He says, in his hoarse, gravely voice. Not very loud. Not shouting, not calling out, not even a greeting. More a statement of fact, but loud enough to overhear.

OOC: I'm spending a Fate point to introduce a story element, if @Gracieblove doesn't object; Hal and Old Jack have met before. They might not know each other well, but at some point before Hal left town, she got some unsolicited advice and/or guidance during a chance encounter with Old Jack. This advice/guidance had the full force of his prophetic powers, and though his phrasing may have been a little vague or cryptic it was good advice/guidance. Whether Hal followed it, however, and what exactly it was about... I'll happily let Gracieblove decide.

column1:
Jamie relaxed for a moment as Cal did not seem to mind the new person in town. 

It's just your anxiety...

She let out a soft sigh as he changed the topic.  Placing down her now empty coffee mug she looked at Cal with a shrug.

""The usual, she concerned and isn't happy about my hours at work. Says, 'Gets in the way of a personal life'.""

She rolls her eyes.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Jamie relaxed for a moment as Cal did not seem to mind the new person in town. <br><br><em><span style=""color: rgb(75, 172, 198);"">It's just your anxiety...</span></em><br><br>She let out a soft sigh as he changed the topic.  Placing down her now empty coffee mug she looked at Cal with a shrug.<br><br><span style=""color: rgb(118, 146, 60);"">""The usual, she concerned and isn't happy about my hours at work. Says, 'Gets in the way of a personal life'.""<br></span><br>She rolls her eyes.  <br><br><br></p>

Cal chuckles, softly. ""Her way of hinting she wants grandkids?"" Cal thinks about his parents, now in care and not knowing who he is. But they play a good cribbage game and seem happy enough at life.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Cal chuckles, softly. ""Her way of hinting she wants grandkids?"" Cal thinks about his parents, now in care and not knowing who he is. But they play a good cribbage game and seem happy enough at life.</p>

Ding Ding

The doorbell rang its joyful song, heralding the entrance of another into the diner. Heads turn and eyes fall upon Lillian Rivera. The older woman was known to almost all in the town in some way or another. 

She had a demanding presence for such a small woman; she was well dressed, an elegant scarf wrapped around her shoulders, and her silver hair tied back. Her stern eyes surveyed the diner in an inscrutable expression.  Her gaze lingering on each person, one at a time before she gave a cold smile to Tori behind the counter.

“One pie and a glass of milk, dear” 

She slowly walked towards a booth, pausing as she saw Oona and “Old Jack” she paused and smiled. 

“It’s nice to see charity in these trying times” 

She gave a small nod, and a chilling smile before sitting down in her own booth, as her pie arrives.

“Thank you, dear”.

Her gaze then fell upon the newcomer in town, Hal.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><em><strong> Ding Ding<br></strong></em></p><p>The doorbell rang its joyful song, heralding the entrance of another into the diner. Heads turn and eyes fall upon Lillian Rivera. The older woman was known to almost all in the town in some way or another. </p><p>She had a demanding presence for such a small woman; she was well dressed, an elegant scarf wrapped around her shoulders, and her silver hair tied back. Her stern eyes surveyed the diner in an inscrutable expression.  Her gaze lingering on each person, one at a time before she gave a cold smile to Tori behind the counter.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);""><span style=""color: rgb(127, 96, 0);""><span style=""color: rgb(242, 195, 20);""><span style=""color: rgb(127, 96, 0);"">“One pie and a glass of milk, dear” </span><br></span></span></span></p><p>She slowly walked towards a booth, pausing as she saw Oona and “Old Jack” she paused and smiled. </p><p><span style=""color: rgb(255, 230, 148);""><span style=""color: rgb(242, 195, 20);""><span style=""color: rgb(127, 96, 0);"">“It’s nice to see charity in these trying times” </span><br></span></span></p><p>She gave a small nod, and a chilling smile before sitting down in her own booth, as her pie arrives.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(255, 230, 148);""><span style=""color: rgb(242, 195, 20);""><span style=""color: rgb(127, 96, 0);"">“Thank you, dear”.</span><br></span></span></p><p>Her gaze then fell upon the newcomer in town, Hal.</p>

His voice is the same as it is in my memory. I'd noticed him but aside from the one time he'd spoken to be before, we had never really interacted much.

But that one time was enough to really stand out in memory. 

((OOC: I'll post a journal about the previous experience later tonight))

I'm actually fairly surprised he knows, let alone remembers, my name. 

And then the little bell rings and we're all being individually considered by cold eyes. I feel instantly like we're being judged, but can't seem to tell what the outcome of that judgement might have been.

But where before people were quietly discussing who  I was, who  they thought I was related  to, and rumors of why I had left... her ppearance has turned any discussion away from me. Which is fine.

When the door suddenly opens, Jamie becomes ridged as a board. The Priestess queen of Autumn was one of Jamie's living nightmares.

""I..i should leave.""she looks at Cal. ""You know, get ready for the search tomorrow""

""Yeah, I could do that, but it'll take twice as long,"" Oona murmured against the lip of her mug. ""I was going to cast it originally but the ridges would be so short, they'd wear down even faster..."" She let the words trail off as her eyes followed Jack's, back to the woman with the documents.

""Who is that? I don't recognize her."" The words were intended to be soft, the same tone as all her words, but some things have a way of carrying when you don't want them to. Unsure if the woman in question had heard her, Oona went back to pretending she was part of the wall.

Until, of course, a certain Horrible Woman appeared. She wanted a snappy comeback for when the Autumn Queen took a dig at her, or Old Jack, or both of them, but her mouth dried and suddenly her hands were so fascinating she couldn't seem to lift her eyes from them. Dammit. She couldn't blame Jamie at all for hightailing it out of there was soon as Lillian's shadow crossed the threshhold, but after that comment Oona couldn't leave without feeling like she was running away.

Like the slightly overbearing angel she was, Tori chose that moment to descending with the food they'd ordered a little while ago. Deposited with a cheerful smile and a quick squeeze to Oona's shoulder, some of the ice left the Wizened's hands and she was able to unlock them from around her mug.

Lillian sipped her milk. Her eyes locked on to Hal in an unnerving manner as she studied the woman. After a few minutes, she gestures to Hal in a small crook of her finger and then opens her hand towards the seat across from her. 

After this, she turns to Tori as she passes from Oona' and Old Jack table.

""Could you get my friend another round of coffee please."" she smiled to Tori before turning her attention towards Hal. Eyebrow raised expectedly.

Old Jack's old eyes crickle as he narrows them at Rivera, her snide words earning no more than a deep grunt from him. The pair of them didn't have much reason to cross paths, to mortal eyes. Except when Old Jack has one of his 'episodes' and bursts in on a high-society dinner, or corners her on the street talking nonsense. Their alliance in the Freehold was a shaky one, relying entirely on a ruthless pursuit of wyrd lore and safekeeping of the Pacts to overcome more than a handful of personal contempt going both ways. 

He looks back down to his tea, and it's unsatisfactory bag. ""The Pearson girl,"" he finally answers Oona. Most people are 'girl' or 'boy' to Old Jack, as ancient as he is. Doesn't matter if they're in their fifties with grandchildren on their knees. ""She got outta here. Guess she came back,"" he glances up at Hal again, expression difficult to read. The dream of much of Naukati Lake's youth is to 'get out.' Hard to imagine that coming back is anything but a severe letdown. 

At that point, the food is delivered. ""Thankyou,"" Old Jack rumbles quietly, eyes down at the food instead of up at Tori. He unrolls his napkin and picks up his knife and fork, metal clinking. ""So do it their way,"" he says to Oona, what could easily be mistaken for a non-sequitur. ""Can't stop folk from bein' fools if that's what they wanna be. Earn yerself nothin' but heartache tryin'."" He's gone back to Oona's project, the rings. Though that may not be immediately obvious.

I don't live here anymore. I don't have any reason to pack my items up and move over to her table. 

I don't care about her approval or disapproval.

But I close the folder and slide out of my seat.

""Ms. Rivera."" I give her a polite smile. No sense being rude, and it's not a lie to say I'm curious. 

""What can I do for you?""

“Miss.Pearson”  Riveria gave a small smile. “So good to see you, Young Lady. It’s been too long”  She said that as if she had some sort of familiarity with her, which was far from true.

She sipped her glass of milk gesturing again to the seat across from her.

“I take it this isn't a family visit for Dear Raven, is it? That would be too convenient given the recent turn of events. Are you here for work then?""

Interrogation and conversation can so often look similar.

The difference was usually in that unquantifiable element of feelings. She tells me it's been too long like shes a caring neighbor or family friend. Not that I'd really know how to act if that was the case. Family is...hard...

I...still hadn't gone to see Raven. I hadn't seen her in person in a couple of years and we really both seemed totally fine with our current relationship status of texting and liking things on each other's Facebook walls. And we took turns sending money for shared gifts to dad at appropriate events.

""Yes ma'am, here to hopefully help."" I didn't know what to say to her, and the 12 year old kid version of me was wanting to hold very very still and quiet to avoid getting in trouble. 

Which was ridiculous really. You don't ""get in trouble"" at my age.

""I am glad to hear it"" she smiles 

""it's nice to know we have a local helping out. Feels right you know?"" She forked the pie on her plate before her.

""You should visit Raven, what a sweet girl,running that book store. I am sure she will be thrilled to see you. You plan on sticking around after we find the kids?""

When Id been assigned this case the very same comment was made. I had quickly stated that calling me a local was stretch, but when she says it I just nod.

She mentions visiting Raven and I work to not let anything show on my expression. ""I will. Just spending some time getting my bearings first.""

Seeing my sister would be nice, but then we'd have that obligation to fill the silence that inevitably comes after the first few minutes of catching up. I still planned to do so, just...not tonight.

But then she asks if I'll be sticking around and I stop thinking about my sister and start thinking about my husb...ex husband. ""Only until I'm needed elsewhere."" I don't say that I can't stay here. 

Because then I have to tell her how this whole damn place tears open memories that I can't begin to deal with. The psychologist in me sees my aversion and then gets flipped the bird by the me that had to walk away from here.

Physician heal thyself? Maybe some other day.

So, after only a small pause I add, ""The kids may need access to services after. One of us usually stays around until we're sure everything is taken care of."" On this matter I have a lot of practice hiding my emotions.

But the reality is that we were called in late and only after multiple abductions. It was unlikely that three kids would all just wander off on their own, especially the second and third. 

And it was also unlikely that our unsub wasn't the same person or persons, and the time-frames between abductions was... problematic. But I found it unlikely that they were all off in a commune somewhere. More likely, he replaced the child with a new one when he'd broken or killed the last.

What we don't say outloud is the likelihood of finding these children alive was slim even before we got here. What we don't say is that we really would get more information from a fourth, because we don't want a fourth child to be taken but our unspoken fear is that if we don't catch the person responsible than we will always wonder if the next missing kid is our fault for that failure.

Instead, ""I wasn't familiar with the family names involved. Were they new to town?""

For a moment it didn't even occur to Oona to try and tie in what Old Jack had said to their previous conversation. The thread of it had been cut in her mind by the Autumn Queen's appearance, and sometimes he just said stuff. Granted, this seemed slightly more topical than some of the stuff he said, and she was game to try and figure out how it applied. How to reconcile 'do it their way' with 'sometimes a fool is just a fool,' in terms of the Freehold, the town- oh yeah, rings. He was talking about the rings. Of course.

It was good advice, either way. She could admit that. But it wasn't easy to follow. ""Yeah, that's true. It's my job to advise them, but in the end if that's what they ask for, it's what they should get."" Picking up a triangle of toast she knew would shatter as soon as she put butter on it, like it always did, Oona reached for her knife. ""Just drives me nuts when people don't listen."" And there the toast went, in half with a bit of butter and a whole lot of crumbs. She picked up one of the pieces.

""You been sleeping okay lately?"" the Wizened asked offhandedly, eyes on her toast and desperately trying to ignore Rivera grilling Hal nearby.

She picked up one of the pieces.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""You been sleeping okay lately?"" </span>the Wizened asked offhandedly, eyes on her toast and desperately trying to ignore Rivera grilling Hal nearby.</p>

""Hmmf,"" he grunts, slathering whipped butter across the golden pancakes on the plate in front of him, watching it melt into the hot, fluffy disks. ""No,"" he finally answers. Predictable, really. Old Jack doesn't have a history of sleeping well. ""Thaw's come. Little better when it's not so cold..."" He sets down his knife and reaches for the maple syrup, pouring it liberally over his plate, ""... Stars don't sleep, though. They ain't loud, but... they keep me awake. Talkin' to me. Don't care if I listen, just talk. So much talk."" 

The syrup bottle clatters back into the dish it arrived in, ""... They're chasin' me. And I run because I have to, because catchin' is worse than runnin, but they follow into my dreams,"" it takes on a strange tone. Almost droning on. Intense, but sort of monotonous. The calm, quiet ravings of a madman. ""And I tell them to stop but if they stop then who's grounded when the storm comes and the shadows have teeth so they can't stop, and they chase me and I run but I don't go no where. And I need to get back out to the crow's nest and draw a line, yeah, a line..."" His fork slices through the syrup-soaked cakes, and he spears the bite, bringing it to his mouth and chewing slowly, ""... Them crows are wily. Made their own deal with the night and shadow. Gotta draw a line. Yeah. Yeah.""

There was a uncanny cunning behind the older woman’s eyes.  SHe listened to Hal closely, a smile on her face before taking a sip of her glass of milk.

“Oh they been here for a while now, the Applegates longest of all. But the Kloses live out of town and the Newarks are artists of some sort or another.”

Rivera glances around the dinner for a moment. 

“If you were asking me, which I know your not. I’d check in on the young folks these days, you know how they are. WIth the their dares and games. They play far to much around the forest if you ask me.”

Suddenly her  phone buzzed and she glanced down at it. 

“Sadly I must depart, urgent business, you understand. Do take care, miss Pearson. I wish you best of luck, for the children's sake”

Kids on dares? ""I'll keep that in mind. Have a good day ma'am."" And I find myself filled with relief that she's directed her attention elsewhere. 

I'd been looking for something that tied the kids together or made them stand out, but I hadn't gotten it from that conversation, so I turn to head back to my table where I can read some more.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Kids on dares? ""I'll keep that in mind. Have a good day ma'am."" And I find myself filled with relief that she's directed her attention elsewhere. </p><p>I'd been looking for something that tied the kids together or made them stand out, but I hadn't gotten it from that conversation, so I turn to head back to my table where I can read some more.</p>

There's a bit of a clink as Old Jack sets down his silverware, and then a slow, low movement as his hand works out towards the edge of the table. As the FBI agent moves to pass him by, that calloused hand reaches out and grasps Hal's. Not snatching it, gripping swiftly and surely. Hal can feel his thin bones pressing against the back of her hand. 

All at once, Jack is looking up at her, fixing his good eye on one of her's. An intense gaze, full of some cryptic meaning, maybe something that only makes sense to him. But however focused the old man seems, his mind is far away. Flung outward and beyond, looking down into the well and up from it's depths all at once, as his mind skates against eternity. It is a misnomer to call them visions. Most include sight, but they are flashes of insight, of meaning, of emotion and consequence. 

After an uncomfortably long moment, trembling in his seat at the booth in Mary's, the old man's face twists into a concerned expression, like that of a worried friend. ""You know what tuh do, don't you Hal?"" He asks, voice low and urgent. Beyond mortal perceptions, lightning flashes and thunder rumbles in his mantle. ""You know what tuh do... when your back's against a wall?"" 

His gaze lingers for a stuttered half-breath, before the moment collapses. His grip vanishes, and his gaze falls, down past Hal, back towards the table, but as if he's not really seeing anything at all. Something's coming for Hal. The future is never certain, but Old Jack knows one thing for sure: Whatever Hal has in store, she can't hide from it, she can't run from it. She'll have to face it. Head on.

OOC: Old Jack is using Reading the Portents (Omens 1) on Halcyon Pearson. With a Success with Style, I am creating the Aspect Back Against A Wall. Within the next few months, the most significant, emotionally important event in Hal's life will be something she can't escape or hide from, she'll have to confront it head-on. This Aspect can be compelled by Players and Storytellers to drive things in that direction.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>There's a bit of a clink as Old Jack sets down his silverware, and then a slow, low movement as his hand works out towards the edge of the table. As the FBI agent moves to pass him by, that calloused hand reaches out and grasps Hal's. Not snatching it, gripping swiftly and surely. Hal can feel his thin bones pressing against the back of her hand. </p><p>All at once, Jack is looking up at her, fixing his good eye on one of her's. An intense gaze, full of some cryptic meaning, maybe something that only makes sense to him. But however focused the old man seems, his mind is far away. Flung outward and beyond, looking down into the well and up from it's depths all at once, as his mind skates against eternity. It is a misnomer to call them visions. Most include sight, but they are flashes of insight, of meaning, of emotion and consequence. </p><p>After an uncomfortably long moment, trembling in his seat at the booth in Mary's, the old man's face twists into a concerned expression, like that of a worried friend. <span style=""color: rgb(84, 141, 212);"">""You know what tuh do, don't you Hal?""</span> He asks, voice low and urgent. Beyond mortal perceptions, lightning flashes and thunder rumbles in his mantle. <span style=""color: rgb(84, 141, 212);"">""You know what tuh do... when your back's against a wall?""</span> </p><p>His gaze lingers for a stuttered half-breath, before the moment collapses. His grip vanishes, and his gaze falls, down past Hal, back towards the table, but as if he's not really seeing anything at all. Something's coming for Hal. The future is never certain, but Old Jack knows one thing for sure: Whatever Hal has in store, she can't hide from it, she can't run from it. She'll have to face it. Head on. </p><hr>

<p><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">OOC: Old Jack is using Reading the Portents (Omens 1) on Halcyon Pearson. With a Success with Style, I am creating the Aspect <em><strong>Back Against A Wall</strong></em>. Within the next few months, the most significant, emotionally important event in Hal's life will be something she can't escape or hide from, she'll have to confront it head-on. This Aspect can be compelled by Players and Storytellers to drive things in that direction. </span></p>

I pull my hand back and frown, but he's not looking at me anymore. A shiver runs down my spine, because the last time he'd talked to me had been the difference between life and death. 

It's all I can do to not question him. To crouch down and look in his eyes again and ask him...and then I notice...no one else heard him. No one seems to notice that he even spoke to me. If they did they're not saying anything about it.

They're all watching Lillian Rivera make her exit.

I clasp my hands together, Old Jack hadn't hurt me, and yet I can still feel the gentle pressure where he'd touched me. And then I scoot on past him and back to my table. ""I'll take it to go please."" I tell the waitress, Tori, and pack my things. 

Maybe I'd eat at dad's afterall.

And then I scoot on past him and back to my table. ""I'll take it to go please."" I tell the waitress, Tori, and pack my things. </p><p>Maybe I'd eat at dad's afterall.</p>

column3: 3.1 Launch party. The Moore Sisters.

column4: Page is lead down a corridor by an obviously nervous David Gallows and presented to the Moore sisters.

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-278705""><div class=""row"">

“Come in”, says a woman’s voice smooth and measured.

“So you’re our little contest winner. The one that David has been going on about.”

The three women are arrayed comfortably around the room one on divan, the other two on deep, plush armchairs. In front of them, on a coffee table is a mess of papers, pens and pencils, tools of the writer and the editor. Also, more strangely, a ball of string, and a pair of scissors. 

There's no chair for Page. She must stand.

“Really, Lacey”, says one of them. This sister has dark hair, pulled back tight. “Why are we even giving her an allotment? Can’t I just cut her out all together?”

“Patience Anne”, replies the tallest blonde sister, “Chloe has drawn the threads of the story together. We should at least see if she has the talent, to use them.”

“Tell us”, The blond one says, “why we shouldn’t just give you your fifteen minutes of fame, cut your character off, and you slide off into obscurity?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><span style=""color: rgb(79, 129, 189);"">“Come in”</span>, says a woman’s voice smooth and measured.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(79, 129, 189);"">“So you’re our little contest winner. The one that David has been going on about.”</span></p><p>The three women are arrayed comfortably around the room one on divan, the other two on deep, plush armchairs. In front of them, on a coffee table is a mess of papers, pens and pencils, tools of the writer and the editor. Also, more strangely, a ball of string, and a pair of scissors. </p><p>There's no chair for Page. She must stand.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(149, 55, 52);"">“Really, Lacey”</span>, says one of them. This sister has dark hair, pulled back tight. <span style=""color: rgb(149, 55, 52);"">“Why are we even giving her an allotment? Can’t I just cut her out all together?”</span></p><p><span style=""color: rgb(79, 129, 189);"">“Patience Anne”</span>, replies the tallest blonde sister, <span style=""color: rgb(79, 129, 189);"">“Chloe has drawn the threads of the story together. We should at least see if she has the talent, to use them.”</span></p><p><span style=""color: rgb(79, 129, 189);"">“Tell us”</span>, The blond one says,<span style=""color: rgb(79, 129, 189);""> “why we shouldn’t just give you your fifteen minutes of fame, cut your character off, and you slide off into obscurity?”</span></p>

Page stares, wide-eyed, caught off-guard and uncertain of what to say. “Um, w-well, it seems like a lot of trouble to go through, to have the contest and bring me in just to, you know, cut me out?” 

She rubs her fingers on the edge of the leather jacket, something she’s been doing all evening to try and comfort herself in the increasingly strange environment into which she’s been plunged.

Oh god, that’s not a good answer! Do you want to just go home? After all the trouble you went through? All the sacrifice of your parents?!

She stops fidgeting with the jacket and stands up tall, shoulders back, the jacket falling fully open for the first time tonight. “I am an asset. Yes, the show got a lot of media attention with the contest, something I’m sure strong writers like you don’t care about. But the contest cast a wide net, far wider than any normal talent call would. And you got me. Out of a National, gosh no, international group, you got me. You know what that is? That’s fate.”

She strides a few purposeful steps left and right as she quotes (and doesn’t notice a seam pop at the hemline of the dress):

“Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie,

Which we ascribe to heaven or the fates in the sky.

Gives us free scope, only doth backward we pull,

Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.”

“I can be that remedy. I won’t be dull. I’m unknown, untouched by this town or the fans or the culture or the expectations of fame or the ego of stardom. I’m... clay. Raw. Unformed. In your hands, ready to be shaped.”

column4:
What started as an evening drizzle has took a turn for the worse. Torrential rains beat down relentlessly. A cold wind blows unpredictably, driving watery chills deep into the bones. In the distance thunder rumbles.

The construction site is located far away from any busy center of traffic and commerce, at the edge of the Westland and Midden-delfland. A brand new suburban neighbourhood it’s supposed to become, a late vinex project. But work has been delayed for months now. Graffiti adorns the concrete structures. Tools have been left to rust.

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-278792""><div class=""row"">

The place is abandoned but for a lone figure in a dark brown trenchcoat, collar popped against the wind and rain, who stands in an unfinished home portal, semi-sheltered against the elements. He flicks the wheel of his lighter, but the wind is howling too forceful for Gerard Winckelman to produce a flame that burns long enough to light his rolie. Finally he gives up. He curses, glancing impatiently at his wrist watch.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The place is abandoned but for a lone figure in a dark brown trenchcoat, collar popped against the wind and rain, who stands in an unfinished home portal, semi-sheltered against the elements. He flicks the wheel of his lighter, but the wind is howling too forceful for Gerard Winckelman to produce a flame that burns long enough to light his rolie. Finally he gives up. He curses, glancing impatiently at his wrist watch.</p>

""Nights like these are like vacation."" Gerard hears from his left... Leaning against the frontage he sees Fred Janssen and his malformed face. A face not many see for what it really is.

""... this weather...I could go out there, walk the streets and no one would be bothered...""

""I appreciate the trouble you took to get here...""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Nights like these are like vacation."" Gerard hears from his left... Leaning against the frontage he sees Fred Janssen and his malformed face. A face not many see for what it really is.</p><p>""... this weather...I could go out there, walk the streets and no one would be bothered...""</p><p>""I appreciate the trouble you took to get here...""</p>

“Jezus Christ!,” Gerard instinctively takes a few steps backwards, right out into the pouring rain again.

“Jezus fucking Christ! Fuck! Waldo? Jezus -fuck, Waldo. Is that you? Fuck me,” he laughs, a nervous laugh. He’s clearly quite uncomfortable, but the sound of Fred Janssen’s voice seems to give Gerard enough reassurance to shuffle ever so slightly closer again, close enough at least to keep out of the rain.

He sniffs and coughs. He tries not to stare, but he can’t help it. He coughs again:

“Yeah, eh - yeah. No problem,” he offers his hand.

“Good to see you,” he lies, “Do you just want to get down to bussiness so we don’t have to rot away longer than necessary in this godforsaken weather?”

He sniffs again. He coughs. Then he tries to light his rolie, meanwhile he mumbles: “Jas send me, Jasmine de Port,” he looks up and out over the flame, as he puffs to get the cigarette going, “Kind of surprised you two know eachother, but anyway. She says to offer you an alliance. Says it’s a long term thing and that there’s a title for you at the end. Or something else of equal value, if you prefer.”

He shivvers.

Jezus -fuck, Waldo. Is that you? Fuck me,” he laughs, a nervous laugh. He’s clearly quite uncomfortable, but the sound of Fred Janssen’s voice seems to give Gerard enough reassurance to shuffle ever so slightly closer again, close enough at least to keep out of the rain.</p><p>He sniffs and coughs. He coughs. Then he tries to light his rolie, meanwhile he mumbles: “Jas send me, Jasmine de Port,” he looks up and out over the flame, as he puffs to get the cigarette going, “Kind of surprised you two know eachother, but anyway. She says to offer you an alliance. Says it’s a long term thing and that there’s a title for you at the end. Or something else of equal value, if you prefer.”</p><p>He shivvers.</p>

""In the flesh... what's left of it, that is."" 

In reply Fred extends his cold hands, that look pockmarked and blistered. Interested in this man that dares to meet with him, he looks Gerard in the eyes and remembers to blink now and then... Mentally a profile of Gerard begins to form; registering his face and demeanor, recalling rumors he heard about weed operations, tasks performed for Jasmine, Jesse's intell...

Nodding first before replying and ignoring the remark about Jasmin and Waldo being acquaintences Fred replies: "" de Port.. an alliance you say.. That means she is making some big plans then.""

""I tell her where the ich is, so she can scratch it, eh?""

Fred removes his soaked cap from his head, squeezes out the water and puts it back on.

With an expectant look on his face he waits for Gerard to specify the nature of this alliance.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""In the flesh... what's left of it, that is."" </p><p>In reply Fred extends his cold hands, that look pockmarked and blistered. Interested in this man that dares to meet with him, he looks Gerard in the eyes and remembers to blink now and then... Mentally a profile of Gerard begins to form; registering his face and demeanor, recalling rumors he heard about weed operations, tasks performed for Jasmine, Jesse's intell...</p><p>Nodding first before replying and ignoring the remark about Jasmin and Waldo being acquaintences Fred replies: "" de Port.. an alliance you say.. That means she is making some big plans then.""</p><p>""I tell her where the ich is, so she can scratch it, eh?""</p><p>Fred removes his soaked cap from his head, squeezes out the water and puts it back on.</p><p>With an expectant look on his face he waits for Gerard to specify the nature of this alliance.</p>

He shrugs and nods. “I’ll relay that back for you.”

Gerard scratches his head, not entirely sure how to proceed.

“She asks you to track the Night Mayor’s holdings and assets. Says it’s time for a regime change...”

He takes a drag and chuckles nervously, again.

“I’m guessing she’s not talking about Jules Deelder...”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>He shrugs and nods. “I’ll relay that back for you.”</p><p>Gerard scratches his head, not entirely sure how to proceed.</p><p>“She asks you to track the Night Mayor’s holdings and assets. Says it’s time for a regime change...”</p><p>He takes a drag and chuckles nervously, again.</p><p>“I’m guessing she’s not talking about Jules Deelder...”</p>

Waldo smiles at the mention of Jules Deelder. ""Ha! I hope not, who could replace him as the 'night mayor'?! Surely not de Port, her brain is not fried and peppered enough.""

""No.. I am right and she wants to play high stakes poker,... or is it bridge?""

With a cocked head Waldo looks to see how Gerard reacts. Before letting him answer he continues, on a more serious tone:

""I can do what she asks... however, ... titles are overrated, and temporary,... always temporary. Or am I a Fool, perhaps?""

Waldo pauzes again for a moment, just long enough to let the moment become awkward.

""mmm... Yes. Tell her I said yes."" - ""Do you have family, Gerard?""

Before letting him answer he continues, on a more serious tone:</p><p>""I can do what she asks... however, ... titles are overrated, and temporary,... always temporary. Or am I a Fool, perhaps?""</p><p>Waldo pauzes again for a moment, just long enough to let the moment become awkward.</p><p>""mmm... Yes. Tell her I said yes."" - ""Do you have family, Gerard?""</p>

Throughout the vocalisation of Waldo’s internal monologue, Gerard has a puzzled look on his face. He seems almost relieved to be asked a normal question, even though it is oddly timed. At least he knows what it’s about.

“I’ve got the one brother,” he says, “He’s a widower, with two kids - my nephews. It’s hard for him, but he manages. Great guy. Much better than me...”

He takes a drag of his cigarette, “Anyway, yeah - if that’s all then I’m going to make my way home.”

column3: [Callum] A date with a girl

column4:
Callum arranged a meeting with Bella, a few messages away and they were happily meeting in this rundown bar.

The bar itself obviously, had been a fairly nice and even a fancy place... a very long time ago. Lack of upkeep, and more importantly, nobody actually caring to keep up the image and allowing anyone to drag in some old TV, or stick random stickers over the place made it into what it is.

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-278951""><div class=""row"">
When Callum arrived, Bella was still not there.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>When Callum arrived, Bella was still not there. </p>

The door to the establishement burst open with a hard ding from the bell above the entrance, Callum Kelly Kramered in. He nodded at the bartender and looked around, expecting to see Bella Goodwin.

When he’d comcluded she wasn’t there, barring the possibility of an improbable toilet break, he walked up to the bar and ordered a Long Island  ice tea, without an umbrella. “Not a fan of the wooden sticks,” he winked, before starting a conversation with the patron next to him about baseball tactics.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The door to the establishement burst open with a hard ding from the bell above the entrance, Callum Kelly Kramered in. He nodded at the bartender and looked around, expecting to see Bella Goodwin.</p><p>When he’d comcluded she wasn’t there, barring the possibility of an improbable toilet break, he walked up to the bar and ordered a Long Island  ice tea, without an umbrella. “Not a fan of the wooden sticks,” he winked, before starting a conversation with the patron next to him about baseball tactics.</p>

Once he was halfway through his conversation, Bella approached him as out of nowhere. Callum didn't notice her entering. 


""Good evening, Kelly."" she slid into the chair next to him, quickly ordering a drink. ""Whatever's your specialty"" she winked to the bartender, obviously not interested in choosing the precise drink.

""So as I understand, you're looking into what happened to me last week?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Once he was halfway through his conversation, Bella approached him as out of nowhere. Callum didn't notice her entering. </p><p><br>""Good evening, Kelly."" she slid into the chair next to him, quickly ordering a drink. ""Whatever's your specialty"" she winked to the bartender, obviously not interested in choosing the precise drink.</p><p>""So as I understand, you're looking into what happened to me last week?"" </p>

“ - so that’s why I’m saying you should never...  hold that thought...”

C.K. glanced over, one eye brow raised indicating he didn’t appreciate the interruption. He sized Bella Goodwin up, meanwhile sipping his drink through the straw until his cheeks were full. Then he blew the Long Island back into his glass. When bubbles broke the surface he turned to the bartender and said:

“These’re on the house. Right, Gary?”

He then turned to Bella, tapped the bar and, with his other hand, indicated an empty booth in the back.

“Step into my office,” he said and lead the way.

When they’d sat down, he took out a cigarette and started chewing its filter’s end.

“Please start by what you recall last, from the time before and after your unfortunate accident.”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>“ - so that’s why I’m saying you should never...  hold that thought...”</p><p>C.K. glanced over, one eye brow raised indicating he didn’t appreciate the interruption. He sized Bella Goodwin up, meanwhile sipping his drink through the straw until his cheeks were full. Then he blew the Long Island back into his glass. When bubbles broke the surface he turned to the bartender and said:</p><p>“<strong>These’re on the house</strong>. Right, Gary?”</p><p>He then turned to Bella, tapped the bar and, with his other hand, indicated an empty booth in the back.</p><p>“Step into my office,” he said and lead the way.</p><p>When they’d sat down, he took out a cigarette and started chewing its filter’s end.</p><p>“Please start by what you recall last, from the time before and after your unfortunate accident.”</p>

She shrugged.

""I don't' really remember much. One moment, I was walking down the street, then some tingling in the chest... and then the next moment I'm in a gory bath of blood and guts in Pods bathroom. Barricaded the doors immediately, and called Matthew to help me.""

""Tell me, Callum, why are you doing this? Doesn't seem that you'd care about someone like Matthew..."" she trailed off at the end, carefully looking at Callum.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>She shrugged.<br><br>""I don't' really remember much. One moment, I was walking down the street, then some tingling in the chest... and then the next moment I'm in a gory bath of blood and guts in Pods bathroom. Barricaded the doors immediately, and called Matthew to help me.""</p><p>""Tell me, Callum, why are you doing this? Doesn't seem that you'd care about someone like Matthew..."" she trailed off at the end, carefully looking at Callum. </p>

C.K. dipped his finger in his drink and flicked some droplets at Bella. “You third eyeing me?”

He laughed. Loud.

“Or that was just an innocent question from a Shadow, yah? Anyway, I don’t see why the why of me doing this should concern you, love. So, back to my line of questioning: where and when exactly were you when you felt these butterflies in your chests, before the lights went out? And how much time had passed between then and the bathroom splatter-fest?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>C.K. dipped his finger in his drink and flicked some droplets at Bella. “You third eyeing me?”</p><p>He laughed. Loud.</p><p>“Or that was just an innocent question from a Shadow, yah? Anyway, I don’t see why the why of me doing this should concern you, love. So, back to my line of questioning: where and when <em>exactly</em> were you when you felt these butterflies in your chests, before the lights went out? And how much time had passed between then and the bathroom splatter-fest?”</p>

She turned her head slightly, discerning Callum.

""And why should I trust you with my business when you won't trust me with a bit of yours?"" she asked, raising an eyebrow.


""As I see it, it's a two-way street. You wanna get something, you got to give a bit. I might be young, but I've been fucked over one time too many, to just trust someone without seeing what makes them tick.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>She turned her head slightly, discerning Callum.</p><p>""And why should I trust you with my business when you won't trust me with a bit of yours?"" she asked, raising an eyebrow.</p><p><br>""As I see it, it's a two-way street. You wanna get something, you got to give a bit. I might be young, but I've been fucked over one time too many, to just trust someone without seeing what makes them tick."" </p>

“Don’t ...”

His fist hit the table hard. Liquor spilled over the edges of both their glasses.

“... Play the mopey teenager with me.”

C.K. reached up, ostensibly to fix his tie. But really it was more to compose himself. He stroked the stubble on his head, before continuing:

“Just answer the questions.”

Bella stood up, her presence filled the room. 

""Callum, let's play nice, or not at all."" she said as her aura clashed with Callum's and to his surprise overpowering his. 

""It's your call honey, you're either in, or I'm out"" she said stepping outside the booth ready to walk away.

“Sit your ass down, cunt,” he said, ouwardly calm. On the inside, however, he was seething with a rage he desperately hoped would drive out that deep-cutting feeling of embarrassement.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>“<strong>Sit your ass down</strong>, cunt,” he said, ouwardly calm. On the inside, however, he was seething with a rage he desperately hoped would drive out that deep-cutting feeling of embarrassement.</p>
""Fuck you, not gonna listen to a pretentious asshole,"" she said angrily, turning around and storming away throught the crowd towards the exit.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Fuck you, not gonna listen to a pretentious asshole,"" she said angrily, turning around and storming away throught the crowd towards the exit. </p>

“You know the old Dragon fears you’ve been the victim of the Striges, yeah?” C.K. calls after her, as he struggles out of his seat to catch up with Bella.

“I didn’t want to burden you with that fact, but there it is: a good reason for all of us involved to treat this like the pressing fucking matter that it is. No time for ego’s, irrelevant questions and all that. Straight to the point. ‘s All I was ever after.”
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>“You know the old Dragon fears you’ve been the victim of the Striges, yeah?” C.K. calls after her, as he struggles out of his seat to catch up with Bella.</p><p>“I didn’t want to burden you with that fact, but there it is: a good reason for all of us involved to treat this like the pressing fucking matter that it is. No time for ego’s, irrelevant questions and all that. Straight to the point. ‘s All I was ever after.”</p>

""Shit."" she just said standing there, the crowd of people walking in all directions. 

She thought for a moment then. 

""Why you then? Why not the sheriff, or my sire? You know, people who are qualified to look for them?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Shit."" she just said standing there, the crowd of people walking in all directions. </p><p>She thought for a moment then. <br><br>""Why you then? Why not the sheriff, or my sire? You know, people who are qualified to look for them?"" </p>

“Qualified is a term relative not only to a persons qualties, skills and temperament, but more importantly it’s relative to situations and the problems that arise from them,” 

C.K. shrugged, “Why take the risk of rumours being blown out of proportion and running wild when you can use good old, discreet little me. And when the danger is high, why put  the life of one of your own on the line? Or those of court officials? Or lives that rival covenants care about? My qualification, Bella, is that I am uniquely expandable.”

He smiled, defiantely, “Say we step outside? Could both use a cooling down. That and some open space to keep that feeling of being cornered at bay,” 

C.K. extended his hand and winked, “We got off on the wrong foot. And that’s my bad. I do hope I didn’t ruin my chances for a second date. I had it all planned out, see. Thought we could hit up a club and have a strobe-lighted dinner, followed by a romantic graveyard walk, holding hands under the new moon and then - who knows? Some coffin gymnastics?,” 

He raised his hands defensively, “Not that I’m presuming you’re anything less than a lady.”
dice roll

She shook her head.

""You see, I made the mistake of assuming, that the man such as yourself is above the bullshit and pretentiousness of the rest of the Ancillae and Elders. I was wrong. Tho, nice try in backtracking.""

She continued walking towards the exit, Callum barely keeping up. 

""Mister Kelly, I am quite certain that it was indeed the work of a Strix. I was looking into this myself for a bit, and it seems that... it's after Mister Johnson, so... keep yourself out of it, and the rest of us should be fine. Now... have a good night. I'd rather not have a second date too.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>She shook her head.<br><br>""You see, I made the mistake of assuming, that the man such as yourself is above the bullshit and pretentiousness of the rest of the Ancillae and Elders. I was wrong. Tho, nice try in backtracking.""</p><p>She continued walking towards the exit, Callum barely keeping up. <br><br>""Mister Kelly, I am quite certain that it was indeed the work of a Strix. I was looking into this myself for a bit, and it seems that... it's after Mister Johnson, so... keep yourself out of it, and the rest of us should be fine. Now... have a good night. I'd rather not have a second date too."" </p>

“That’s all right, love,” C.K. blew an air kiss, “Lemme know when you’ve transcended the petty pretense. Would love to know if you’ll still smell the shit up from up in your high catsle. Remember: hot air rises.”

column4:
Exter came out of burn and entered a parking orbit. An ISA  (Interstellar Space Agency) patrol ship scanned them, ran their ID and waved them on. Exeter had been keeping its nose clean for the last few years. On the bridge, calculations were made. They don’t have enough fuel for a touch down and dust off at the Ranch. Vandemberg Spaceport has added a surcharge, in addition to the already scandalous port fees that were negotiated after the war, to cover ‘clean up’ on Ares, the moon that served as an Alliance Naval Shipyard... but has since be ‘decommissioned.’

They’d have to travel by shuttle to the ranch, and then pick up some paying customers or cargo when it was time to leave. 

(Assume a skeleton crew of ‘temp workers’ on Exter. Let me know if you want to keep any of them.. if so, write them up. But between Nika, Rina and thr others,, you don’t “need”anyone else to Keep Flyin).

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-279100""><div class=""row"">

The shuttle is in good shape...in some ways better than the main ship itself, probably because it had gotten less heavy use. Which was good, because they were running crew light on this flight, meaning Ezekiel, Kiera, Chris, and Quentin were really the only available hands. With everyone else busy preparing for arrival, it was left to Ezekiel to get it ready. If the shuttle had been in worse shape, he might not have been up for the task. Mechanical work wasn't his greatest strength, to be sure.

He looked at his watch, an old fashioned mechanical piece with a leather strap. He made the effort to keep it in time with their landing spots. It was a good routine and habit to be in. The watch face read five thirty. Early morning, Boros time. Ranch hands would be up doing the normal work. Whether anyone else would be - that'd be up for grabs. Good chance Nika would be. Rina too. Gabe was unlikely - he was a teenage boy, after all. Regardless, they'd radio the ranch on the way down. Hopefully they wouldn't throw too much havoc into the routine. Assuming that whatever Rina sent the wave about hadn't disrupted that routine already.

Checking the last of the dashboard readings, Ezekiel pronounced the shuttle ready for flight. He pressed the button on the intercom, which produced a large burst of static before quieting down. Something else to add to the repair list. ""Whenever we're parked, shuttle is ready to take us down. Don't dawdle too much - that means you, Chris.""

""Whenever we're parked, shuttle is ready to take us down. Don't dawdle too much - that means you, Chris.""</p>

Knowing when they're going to be hitting orbit (at least approximately) meant that Nika had spent the past several days squaring herself away dirtside. Tasks that needed finishing before she could leave were prioritized and tasks she couldn't finish before the arrival were parceled out to some of the hands. Larry and Nala were both good about rearranging tasks as needed.

Ranch work doesn't stop just because visitors are expected, though, and today was no exception. Nika released the horses from their stalls into the paddock and pulled on her gloves to begin tossing pitchforks full of hay into the feeding troughs. The water were full, thanks to Rina's jiggering of a constant fresh-water refreshing system. When she stepped into the paddock, it was to find Nate already out there doing the feed.

""You didn't need to do that,"" she told him with a smile.

He tossed the last bit into the bin and then leaned on his pitchfork, one hand on his hip. ""I know. But I needed to do something,"" he admitted. ""Are you planning on loading up as soon as they touch down?""

""I expect that we'll need to help make arrangements for cargo or passengers before we can head out. Probably be a couple days on the ground, just to arrange that... but I don't rightly know. None of us are exactly rich enough to keep her flyin' out of our own pockets."" Nika paused and then shot him a cheeky grin. ""Well... Kiera might be. But the rest of us ain't!""

""Ain't ain't a word,"" he teased back, tossing an arm around her shoulders as they walked back toward the barn. ""Ain't that what you're always tellin' all the kids?""

Laughing, she wrapped an arm around his waist, hooking her gloved fingers into a belt loop. She leaned her head against his shoulder briefly, matching her steps to his back into the barn. ""I do tell them that all the gorram time,"" she admits. ""It ain't stopped 'em yet.""

She leaned into the kiss he pressed to the top of her head. When he released her, with a quick swat to her derriere, Nika sent him a sassy grin. ""Meet you in Dancer's stall. Nala's goin' all-out on breakfast this mornin', since they'll be gettin' here in time to eat -- she hopes."" She headed to fetch the wheelbarrow and another pitchfork so that they could work on mucking out the stalls companionably.

Kiera poked her head in the door of her son's room.  ""Chris?  C'mon kiddo, hoof it.  You heard your Dad.""

She only had her guitar case and a rucksack.  She had always traveled light, even in the days of her container travel.  The container hadn't been small, mind you, but beyond the equipment, most of her things had always fit into a rucksack. A psychologist could probably write volumes about that.  Her mother's psych alone would have charged another fortune to have a whack at the Honorable Mrs Sullivan's obviously troubled daughter.

At least he found her.  The real her.  Ornery, proud and as intolerable as ever.  Almost.  

Kiera bit her lip, remembering.  Merribeth came back home just a little bit more subdued, her slender frame starved and her eyes dark and sunken.  They wouldn't tell her about it, wouldn't say what was done, how much was paid.  JJ had slept with a gun for a year.  But spas, the family physician and makeup did wonders for her.  Nonetheless, Kiera knew that her mother and father would never be the same..  

Humbler, more patient with others now.  It made them better grandparents.  They were surely better grandparents than they had been parents, a little more free with their affections.  Still hard, both of them.  But to Chris, they were everything she could have asked of them.  

Tilting her head, she watched as he slung his guitar on his shoulder over the pack.  ""Toothbrush?"" she asked.He groaned and put everything back down again.  Her chin went up.  ""Do I need to ask about underwear?""

His blush told her yes, she did need to. ""I can borrow some,"" he informed her.

Teenage boy, teenage boy, she reminded herself and tried not to laugh.  ""I'll loan you a pair of mine then.  C'mon!  Time is wasting!""

His indignant squeal was all the reward she needed.  He grabbed the offending items and shoved them in his pocket before as he followed her down to the shuttle.

Getting everyone together and moving was actually more work than the actual shuttle ride down to planet side was. Guess I'm not as rusty as I thought.

The conversation on the ride down was full of talk of how good it would be to see everyone again. To get a chance to get on horseback again. To get fresh food rather than the fake stuff that they ate on a regular basis. Everyone, even Chris, knew they were there on serious business. But all the more reason to enjoy the moments beforehand, Ezekiel thought.

Nika had land outside the main ranch area set aside for shuttle landings. In fact, it was the same place he and Kiera had landed when Kiera had surprised Nika and Rina with Ezekiel's presence so many years ago. As the shuttle doors opened on the early morning darkness, Ezekiel leaned over to Kiera as they got ready to leave and said, ""At least this time, we let them know we were coming.""

To get a chance to get on horseback again. To get fresh food rather than the fake stuff that they ate on a regular basis. Everyone, even Chris, knew they were there on serious business. But all the more reason to enjoy the moments beforehand, Ezekiel thought.</p><p>Nika had land outside the main ranch area set aside for shuttle landings. In fact, it was the same place he and Kiera had landed when Kiera had surprised Nika and Rina with Ezekiel's presence so many years ago. As the shuttle doors opened on the early morning darkness, Ezekiel leaned over to Kiera as they got ready to leave and said, ""At least this time, we let them know we were coming.""</p>
She could only grin.  ""Maybe not the best thing.  They'll have gone overboard to welcome us.  You know them.""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>She could only grin.  ""Maybe not the best thing.  They'll have gone overboard to welcome us.  You know them.""</p>

He grinned back. ""I know. I'm looking forward to it."" And he was. He had spent so much of his life before Kiera alone that he relished these moments with the larger family that he had inherited. With his free hand, he took hers and stepped out on to land to see what that family had in store for them.

only a shallow slumber that was easily broken. After waking yet again on the
shreds of a dream, she checked her watch: 04:50. Giving up, she threw back the
covers and dressed in the predawn darkness. There was one thing she needed and
right now, it might be the last time she'd get it.

Best I do it now. I won't have later.

She
paused on her way out to check on Gabe, cracking his bedroom door and peering
through. The light she kept burning in the main room showed her
enough: he was still asleep and would be fine. Nevertheless, she wrote him a
note and left it propped on the table on her way out the door.
The air frosted with her breath as she stepped off for Joshua's grave. 15 years
of sunsets and sunrises, of greeting and releasing the day with him as much as
she could, meant that she knew the way without needing to watch her feet. The iron
gate swung silently under her hand on her arrival and she sat on his grave, her
back against the headstone, and cast her eyes toward the horizon. As was her
routine, Rina tipped her head back, stretched her legs before
her, spread her fingers on the ground beneath her, and began.

Good morning, Joshua.

***


She tended to lose track of
time when she talked to Joshua. The distinctive whine of a shuttle's engines
brought her back to the present and she knew without having to look up whose
shuttle it was. She'd heard it before.
She gave Joshua's headstone a final pat. Déjà vu was strong when she put the
graveyard at her back and went down the hill toward the LZ. Had it been 15
years since Ezekiel's first arrival to the ranch, pulling her away from his
brother where he lay? Rina shook her head. She was approaching the age where
the circles life ran to were starting to show themselves, where changes rung
only served to illustrate how some things would forever remain the same. Rina
tracked the shuttle's progress with a hand raised against the growing dawn and
steered herself to her house midway. She'd wake Gabe and join the reunion at

the main house when everyone got there.

""Gabe,"" she called
softly moments later, teasing her son's ear from his door. ""Wake up, hon. They're here

There's an order to things on the ranch. Miss Nala feeds the family. BJ feeds everyone else. Sometimes they work together to put on something a bit fancier during celebrations.

This morning, the order's been disrupted. Miss Nala's nursing a mother-in-law down with a bad case of flu and there's company landing soon. Big company, from the way Miss Rina and Miss Nika were running about like the past was about to reach out and snap their necks.

""Don't I know a thing or two about that."" BJ muttered to himself as he popped open the waffle iron and worked two more of the thick, delicious cream ale waffles. He added them to the pile, filled the iron, closed, and flipped it. That done, he moved over, checking on the sausage. These he made two days ago, using the meat of an alligator which had somehow crawled up into the pastures to threaten the livestock. It had been a good excuse to make use of the hand cranked sausage stuffer. It was grilling perfectly. He turned a few, then continued to load the omelette cart. One of the advantages of being head cook on a ranch was plenty of farm fresh eggs and he'd be damned if they weren't going to be added to this meal.

""Breakfast'll be ready in ten."" BJ says, calling out to whomever was on the other side of the kitchen door. ""If you survive my hot sauce I'll buy you a pint later!""

Stall mucking was something that could be put off, but they managed to get three of them cleared before the actual time of landing arrived. The rest, Nika left for the hands. Giving Nate a smacking kiss on the cheek on her way out of the barn, she stripped off her work gloves and headed for the mule to drive it out to the landing pad in the back pasture.

She honestly couldn't wait to see them. Over the years, she'd come to cherish the extended family they'd built among them. The shuttle streaked over her and she was just bringing the mule to a full stop when the hatch opened up. She swung her long legs out of the mule and walked with an easy smile in the early morning light part way toward the craft, waiting there with both hands tucked into her back pockets.

""Hey, y'all. Welcome home!""

Because no matter what -- this place where Joshua is buried will always be one of their homes. Even if they have others.

Welcome home!""</p><p>Because no matter what -- this place where Joshua is buried will always be one of their homes. Even if they have others.</p>

""Ok, ma,"" Gabe said as he slowly got out of bed, which was difficult, given that Mugen, his grey russian cat was curled up tight on the bed with him. ""Come on, Mugen, let's get you fed so you aren't completely underfoot this morning,"" he said. She yawned and stretched in response.

This was the day he'd been waiting for. He'd be able to go out into the stars and see the many systems he'd memorized. He be able to go out there.

He got dressed in record time and headed downstairs.

""Let's go.""

Ezekiel moved forward, letting go of Kiera's hand so they could each get their required hugs from the group. He had never been much of a hugger before meeting Kiera - not really a learned childhood behavior in the Drake family. But he had gotten used to it.

Thankfully today was a good day. He wasn't really using his cane other than as a safety net. He would need both hands for the greetings, so he set the cane down to be picked up later.

""Nika. As always, good to see you."" He hugged Nika, a solid but not excessive hug that suited her as much as it did their relationship. 

""And Rina, I hope you are treating yourself well."" A Rina hug was a more intense affair. He had found Rina did not do anything halfway and hugs were no exception to that rule.

Then he got to stand in front of his nephew who had sprouted what felt like a foot since the last time Ezekiel had seen him. Standing firmly on the border between childhood and manhood, Gabe was quickly growing into the adult he would soon become. Ezekiel remembered being a 14 (or is it 15? had it been that long?) year old boy and feeling uncomfortable with all the routines of the past and with things like giving relatives hugs. The Lord knew that he could see it in Chris. 

So instead of giving a hug, Ezekiel extended forth his right hand. ""Gabriel, you are looking well."" Normally, he was Gabe to Ezekiel (and probably would be again), but something about seeing him again, older (and hopefully wiser) made Ezekiel lean towards using Gabriel.

Abruptly, striding forward, she gathered NIka in her arms.  ""I've missed you lady.""

""As best as I can,"" Rina said, answering Ezekiel's question. As always, long absences between visits only emphasized the echoes of Joshua in Ezekiel: indefinable similarities in body language and voice, a serendipitous note in a laugh, chance angles of light bringing a shared feature into sharp relief ... all of it fleeting, gone between one breath and the next. 

And as always, Rina couldn't prevent the needling of her heart upon seeing him. All she could do was hug Ezekiel hard to reinforce the fact it wasn't Joshua she held. Repetition over the years made it easier to bear and this time when she stepped back, her eyes held no trace of tears. 

Instead, she merely smiled and stepped aside to let Gabe take her place.

""Fuhn Pi,"" Nika retorted, informing her friend that she's talking out her arse. And then she wraps her arms tight around Kiera and laughs. ""Don't take so long between visits, then, is the answer, don'tcha reckon?"" She doesn't let go for a long time. The Wave has shaken her, but Kiera and Ezekiel being here means that they are once more standing strong. Nothing in the Verse dared stand in the way when you put Rina, Kiera, and Nika together -- at least in //her// lowly opinion.

""Ezekiel, you been keeping my heart-sister and my nephew away too much,"" she scolds lightly, clearly teasing. Taking her cue from Rina on how to handle the hugging thing, she grins at Chris. ""Holy Hell, boy, you been hanging upside down by your toes to get that tall?""

Once the greetings were all managed, Nika waved everyone to the mule. ""C'mon, then -- you people know the drill. There's food awaitin' -- I'm quite sure if we don't get there soon, Gabe and Chris'll fall over dead of starvation. You clearly don't feed them kids enough,"" she quips. ""Mount up!"" Not that there's anything to mount, really -- it's a mule!
