column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-279401""><div class=""row"">

Emily, Hannah, Elijah, and Stavros got home from worship at the Landis family home. Hermes Landis was not an actual ordained minister, but he was the closet thing Abundance had. Sadly Emily knew more of the Bible and had a better grasp of the inner meaning of most passages. Tonight Landis was trying to make a point about the parting of the Red Sea and how it was close to living in Abundance.

Emily and Elijah were in the kitchen, Hannah and Stavros in the home parlor, when Corinne arrived. It was quite late/dark by this time and past the children's normal bedtime.

Before Emily finished with Corinne, Calamity and Dune arrived. They were assisting a pant-less Harris (owner of the mining company). Harris had on shirt, vest and boots only.

Questions:

Corinne: why are you visiting Emily at this late hour?

Emily: why is Stavros here so late?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>Emily</strong>, <strong>Hannah</strong>, <strong>Elijah</strong>, and <strong>Stavros </strong>got home from worship at the Landis<strong> </strong>family home. <strong>Hermes Landis</strong> was not an actual ordained minister, but he was the closet thing Abundance had. Sadly Emily knew more of the Bible and had a better grasp of the inner meaning of most passages. Tonight Landis was trying to make a point about the parting of the Red Sea and how it was close to living in Abundance.</p><p>Emily and Elijah were in the kitchen, Hannah and Stavros in the home parlor, when <strong>Corinne </strong>arrived. It was quite late/dark by this time and past the children's normal bedtime.</p><p>Before Emily finished with Corinne, <strong>Calamity </strong>and <strong>Dune </strong>arrived. They were assisting a pant-less <strong>Harris </strong>(owner of the mining company). Harris had on shirt, vest and boots only.</p><hr><p>Questions:</p><p>Corinne: why are you visiting Emily at this late hour?</p><p>Emily: why is Stavros here so late?</p>

Corinne is visiting Emily for two reasons, both of them business. The first is that after their tense encounter with a rancher and the mystery of his poisoned cows, she wants to keep certain information out of the town's ears. So Emily's discretion would be appreciated. 

The second is a more broadly social reason, since Corinne is looking to make inroads with Abundance's more indispensable inhabitants. Emily's the doctor. She's important, in Corinne's eyes. That translates to influence, and if a genuine friendship lurks under the convenience, all the better!

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Corinne is visiting Emily for two reasons, both of them business. The first is that after their tense encounter with a rancher and the mystery of his poisoned cows, she wants to keep certain information out of the town's ears. So Emily's discretion would be appreciated. </p><p>The second is a more broadly social reason, since Corinne is looking to make inroads with Abundance's more <em>indispensable </em>inhabitants. Emily's the doctor. She's important, in Corinne's eyes. That translates to influence, and if a genuine friendship lurks under the convenience, all the better!</p>

Emily sits at the kitchen table, still in the dress she wore to church sipping tea next to Corinne.

Elijah is at the counter washing dishes from their supper grumbling about how Hannah got out of doing the dishes.

Emily concludes a point she had been trying to make about the recent meeting at the Landis home.  "" ... So, I ask you, how can Mr. Landis possibly equate the parting of the Red Sea and the trials of the Jewish people to the new construction of a bridge for Abundance?""

Without missing a beat, she turns slightly in Elijah's direction.

""Because, Elijah dear, your sister said that Stavros needed to speak with her.""  Something in Emily's voice was a little tense.  It WAS late, after all, and Stavros never stayed over this late.  While he might be a bit on the informal side, he had always been proper enough when it came to Emily and their home.

""Who knows what they're doing in there,"" Elijah grumbles.

""I have excellent ears, dear,"" Emily assures Elijah as she turns to Corinne.  Smiling, she reaches for the teapot.  ""More tea?""

As she reaches for the teapot, her mind does wander to what IS going on with the boy.  Something is not quite right.  He had been fidgeting all evening at the worship service, which was unlike him.  The boy accompanied them to the service ever since he and Hannah had made googly-eyes at each other, but his parents had never joined them.  She knew that things at home were strained between Stavros and his parents, but she never pried into the details.

He shall tell me when and if he is so inclined, she had always concluded.  But, tonight she was concerned.  But, darn if the children weren't keeping their voices down in the parlor!

""We still have some biscuits and preserves if you want a bite with the tea,"" she offers to Corinne.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><img src=""https://www.assignmentx.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/12/HellOnWheels-S1-Dominique-McElligott2.jpg"" alt="""" style=""float: left; width: 119px; margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px;""></p><p>Emily sits at the kitchen table, still in the dress she wore to church sipping tea next to Corinne.</p><p>Elijah is at the counter washing dishes from their supper grumbling about how Hannah got out of doing the dishes.</p><p>Emily concludes a point she had been trying to make about the recent meeting at the Landis home. <span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);""> </span><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">"" ... So, I ask you, how can Mr. Landis possibly equate the parting of the Red Sea and the trials of the Jewish people to the new construction of a bridge for Abundance?""</span></strong></p><p>Without missing a beat, she turns slightly in Elijah's direction.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""Because, Elijah dear, your sister said that Stavros needed to speak with her.""</span></strong>  Something in Emily's voice was a little tense.  It WAS late, after all, and Stavros never stayed over this late.  While he might be a bit on the informal side, he had always been proper enough when it came to Emily and their home.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(89, 89, 89);"">""Who knows what they're doing in there,""</span></strong> Elijah grumbles.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""I have excellent ears, dear,""</span></strong> Emily assures Elijah as she turns to Corinne.  Smiling, she reaches for the teapot.  <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""More tea?""</span></strong></p><p>As she reaches for the teapot, her mind does wander to what IS going on with the boy.  Something is not quite right.  He had been fidgeting all evening at the worship service, which was unlike him.  The boy accompanied them to the service ever since he and Hannah had made googly-eyes at each other, but his parents had never joined them.  She knew that things at home were strained between Stavros and his parents, but she never pried into the details.</p><p><em><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">He shall tell me when and if he is so inclined</span>,</em> she had always concluded.  But, tonight she was concerned.  But, darn if the children weren't keeping their voices down in the parlor!</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""We still have some biscuits and preserves if you want a bite with the tea,""</span></strong> she offers to Corinne.</p>

Dune pushes the door open as they essentially carry Harris across the threshold, she is still speaking excitedly to Calamity telling her what happened after she left Harris being too out of it to know what she is saying.

""... as though I had entranced him with my 'womanly wiles' and I did not even know I had any."" She says, much louder than is appropriate this time of night. ""I thought I might have to cut him off me...""

Realising where they are she drops her voice. ""Shhh."" She says, with a small giggle.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Dune pushes the door open as they essentially carry Harris across the threshold, she is still speaking excitedly to <strong>Calamity</strong> telling her what happened after she left Harris being too out of it to know what she is saying.</p><p><strong>""... as though I had entranced him with my 'womanly wiles' and I did not even know I had any."" </strong>She says, much louder than is appropriate this time of night. <strong>""I thought I might have to cut him off me...""</strong></p><p><strong></strong>Realising where they are she drops her voice. <strong>""Shhh.""</strong> She says, with a small giggle.</p>

Calamity wheezes with laughter at Dune's description. The image of her pragmatic and usually serious friend leading the poor barkeep along is too much to bear. At Dune's shushing, Calamity catches herself. For the first time, she notices the dining room is rather full. She steps in front of Harris in a limp attempt to shield him from view.

""Err... hello Emily, Elijah. Corinne, is it?"" Calamity manages an awkward smile, ""Apologies for bothering you all at this hour, but it's a bit of an emergency.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Calamity wheezes with laughter at Dune's description. The image of her pragmatic and usually serious friend leading the poor barkeep along is too much to bear. At Dune's shushing, Calamity catches herself. For the first time, she notices the dining room is rather full. She steps in front of Harris in a limp attempt to shield him from view.</p><p><strong>""Err... hello Emily, Elijah. Corinne, is it?"" </strong>Calamity manages an awkward smile, <strong>""Apologies for bothering you all at this hour, but it's a bit of an emergency.""</strong></p>

Emily looks up, startled by the commotion at the door.

""Excuse me,"" she says to Corinne and sets down her teacup.

Emily steps from the kitchen through the dining room to the front door where she gawks at the sight before her - of the two women and the half naked man.

She looks at Dune and her dress.  ""Is that ... one of my ...""  Emily shakes her head, dismissing the question (for the moment) and then motions for the parlor.

""What's wrong with him?"" she asks as she moves ahead of them.

Stavros and Hannah both sit upright on the treatment table where they had apparently been sitting, or leaning upon ... rather closely it would seem.

Emily offers Hannah a brief and disapproving glare before waving her hand.  ""Move, children.""  Looking at Hannah, she adds, ""I might need you, dear.""  

Then, to Stavros, ""Be so kind as to wait in the kitchen.  And, be a dear and assist Elijah with the dishes, would you?""

Both of them leap off the table and Stavros nods replying with an almost unintelligible, ""Yes ma'am,"" as he retreats to the kitchen.

Hannah moves to Emily's desk awaiting further instructions.

Emily motions for the table.  ""Lay him here."" 

She hears a light gasp behind her where Hannah stands. ""Yes, dear.  He's naked.  Get over it,"" Emily informs her stepdaughter sternly.

""Hmm,"" Corinne muses, standing up as the commotion breaks out. ""Evenin' to the three of ya,"" she says, managing a bit of politeness in these unusual circumstances. She gives both of the newcomer women a rapid, appraising glance, but her eyes linger on the man.

""Councilman, ain't he?"" She asks with a gesture. She's pretty sure she knows the answer already. ""Don't imagine he was with one of mine.""

The Red Sun didn't require her constant attention, of course, but if there had been someone like him in a compromising position in her establishment, she would've been notified. And since this came as a surprise, well, must've been somewhere else.

He isn't much to look at right now. Letting the doctor do her doctor things, she instead half-whispers to Calamity, ""girl disagree with 'im?""

""Poison?  Do you know what kind?  How was it ingested?  What kind of food or drink?""

""Glass and tongue depressor,"" she says, already examining the man's lips, nose, and eyes.  

Hannah passes the items to Emily who continues to examine the man.

As Emily is examining him, Harris's breathing becomes ragged and shallow, and his eyes roll back and a light, white coating of foam trickles from the right corner of the man's mouth.

She feels his forehead and purses her lips.

""Dammit!  Monkshood!  How the ...?""  Emily leaves the question unfinished and turns to Hannah.

""A teaspoon of mustard with warm water in a teacup!"" she barks to her stepdaughter. She does not turn to see that her order has been adhered to, as she knows the teenager and the seriousness she brings to their tasks.

""Help me hold him,"" she says to the assembled women, but not to any one in particular, and she props the man up in a seated position.

""Hannah!  Please hurry!"" she calls out after the girl.

""Monkshood's not in season right now,"" Corinne observes, no stranger to plant-based poison. She knew it more readily as wolfsbane, but the fell flower found its bloom only during the summer months. ""If you're sure, then it's likely the culprit has good preserves. Or a green thumb.""

There's a bit of inference in that statement, but she's pretty close to sure. Refining wolfsbane was a simple enough task, true, but it took a fair amount to kill a man. Then again, Harris is still alive. And wolfsbane has one Hell of a reputation.

Mustard? Really? Corinne tries to hide her incredulity as she holds Harris steady for the good doctor. ""See, me, I'd've fed 'im some crushed coal lumps and left it at that. Truth be told the dose probably weren't enough to kill, elsewise he'd already be turning blue.""

I don't have time to explain myself to this woman! Emily's thoughts bark out in her mind.  Still ... 

She looks to Corinne.  ""Least intrusive and harmful actions, first.  Then, if that fails to gain the desired results, we'll move on to charcoal.""

""You're the doc,"" she answers. No sense stepping on toes right now, particularly with Emily's vital importance to the town. And if they all ended up witness to her life-saving skills, all the better right? Since they'd all been helping.

Yeah. The only way this story went South was if he didn't pull through. ""Don't die on us, Councilman, y'hear?"" Corinne insists, one steady hand at his back.

""Can't let a whiskey be the end of ya.""

Uncomfortable with the social tension in the room, Dune quietly slips out and moves to the front door. She peeps through and then steps out into the night to check up and down the street for threats; poisoning --or even drugging-- probably means someone had plans, meddling with plans makes people upset.

Dune had paid close attention --old habits from years of hunting-- and was pretty sure no one was following Calamity... but, after she caught up to the staggering pair, she may have been a little distracted while relaying the events with Arbit. Still, she is pretty sure they were not followed and does not see anyone lurking or approaching.

She retreats to the front porch, from there she can hear what is going on through the window and watch the street... and escape the tension of women fighting. Why is that Corinne woman here? She wonders with a bit of resentment. What is she playing at, questioning the doc? Does she want to take over here too?

Dune had not released until a second ago, but she misses Smoky, and blames Corinne for him leaving. She knows this is irrational, but he turned out to be a surprisingly good friend, and she does not have many of those.

Unseen behind Corinne and Emily, Calamity bites her thumb in a rare display of nerves. Fucking monkshood, Anna? Fan-fucking-tastic... Why did I have to stick my head in her business?

She searches for a distraction, any distraction. The young man, Stavros, has wandered out of the kitchen into the dining room. He ignores the commotion, and instead fixates on Hannah. He wears an expression somewhere between confusion and worry, and is still absently wiping a long-dry frying pan with a dishcloth. 

Calamity walks over to stand next to him, though he takes no notice of her.

""A little past your bedtime, isn't it?"" she teases.

When Dune sees Visage approaching she looks looks both ways up and down the road again before stepping into a patch of light, so she can be seen, and then casually back into the shadows near the building. Visage does not like being seen, and Dune knows she will be more comfortable in the dark.

Visage is old and wrinkled, but has keen eyes that see everything, she does not speak much --and when she does it is with a thick accent that Dune can not place-- but Dune has learned to listen when she does.

""You'm said to come tell'm you about anyone suspicious."" Visage says by way of greeting. ""A woman showed up a while ago, trying to look casual, but something is up, ya?: She'm's a bit desperate to remain unseen. She's'm squatting near the east side of the Alley, but like to move.""

With that, Visage turns and shuffles off into the night. Dune knows she did not waste words saying that only she noticed the stress in the woman, or that no one else was paying attention, if there was other interest, she would have mentioned it.

With Harris out of the woods and resting comfortably, and snoring, Emily suggests that the ladies retire to the kitchen for some tea.

She sets Elijah and Stavro to collecting wood from outside and then they can assist Hannah in cleaning up the parlor.

Leaning against the far counter in the kitchen, teacup in hand, Emily eyes Dune up and down.

""So ... care to tell me about the dress?""  Then her eyes scan to Calamity.  ""And, how you managed to come upon a half naked and inebriated poisoned man?""

She takes a sip of her tea.  ""There simply must be an entertaining tale in there somewhere.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>With Harris out of the woods and resting comfortably, and snoring, Emily suggests that the ladies retire to the kitchen for some tea.</p><p>She sets Elijah and Stavro to collecting wood from outside and then they can assist Hannah in cleaning up the parlor.</p><p>Leaning against the far counter in the kitchen, teacup in hand, Emily eyes Dune up and down.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""So ... care to tell me about the dress?""</span></strong>  Then her eyes scan to Calamity.  <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""And, how you managed to come upon a half naked and inebriated poisoned man?""</span></strong></p><p>She takes a sip of her tea. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);""> ""There simply must be an entertaining tale in there somewhere.""</span></strong></p>

Worried that she may have overstepped, Dune immediately makes to take the dress off, ignoring the fact the the menfolk will be with wood in a minute. Fortunately the stitching makes this hard.

""I'm sorry,"" Dune says distraught, showing Emily the lightly tacked waistline. ""The adjustments were not permanent. And we could not have gotten into the hotel unnoticed 'in my usual getup'."" She says, obviously quoting someone. ""You said you would to loan me a dress if I needed one."" She adds apologetically.

Dune feels a sense of dread pass over her, what if she misread the situation or the offer, has she been imagining the implications of 'family' she has been enjoying so much? For the first time she realises that she does not --really does not-- want leave town. She has never had a place she felt she belonged, that is all down to the Parkers, everything else in town is horrible.

She looks up, her eyes pleading, ""I will make sure it is clean, and then..."" She trails off, not wanting to suggest leaving, hoping Emily does not assume that and agree.

Emily looks towards Dune, her expression soft - even endearing.

""Dear, don't worry.  What I have, you are free to borrow.  Though, it might be nice to know ahead of time.""  She smiles at the young woman.

She steps a little closer to examine the stitching.  ""Quick work,"" she says, running a finger over the tacking.  ""And easily undone if need be.  Or,"" she says, looking to Dune with a smile.  ""Easily made more permanent if it is to fit you properly.""

She leans against the counter next to Dune and takes a sip of tea.  ""I hear that there is to be some sort of social gathering here soon, and you will need something appropriate to wear, after all.  I was not in much of a mood to attend, but, Hannah has insisted.""  She looks to Dune.  ""So, I could use some support.

""Hannah will most certainly be huddled with her new friends and with Stavros, and Elijah ..."" she frowns for a moment.  ""Will hopefully behave himself.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Emily looks towards Dune, her expression soft - even endearing.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""Dear, don't worry.  What I have, you are free to borrow.  Though, it might be nice to know ahead of time."" </span></strong> She smiles at the young woman.</p><p>She steps a little closer to examine the stitching.  <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""Quick work,"" she says, running a finger over the tacking.  ""And easily undone if need be.  Or,""</span></strong> she says, looking to Dune with a smile.  <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""Easily made more permanent if it is to fit you properly.""</span></strong></p><p>She leans against the counter next to Dune and takes a sip of tea. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);""> ""I hear that there is to be some sort of social gathering here soon, and you will need something appropriate to wear, after all.  I was not in much of a mood to attend, but, Hannah has insisted."" </span></strong> She looks to Dune.  <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""So, I could use some support.</span></strong></p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""Hannah will most certainly be huddled with her new friends and with Stavros, and Elijah ...""</span></strong> she frowns for a moment. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);""> ""Will hopefully behave himself.""</span></strong></p>

""Like: a Party?"" Dune says, slightly panicked. She was about to say that she did not see any reason to need a permanent dress when Emily's well timed guilt-trip hits her where it hurts. How can she say no to the request for support right on the heels forgiveness and a generous offer.

""Um, I don't really like crowds, and public scrutiny..."" she says, but then looking over Hannah, cleaning up in the parlor, she adds: ""But if it is important to Hannah... Then, um, what do I need to do? What happens at one of these things?"" Dune is remembering the situation with Arbit, and it is looking much less funny now that the excitement of the heist has worn off.

Smiling at Dune's near state of panic, and the realization that there may be some who truly do not know how to act or react in such social situations, Emily sidles closer to the girl to lay a reassuring arm over her shoulders, tugging her in close.

""There is no need to fear.  We have ample time to discuss the proprieties.  Mostly, you stroll about looking pretty, engage in charming chatter with those who might strike your fancy, eat and drink a bit, and dance should you be asked and choose to do so.""

She pats Dune's shoulder.  ""Hannah and I can prepare you.""  She smiles, adding an amused tilt of her head.  ""And we shall need someone to help with our hair.""

Emily pulls the younger woman into her shoulder.  ""It shall be fun.  We shall make it so!""

She glances about at Calamity and Corinne.  ""We shall each be there, am I right?  We shall make certain you have a good time,"" Emily adds with assurance.

Corinne has been listening thus far, full aware that the other three women already know each other. She gives Emily a nod at the question, intending to be present for any and all social gatherings Abundance plays host to. At Calamity's question, she rubs the edge of her saucer absentmindedly.

""I've had a share of things take my attentions away from it, truth be told. Harris over here,"" she gestures in the sleeping man's direction, ""is the first Councilor to have an ear anywhere near my words. If you catch my drift."" I will be there as a social matter, of course.""

With a faint chuckle, she adds, ""but if you're looking for somethin' more than a clumsy highball, you come to me.""

""And I assure you, wolfsbane ain't my cup of tea."" She punctuates that claim with a sip of actual tea. ""If he's itchin' for a stiff drink that won't turn him stiff, though, I could oblige.""

She bends down and picks up the engraved bullet. Where did you come from? Dune asks. I am sure I put you back where I found you.... Yes, I definitely did!

""Ranchers been complaining to the mayor about the dirty water. To hell with them! They don't like the water, go somewhere else!

""I fired Flicker last week. He threatened to kill me, so's I had him beat and dumped outside a town.""

Dune had met Flicker, he was an angry young man to whom she had been trying to teach the opposite virtue of not resorting to violence, standing up for oneself did not always mean taking action, and it is more about the self than the other.

Hearing Harris speak, Dune is not so sure Flicker was wrong --well, 'threatening' is always wrong, that gives the other the opportunity to act first-- and maybe Harris could benefit from a little killing?

What sort of friends does Calamity have anyway? She worries, especially since she counts herself one of them.

He smiles and burps.

Emily rolls her eyes.

""That was tremendously illuminating,"" she says, drolly.

""Is there someone who we might contact about getting you some clothing?  You were brought in last night minus your pants,"" she says, nodding to the blanket now covering the man;s nether regions.  ""I would hate to send you back home later in a state of undress.  There might be children on the street.""

""I'll make some arrangements for some clothes for him, Emily. I know his place pretty well,"" Calamity says with a wink.

How could any of those people be involved with an LTS spy? Has Anna gone rogue too? I can't tell if that would be better or worse.

""So, Harris. You're nice and comfy now, yes? I saved you once already, and I want to find your killer and make sure you're safe. But this badge hasn't been proving too useful. Spikes and I have been pushed to the side, I'm not even getting paid -- can you imagine? It makes it hard to find a poisoner when a girl has are her own wits. But, if someone were to go to the council on our behalf, get us nice and official, set back up in the sheriff's office... that would make things a lot easier. I wouldn't need to go around breaking into Virgil's hotel, I could just show him my badge and he'd know the score. I'd like that, wouldn't you?""

Calamity gave Harris a sickly sweet smile. She wasn't naive enough to expect gratitude, but a deal was something the businessman should understand.

""Cause if foul play's the worry, why would he be in Abundance's finest drinking establishment?""

""Lookie here, girl: Spikes is all official already, but she ain't doing her job. I prefer her to the thugs the mayor got, but what you want me to do about it? I just waltz in the council meeting and say what exactly? If I get a voice to say anything, I'll back ya.

""Here's what you do: kick those assholes out of the sheriff's office. Longer they sit in there, the longer they look legit. Then you wave the badge in Virgil's face when you want and mean it. Or do him a favor like you done me.""

The gun-hand is dressed a little better than average, cleaner than average. He probably has a good job somewhere.

""Well, I want to know. And Mr. Clay at the Grand Hotel wants to know. If Harris is here, because he ain't at home then he ain't dead.""

I can start throwing my weight around all I want -- the way I see it, I'm still not official unless I'm getting paid. And my savings are only going to stretch so long before I need to go finding other work.""

Calamity beams confidently, ""I know you'll find a way. In the meantime, try to keep a low profile. Better if folks don't know you're here, just in case.""

Emily nods to Calamity.  ""Yes, thank you.""

As Calamity disappears to the kitchen, she looks at Harris with a serious expression.  ""Seems to me that you owe the woman.  Hopefully you'll be able to help her out.  And Sheriff Spikes could use someone reliable to assist her.  Not like the help the Sheriff had before, and those two thugs camping out in the office now.""

She shrugs.  ""But, you seem to be much better now.  Your stomach should feel a bit queasy for a while ... though, I presume your stomach is used to being unsettled.  So, all I can suggest is try adding some real food between bottles.""

He looks like he remembers something.

Corinne smirks at the man, now that he's finally made himself plain. ""If Mr. Clay is worried about competition, you best tell him my guest records are confidential. I ain't in the habit of sharing who's up for accommodations in my place of business.""

She looks at his hands, making sure he's not about to do anything catastrophically stupid. ""But shouldn't it be enough that he ain't at home and he ain't dead? Reckon that'd fit most men in town."" She reaches slowly, deliberately, for a bottle on the counter. ""Now, what'll you have?""

So Clay has a hand to play with regards to Harris. Maybe Calamity outta know.

The question was how to approach the authoritative woman. Corinne doesn't exactly have the most flexible schedule, at least not so many evenings in a row. But it made little sense to wait until a shindig to let her know. ""Avo,"" she calls out, getting the clever young man's attention. ""I need a message run. Discreet-like. Wait ten minutes then head out the back. You're lookin' for a certain Calamity."" She scrawls out a quick note, folds it, and tucks it into Avo's breast pocket.

Corinne isn't actually clear on where the woman stands, hierarchically, in the town's law presence. But in a pinch, she'll have to do.

Be aware.

The children, her home, Dune ...

She shakes her head, reluctantly.  ""No.  It'll be best to keep an eye on him here.  There's a lot of us here, so it's not too likely that anyone would come for him too aggressively,"" she states with more hopefulness than conviction.

""I'll just go get my gun, all the same.""

Emily, her hands gripping her forearms tightly about her folded arms, glowers at the man.

""Elijah had a wonderful role-model in his late father - a man who was intelligent, industrious, and certainly not a drunkard!"" she half snarls at Harris.  ""I'll thank you not to speak of my children!""

Her expression turns to something a little more conspiring.  ""That being said, we shall do all we can to see that you are safe while you are in my care.  And, for that, I do expect recompense.""

Emily nods towards Dune and offers the girl a pleased smile.

Calamity disappears for some time, visiting Harris' mansion. She's able to sneak in easily using a hidden key Harris carelessly revealed in a drunken fugue. She retrieves some clothes for him and returns them to Emily's house.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Calamity disappears for some time, visiting Harris' mansion. She's able to sneak in easily using a hidden key Harris carelessly revealed in a drunken fugue. She retrieves some clothes for him and returns them to Emily's house.</p>

Calamity spends the week leading up to the party trying to do her job as deputy, but more importantly, being seen doing her job as deputy. She's friendly with Abundance's citizens, building on existing rapport where she can, and working on new connections when necessary. The tough no-nonsense act being Spikes' thing, Calamity instead tries to make everyone feel like she's a friend who can be trusted. Anyone who may be a potential enemy to her ambitions are carefully noted.

Part of this involves spending time at the sheriff's office, and getting to know the other deputies. She's careful to make sure they don't feel threatened by her, but tests the waters to see how easily she can manipulate them.

She shows as many people as she can the photo she got from A.T.'s room, searching for any kind of additional lead.

She stays in close contact with Harris, and does her best to make sure he doesn't put himself in danger. 

Calamity exercises a healthy degree of paranoia in keeping an eye open for Annabelle, but doesn't encounter her. The question of just how much her old -- well, Calamity isn't quite sure how to label their relationship, but call it friendship as a lie of omission -- The question of just how much her old friend knew about Calamity's presence in Abundance haunts her. If she doesn't know, how are they avoiding each other? If she does know, what is she planning? Or has Anna simply moved on to another town? All Calamity can do is wait.

Brock Gunnerson (runs the General Store) thinks that Erns Armaghast is in the photograph.

The clerk at the town hall says A.T. showed him that photograph, pointed at Erns Armaghast and asked if that man still lived outside town. The clerk showed A.T. where Armaghast's land was on a map. Then A.T. told the clerk that Erns Armaghast was his cousin.

Photograph: small, blurry, faded. Three men with rifles in it, posing behind a dead buffalo. One of the men could be Erns Armaghast, or a younger, blurry version of him.

column2: Dune returned home from her meeting with Anna and spoke quietly with Emily and Calamity out of earshot of Harris or the kids.

""You remember Longlost Liu?"" She asked Emily. ""The man who tried to take Delightful Wu?

""Well, someone in the alley says he has been 'watching us at night'; after some sort of revenge."" Dune did not seem overly concerned about this. ""It has been a long time,"" Dune's life had been busy recently, so it maybe felt like a longer time than it really was, ""and it is a pity that he is still nursing a grudge, but the fact that he has not acted as of yet... Well, I just thought you should know, just in case.""

column1:
Emily nods, adding her own scowl.  ""Oh, yes.  I recall.  But ... why would he ...?""

She shakes her head.  ""All right.  Just one more person to watch out for.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Emily nods, adding her own scowl. <strong> <span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);"">""Oh, yes.  I recall.  But ... why would he ...?""</span></strong></p><p>She shakes her head. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(31, 73, 125);""> ""All right.  Just one more person to watch out for.""</span></strong></p>

Most of the citizenry of Abundance views Calamity's friendly nature skeptically, wondering what she really wants. It's a hard town where people look after themselves first.

The deputies are just hired guns. They don't care about the town and just do what the mayor tells them to do. They get food, jingle and a place to sleep. They're waiting for Spring and have plans to head south and raid some Indian camps with some other guns.

Harris lasts a couple days with the Parkers and returns home. There is a commotion at the mine as some dynamite was stolen from a locked room at the site. Rankur is blamed.

Annabelle isn't seen but Calamity catches a minty smell upon the air one night. Calamity recalls Annebelle's love for the Hummingbird mint flower.

Calamity spends the week leading up to the party trying to do her job as deputy, but more importantly, being seen doing her job as deputy. She's friendly with Abundance's citizens, building on existing rapport where she can, and working on new connections when necessary. The tough no-nonsense act being Spikes' thing, Calamity instead tries to make everyone feel like she's a friend who can be trusted. Anyone who may be a potential enemy to her ambitions are carefully noted.

Hummingbird mint (Agastache cana): very minty scent. Its red tubular flowers are hummingbird magnets. This plant does best in the mid to high deserts.

column4:
The North stage is a platform raised about 6' off the ground raised atop a series of disparate scaffolding and risers held together by cross bars, lumber, screws, bolts, and cabling.  The stage is about 50' across and 30' deep, has a series of dark tarps hung behind it tied down by twine and rope.  Cross beams hang over the front of the stage with a dozen or so large lights set in silver metal half-spheres aiming towards the stage, though the lights do not appear to be emitting anything just now.  Cables and lines run from the lights to the sides supporting the cross beams along both sides of the stage and towards the rear.

Standing on either side of the stage are some large black boxes with a fabric sort of covering in front of them.  There are two large boxes on either side (about as tall as a man), with smaller boxes stacked atop of them.  Wires run from these to the sides of the stage and then back out of view just as with the lights.

It is afternoon and a 5 piece band of young adults (2 girls, 3 men) has just concluded playing on the stage and departed.  They were announced as Three Plus Two ... or, at least, the loud fellow in the red suit had said that was the name of the group.  The lead singer is a gregarious woman who seems to have captivated many in the crowd with her pleasing combination of pleasant bluesy lyrics with a jazzy lilt.  The music is not acoustic.  That is, the sound is coming from the cabled boxes to either side of the stage.  Liquid fuel powered generators chug in the background, and the sound of the music and the voices are propelled loudly from the speakers which hiss and pop with the sound.  (Note that electronic devices are the exception, rather than the rule, as the knowledge of how to power and run electronics is a skill that has largely fallen from the realm of common knowledge.)

On the street before the stage there must be more than two hundred people.  They are seated on makeshift chairs and stools, blankets and sheets, and standing.  The crowd nods, bobs, and moves to the sound of the music in the warm spring sun. 

Vendors carrying boxes of wares stroll among the gathered waiting spectators hawking food items, hats, clothing, jewelry, spinners made of metal and light wood, and many other trinkets of amusement.  Barter or jingle is good for most items.

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-279454""><div class=""row"">

Coda finds herself out on the street in the warm sun. Nero has not given her the night off, so she WILL be expected to dance tonight at Smotherland, but such is the nature of her work. And today is not entirely a free day, either.  Nero has asked that she do something for him ... ""A favor,"" he had said.  It's what he always says.

The energy on the street is palpable.  There is both joy and a sense of peace leisure, as well as a sense of trepidation present on the streets.  Still, it's a celebration unlike any in Bell Town - or anywhere else in Seattle, for that matter.

@Coda - Incorporate the answers to these into any reply, if you would.


Who is Coda with?

Where is she?

What is this ""favor"" Nero has asked of Coda?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Coda finds herself out on the street in the warm sun. Nero has not given her the night off, so she WILL be expected to dance tonight at <i style=""font-weight: bold;"">Smotherland</i>, but such is the nature of her work. And today is not entirely a free day, either.  Nero has asked that she do something for him ... ""A favor,"" he had said.  It's what he always says.</p><p>The energy on the street is palpable.  There is both joy and a sense of peace leisure, as well as a sense of trepidation present on the streets.  Still, it's a celebration unlike any in Bell Town - or anywhere else in Seattle, for that matter.</p><hr><p><strong>@Coda - Incorporate the answers to these into any reply, if you would.</strong></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><strong><br></strong></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>Who is Coda with?</em></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>Where is she?</em></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>What is this ""favor"" Nero has asked of Coda?</em></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em><br></em></p>
pensively on her nether lip, Coda scurries her way through the crowd, wondering
how they manage to move, to breathe, to think, while surrounded by such an
agitation. When she’s on stage, she can manage that: she even appreciates it,
the waves of a hundred pulses dispersed into the air and ground, rhythmed. But without
the distance, and the unreal feeling of power that accompanies her performances…
well, she feels just what she is: one frail, clumsy stranger, lost in a crowd full

of people, with no clue of what she is, that barely notice she’s there at all.

She’s
alone, for now. She prefers that, when she’s running Nero’s errands: having Ba,
Rotschild and the whole wolfpack around her to a casual meeting was as
ridiculous as bringing a flamethrower to do groceries. Too unsubtle. Too

lethal. Not a good idea.

The job in itself
is pretty straightforward: she must simply carry a small black package to a
given stall, near the North Stage. <em>Can’t miss
it, he said, they sell jewels
and all that fancy shit. Go there, and ask for Holloway. Tall gal, gray eyes, lacks
two fingers. She'll let you inside her place, if you say who sends you. Give her the box, tell her that she needs to come tonight, listen
well if she has somethin’ to say, and get the hell out of here. He
averted his eyes for a moment, exhaling a long trail of smoke (she didn’t where
he managed to find cigarettes: those were so expensive these days). <em>I don’t care what you do afterwards, but you

better get your ass back here before nine. We need to impress them tonight. And with that, he dismissed her.

She looked
inside the package before leaving, of course (he didn’t forbid her to do so, after
all). Inside, she found two things: a dozen of little glass phials, each full
of a translucent, thick-looking blue liquid, and a small envelope, sealed shut
with black tape. She hadn’t opened either
– couldn’t bring herself to. She knows Nero wouldn’t like it, and even though
his sway over her has been steadily decreasing over the course of the last days,

she still feels her stomach churn at the mere idea of disappointing him.

It could be
just a drug thing. That wouldn’t be suprising: from what she gathered (mostly
from Rotschild, a fervent consumer), the abandoned building where Nero
drug hub way before they arrived, and Nero being the greedy bastard that he is
(but in a good way, she can’t keep
herself from mentally adding), he gladly took part in their new neighbors’ business,
selling drugs to the party-goers to accompany the shows. Now that he's on the
leave, he's maybe trying to placate them with a gift – or to get rid of a troublesome product. But if that’s the case, it doesn’t make
much sense to send her, and not someone
already involved in that business already. Like Rotschild, for example. Or Giuliana.

Or Cayd. Or Reever. Or pretty much any one of Nero’s thugs.

Perhaps foolishly, that makes her hope. Hope that this Holloway, whoever she is, may be someone like her. Someone… different. She hadn’t have much luck finding answers
in Bell Town, and perhaps Nero purposefully sent her where she could finally quench
her thirst for explanations. Highely unlikely, given how self-interested the

guy was, but eh, a girl can dream, right?

And so, she
dreams, lost amidst the revelers, squinting her eyes while looking for a stall with jewels on it.

herself from mentally adding), he gladly took part in their new neighbors’ business,
selling drugs to the party-goers to accompany the shows. Now that he's on the
leave, he's maybe trying to placate them with a gift – or to get rid of a troublesome product. But if that’s the case, it doesn’t make
much sense to send <em>her, </em>and not someone
already involved in that business already. Like Rotschild, for example. Or Giuliana.

Or Cayd. Or Reever. Or pretty much any one of Nero’s thugs.</p><p class=""MsoNormal"">Perhaps foolishly, that makes her hope. Hope that this Holloway, whoever she is, may be someone like her. Someone… different. She hadn’t have much luck finding answers
in Bell Town, and perhaps Nero purposefully sent her where she could finally quench
her thirst for explanations. Highely unlikely, given how self-interested the
guy was, but eh, a girl can dream, right?</p><p class=""MsoNormal"">And so, she
dreams, lost amidst the revelers, squinting her eyes while looking for a stall with jewels on it.</p>

Coda weaves through the throng of revelers gathered closer to the North Stage.

A man in black coveralls is on the stage gesturing his arms angrily at a half dozen men who appear to be having difficulty with something on the stage. Clearly there has been ample time to transition to a new musical group by now as the first one had finished some time ago.  Very good from what Coda could hear down the street.  Captivating voice, the girl who took the primary vocals, and a nice lively sound from the quintet.  But, they could not have been the main part of the show, their set was too short and they did not seem ... well, they were not as polished as other performers are.

Beads.  Just south of the corner occupied by the cart and tables owned by the restaurateur, Proper, she sees a makeshift structure jutting out from the half block of half-collapsed brick storefront (west side of the street about 150' south of the stage right corner of the North Stage).  On a pole over the structure are strings of shiny beads.  Could those be the jewels of which Nero spoke?  It seems to be in the right area, and unless the business is concealed in the more mundane shops Coda noted on the other side (east) of the street, this seemed the most likely prospect.

The makeshift structure does not appear to have been there for too long.  It was small - perhaps 20' wide and twice that deep.  REAL small.  The walls were adorned with hooks and small shelves adorned with strings of beads and woven adornments for hair, wrists, ankles and necks.  A shelf in the middle contained woven hats and mittens that appeared to be of actual wool!  And not at all worn!  At the back of the stall was a shelf mounted on four legs covered by a black iron mesh concealing the contents within ... but, as she moved, Coda could note the sparkle of red, blue, white, and even green from places beneath the iron mesh.

A woman sat in a red, wooden folding chair before the back shelf.  She appeared far too tall for the small chair, and her long legs were crossed and her knees angled upwards from the angle at which she was seated.  In her hands was a needle and thread, and she was stringing small beads onto the thread, carefully considering each bead as she dropped them into place over the needle and onto the thread using the three fingers of her left hand (her two outside fingers appeared to be missing at the knuckles of the hand).

The woman glanced up to smile at a lady in a yellow sundress with twine straps who slowed just long enough to look longingly at the stall's wares only to be gestured onward by the elbow from a gaunt man in torn gray coveralls with an expression that screamed, ""No!""

Coda catches a glimpse of her eyes. Gray.

Clearly there has been ample time to transition to a new musical group by now as the first one had finished some time ago.  Very good from what Coda could hear down the street.  Captivating voice, the girl who took the primary vocals, and a nice lively sound from the quintet.  But, they could not have been the main part of the show, their set was too short and they did not seem ... well, they were not as polished as other performers are.</p><p>Beads.  Just south of the corner occupied by the cart and tables owned by the restaurateur, <strong>Proper</strong>, she sees a makeshift structure jutting out from the half block of half-collapsed brick storefront (west side of the street about 150' south of the stage right corner of the North Stage).  On a pole over the structure are strings of shiny beads.  Could those be the jewels of which Nero spoke?  It seems to be in the right area, and unless the business is concealed in the more mundane shops Coda noted on the other side (east) of the street, this seemed the most likely prospect.</p><p>The makeshift structure does not appear to have been there for too long.  It was small - perhaps 20' wide and twice that deep.  REAL small.  The walls were adorned with hooks and small shelves adorned with strings of beads and woven adornments for hair, wrists, ankles and necks.  A shelf in the middle contained woven hats and mittens that appeared to be of actual wool!  And not at all worn!  At the back of the stall was a shelf mounted on four legs covered by a black iron mesh concealing the contents within ... but, as she moved, Coda could note the sparkle of red, blue, white, and even green from places beneath the iron mesh.</p><p>A woman sat in a red, wooden folding chair before the back shelf.  She appeared far too tall for the small chair, and her long legs were crossed and her knees angled upwards from the angle at which she was seated.  In her hands was a needle and thread, and she was stringing small beads onto the thread, carefully considering each bead as she dropped them into place over the needle and onto the thread using the three fingers of her left hand (her two outside fingers appeared to be missing at the knuckles of the hand).</p><p>The woman glanced up to smile at a lady in a yellow sundress with twine straps who slowed just long enough to look longingly at the stall's wares only to be gestured onward by the elbow from a gaunt man in torn gray coveralls with an expression that screamed, ""No!""</p><p>Coda catches a glimpse of her eyes. Gray.</p><p><img src=""http://i.vimeocdn.com/video/548568966_1280x720.jpg"" style=""width: 406px;""></p>
Coda can’t help but pay attention to the

chattering of the crowd, and the rumors briefly catch her interest. 

Don’t know where she
comes from.""Three plus Two”, they
said, right? Her voice – so perfect. D’you if they’re scheduled
again? I felt… alive. So

alive, man.

There’s something there, for sure. But then, why
the hell did she let another group – clearly not as gifted, given the cringeworthy
sounds that now resounded from the platform – steal her spotlight? Technical
issues were no excuse. Either that mysterious singer, whoever she was, didn’t
have enough grit to keep them under her sway, or she deemed that crowd simply
didn’t deserve such artistry. Had it been her, she’d have kept going on, rig or
not, until either her voice cracked or her audience’s feet bled. When the Song
takes you, when It speaks Itself through you, allow yourself to be silenced… in

Coda’s mind, it’s nothing short of a blasphemy.

The sight of the shining beads abruptly ends
her considerations. There. It has to be there. But they’re right next to from
Proper’s place! How is she expected to conduct any kind of private business
while being feet away from the most popular hotspot in town? What if someone saw

her? What if that someone was a lawgiver? What if –

Shaking off her useless thoughts, she walks up
to the structure with a steady pace: once there, she starts playing the part of
the idle bypasser gone window-shopping. Her feigned interest soon shifts to a
sincere admiration. The amount of intricacy in the necklaces, the freshness of
the colors. And… is that… whool? Freaking freshly sheared whool? Machinally, she rubs a knitted scarf – a purple one,
with tiny orbs of amber embroidered in its fibers – feeling its warmth, its
slight roughness on her fingers. She’s has never been able to do anything manual
– she can’t sew, doesn’t know jack about repair, and the simple mention of her
only attempt at cooking still causes her crew to experiment flashback nausea. She

feels more than impressed. She’s in awe.

She tries her best not to look to the covered
shelf (now is not the time to seem suspicious), but she can’t avoid darting
wary looks to the rays of colored light that shine through the opaque fabric. She’d
bet her left kidney that, if she raised it, she’d find row after row of small
little phials, just like those she’s carrying. That’s reassuring, in a sense. She’s
definitely in the right place. Come what may, she has followed Nero’s commands.

He’ll be pleased. That’s all that matters.

And then, she sees the woman. There’s something
poignant in seeing her so, craftfully creating her ornaments while obviously
impaired by her missing fingers. As the scene with the couple unfolds, the man pressing
the woman onwards as he’d saw a ghost, she can’t help but think of two mice,

running and squeaking to escape a cat’s cold, but playful eyes.

She’s feared. And she

seems used to be feared. Maybe she even likes it that way.

Coda, strangely enough, is not afraid. In fact,
she’s thrilled, now more than ever. That woman literally exuded mystery. How
was she so gifted with a needle? Where did she managed to acquire the raw
material for her creations? And what’s the deal with people avoiding her like
plague? Of course, that might mean possibly walking into a risky situation, but
she’s sure of one thing: if she gets answers to her questions, no matter how

things will turn out, it’ll have been worth it.

Cut to the chase. No

charming, no bragging. Simply say what you truly mean to say.

“This is beautiful”, she says, raising the scarf to her
eyes, watching the amber beads glisten in the reddening light of the afternoon.
<strong>“I don’t care what Nero says, I won’t
get up on stage tonight if I’m not wearing something you made.” She makes
a brief pause, to let her name dropping being picked upon: then, she approaches,
sits on a ground at the woman’s feet, like a child would, and looks up, locking
name is Coda. Where can we talk… safely? I’ve got something for you.” She
pats two times on the small package in her arms. And she waits.

charming, no bragging. Simply say what you truly mean to say.</em></p><p class=""MsoNormal"" style=""text-align: justify;""><strong>“This is beautiful”, </strong>she says, raising the scarf to her
eyes, watching the amber beads glisten in the reddening light of the afternoon.
<strong>“I don’t care what Nero says, I won’t
get up on stage tonight if I’m not wearing something you made.” </strong>She makes
a brief pause, to let her name dropping being picked upon: then, she approaches,
sits on a ground at the woman’s feet, like a child would, and looks up, locking
name is Coda. Where can we talk… safely? I’ve got something for you.” </strong>She
pats two times on the small package in her arms. And she waits. </p>

The woman looks up as Coda enters, her eyes carefully observing her as she enters and examines the stall's wares.

Holloway's fingers are not deterred from their task as they continue as if possessed of their own sight to insert the needle and thread through the invisible eyes of the beads even as the woman's captivating gray eyes seem ready and able to to bore into Coda's very soul.  

As Coda sits on the ground before her, Holloway smiles.  She nods a head to a stool sitting immediately to her right, her eyes flashing in its direction only for an instant.

""Please.  Have a seat here.  It would be more comfortable, I am certain.""  Her voice has an accent to it - a patois unfamiliar to Coda.  The lilt of her voice, even those scant four words, is possessed of a sedate poetry. 

Setting her work down, finally, she asks, ""Could I interest you in one of my creations, then?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The woman looks up as <strong>Coda</strong> enters, her eyes carefully observing her as she enters and examines the stall's wares.</p><p>Holloway's fingers are not deterred from their task as they continue as if possessed of their own sight to insert the needle and thread through the invisible eyes of the beads even as the woman's captivating gray eyes seem ready and able to to bore into Coda's very soul.  </p><p>As Coda sits on the ground before her, Holloway smiles.  She nods a head to a stool sitting immediately to her right, her eyes flashing in its direction only for an instant.</p><p><strong>""Please.  Have a seat here.  It would be more comfortable, I am certain."" </strong> Her voice has an accent to it - a patois unfamiliar to Coda.  The lilt of her voice, even those scant four words, is possessed of a sedate poetry. </p><p>Setting her work down, finally, she asks, <strong>""Could I interest you in one of my creations, then?""</strong></p>

Coda gulps, then nods stiffly, and go quietly perch herself on the stool. She keeps her eyes riveted to Holloway the whole time, striving not to blink or look away to better keep track of the twin grey chasms on the woman's face.

Alright. You and her both know who's in charge, here. Play her game, or god knows what will happen. 

""I'd love to,"" she says, with a slightly tensed smile. ""But it'd disrepectful from me to pick one of your creations while being so unfamiliar with your work, wouldn't it? Tell me a bit more about what you create, Holloway... and tell me what you expect as payment.""

""I create objets d' arte,"" Holloway says in an unfamiliar accent, ""Designed to enhance one's perceptions of themselves, and the perceptions of those about them.""

Holloway gestures about her.  ""I weave this humble fabric from a tapestry I glimpse beyond these mortal coils.""

Lifting a string of blue-white beads, a silvery luster flashing off of them in the indirect lighting from the afternoon sunlight outside the confines of the stall.  The ""thread"" appears clear with a light blue hue almost as if of glass itself.  She gently displays the lengthy strand in the palm of both hands leaning it closer to Coda.  It appears of sufficient size to be wrapped two to three times about one's wrist.

""These stones can focus the light about you, allowing the spirit within to radiate more brightly so that others might see the brilliance of your spirit.""  She smiles, and then angles her head leaning in closer as if about to reveal some great secret.  ""When you next perform.""

She extends her palms forward to Coda, offering the bracelet to Coda for her examination.

""For anything I have here, I would ask one thing: Allow me to read what is within.""  She nods to Coda.

Holloway nods, her expression fixed in contemplation.

""I would be more than pleased to meet with you this evening at the conclusion of your performance,"" she says. Holloway waves in an elegantly dismissive nature to the strand of exotic stones.  ""May these bring you good fortune and pleasant dreams,"" she says with a smile.

Her eyes fall to the box, though not impatiently in the slightest.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><img src=""http://i.vimeocdn.com/video/548568966_1280x720.jpg"" style=""background-color: initial; float: left; width: 236px; margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px;"" alt="""">Holloway nods, her expression fixed in contemplation.</p><p><strong>""I would be more than pleased to meet with you this evening at the conclusion of your performance,""</strong> she says. Holloway waves in an elegantly dismissive nature to the strand of exotic stones.  <strong>""May these bring you good fortune and pleasant dreams,""</strong> she says with a smile.</p><p>Her eyes fall to the box, though not impatiently in the slightest.</p>

""Perfect!"" Coda feels relieved, even she can't exactly pinpoint why. Maybe it's the perspective of having her amongst tonight's audience that comforts. Or maybe simply her kind words, far different than what she's used to from Nero. 

She follows Holloway's gaze, and startles. 

""Oh, yeah right - I'm sorry, I totally forgot about these ! I'm so sorry...""

Dutifully, she opens the carboard box, fishes out the sealed enveloppe and hands it to Holloway, along with one of the little phials that it contains. She then puts the box on the ground, between them two.

""Here. I - that's all he gave me. I must confess that I have no idea of what all this is about, but-""

She cuts herself abruptly. That's not her business. She's not supposed to ask questions. Hell, she's not even supposed to stay here so long. But she wants to know. She has to know. And so, it doesn't take long for her to ask out:  

""Are you- are you two on good terms ?""

Hell, she's not even supposed to stay here so long. But she wants to know. She has to know. And so, it doesn't take long for her to ask out:  </p><p><strong>""Are you- are you two on good terms ?"" </strong></p>

Holloway only smiles at Coda's meandering conversation.  Though, she cocks her head and her eyes grow thoughtful at the girl's question about her and Nero being on ""good terms.""

""We have a working relationship.  Though, the pattern of his weave is coarse, and his stitching is... rough and knotted.""

It seems as she considers saying more, but casually leans back, clasping her hands about one knee as she crosses one bare limb over the other.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Holloway only smiles at <strong>Coda's</strong> meandering conversation.  Though, she cocks her head and her eyes grow thoughtful at the girl's question about her and Nero being on ""good terms.""</p><p><strong>""We have a working relationship.  Though, the pattern of his weave is coarse, and his stitching is... rough and knotted.""</strong></p><p>It seems as she considers saying more, but casually leans back, clasping her hands about one knee as she crosses one bare limb over the other.</p>

Coarse, rough and convoluted. Yeah, definitely sounds like Nero's line of business. But most importantly, Coda has the beginning of an answer. Holloway isn't particulary fond of the guy.

And if she's being one-hundred percent honest, Coda neither. 

Sure, he still have influence over her, she feels kind of indebted to him, and she wouldn't disobey him outright. But he has let her leash slip from his fingers, inch after inch, and now, she's got a wide enough berth to realize that standing by him isn't the best, not ever the safest option anymore. He's leaving town soon. She needs to think to her own future without him - and to that end, gaining Holloway's favor doesn't sound like a bad move. 

The logistics are clear in her head. Tonight's show won't be no simple dance routine. Nero implied that he had people to impress: ergo she will have to sing - to truly sing, that is. 

All she'd have to do is to sing a little tune, one of those little tunes she knows that can crack open the world and lay bare its skeleton. One that would throw a wrench in his plans, or advance Holloway's own. And at the end, when he'll come to her for explanations, he'll just have to say what she always did during her first concerts, when she gave the crews nosebleeds: that she was sorry, it was all an accident, that she must have gotten the notes wrong, blah blah blah, the whole spiel. And then... and then, she'll see how it turns out.

Yeah. Good plan. Good plan. Now all she needs is Holloway's acquiescence and direction.

""Oh, trust me, I know"" she says, chuckling. ""And if I'm being honest, being the one that's forced to model for these rags isn't exactly a thrilling experience. Maybe..."" Her right hand linger over her beads. ""Maybe it's time for me to get a makeover. Unstitch the old pattern and patch up something new."" She smiles wryly at the woman, sagely putting her hands on her knees. 

There. Not particularly subtle, but she should get the gist.

""Do you have a song you'd like me to sing tonight? I've not made up my mind yet, but maybe I have something in my répertoire that might... please you. ""

""It is good to make one's self over; to weave a new pattern in a worn out fabric,"" Holloway says with a nod.  ""Do not be content with merely existing in a single state.""

Holloway taps her chin with a single finger as she ponders Coda's question for a moment.

""There is a song from the before time.  I am told it was performed as part of a living story where men and women would sing as well as speak the story words.  The song was called, 'I Don't Know How to Love him.'  A song about a woman not knowing how she might love a god who had walked the world with her borne in flesh.""  She smiles.  ""I find such curiosities intriguing.""

Leaning back with a sigh, and a defeated gesture with a short parting of her hands before her, she says, ""Yet, I know that such esoterica might be outside your repertoire.  So, perhaps a song of forbidden or unrequited love?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>""It is good to make one's self over; to weave a new pattern in a worn out fabric,""</strong> Holloway says with a nod.  <strong>""Do not be content with merely existing in a single state.""</strong></p><p>Holloway taps her chin with a single finger as she ponders Coda's question for a moment.</p><p><strong>""There is a song from the before time.  I am told it was performed as part of a living story where men and women would sing as well as speak the story words.  The song was called, 'I Don't Know How to Love him.'  A song about a woman not knowing how she might love a god who had walked the world with her borne in flesh.""</strong>  She smiles.  <strong>""I find such curiosities intriguing.""</strong></p><p>Leaning back with a sigh, and a defeated gesture with a short parting of her hands before her, she says, <strong>""Yet, I know that such esoterica might be outside your repertoire.  So, perhaps a song of forbidden or unrequited love?""</strong></p>

Coda nods evasively. She thinks she has heard of this concept or song-stories once or twice: it figured in the rambling of some elders who she'd met during her travels, along with a kind of mythical road called the Broad Way. Still, the title of the song doesn't evoke any memories in her, nor does its strange subject (a woman in love, but unable to love, a god who is a... man? How peculiar. No wonder the Old Age did come to an end so fast, if that was the type of convoluted stories that was liked then).

""Unrequited love, then?"" she muses outloud. ""I can work with that. A song of longing, hope and despair, about the bonds of love who ensnares and misguide as much as they enlighten one's life... yes, that's definitely feasible. Quite a bold artistic choice, but I'm sure the public will understand.""

Well, in fact, I'm rather pretty sure they won't understand what hit them, but hey, whatever.

A small smirk curves Coda's lips. That's been a while since the last time she thought something in the lines of ""consequences be damned"". Galvanized, she plunges her eyes in Holloway's once again.

""Very well. I will sing of love and its torments tonight. I'll wait for you to arrive to begin my set, and once I'll be done, we'll be free to go elsewhere and learn to know each other a bit more.""Her smirk widens slightly, as she raises from her stool, stretching her arms and legs. ""I have a feeling this night will be... memorable"".

""I imagine that it will.  Be memorable, that is,"" Holloway says with a smile as she stands with Coda.

""I do hope that you shall enjoy my crafting,"" she says, with a glance towards the bracelet.  ""I look forward to observing how it might enhance your own tapestry,"" Holloway continues with a subtle smile.

Extending her hand, she adds, ""Until this evening, then.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><img src=""http://i.vimeocdn.com/video/548568966_1280x720.jpg"" style=""background-color: initial; float: left; width: 256px; margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px;"" alt=""""><strong>""I imagine that it will.  Be memorable, that is,""</strong> Holloway says with a smile as she stands with <strong>Coda</strong>.</p><p><strong>""I do hope that you shall enjoy my crafting,""</strong> she says, with a glance towards the bracelet.  <strong>""I look forward to observing how it might enhance your own tapestry,""</strong> Holloway continues with a subtle smile.</p><p>Extending her hand, she adds, <strong>""Until this evening, then.""</strong></p>

""Until then !"" Coda echoes gingerly, while shaking the woman's hand. ""I hope I won't disappoint you."" 

At the very instant when she utters that sentence, and quite to her surprise, many things happens simultaneously.

She graps Holloway's hand - warm, soft, yet a bit callous at the fingertips.

She feels acutely the beads on her left arm, as if they tightened around her wrists.

She hears something ringing in her ear: the sound soft, but piercing, evoking a crystal object on the verge of shattering.

She loses balance, as black dots start puncturing her vision.

And then, something happens. 

(Coda opens her brain to the psychic maëlstrom, with the general intention of ""what is it that Holloway expects from tonight's performance ?"")

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>""Until then !"" </strong>Coda echoes gingerly, while shaking the woman's hand. <strong>""I hope I won't disappoint you.""</strong> </p><p>At the very instant when she utters that sentence, and quite to her surprise, many things happens simultaneously.</p><p>She graps Holloway's hand - warm, soft, yet a bit callous at the fingertips.</p><p>She feels acutely the beads on her left arm, as if they tightened around her wrists.</p><p>She hears something ringing in her ear: the sound soft, but piercing, evoking a crystal object on the verge of shattering.</p><p>She loses balance, as black dots start puncturing her vision.</p><p>And then, something happens. </p><p>(Coda<strong> opens her brain to the psychic maëlstrom</strong>, with the general intention of ""what is it that Holloway expects from tonight's performance ?"")</p><p><strong><br></strong></p>

The black dots of Coda's vision spin and tighten together, cascading off one another in a steady rhythm, the sound of tiny crystal bells ringing a melody her mind says she knows, but she cannot recall.

At the center of the dancing black dots in her mind's eye, are a pair of luminescent, blue-gray agates.  The beautiful stones examine her, they watch her, they see inside of her.  

The gray stones grow misty and dance in rhythm to the bells, and to the unknown melody.  The melody responds to the presence of the stones, encouraged by the agates, and growing in strength and independence.  The blue-gray of the agates pulses in approval of the renewed strength of the melody - the power and verve within the crystal chimes accompanying the melody.  

Power.  Independence.  Strength.

Vulnerability.  Kindness.

Love.

The dots cease their rhythmic dance and disperse in a whine and tinkling of shattered crystal as the agates burst forward and into Coda herself.  

Catching herself before she stumbles to the ground, Coda regains her feet and stands straight.  And ... that melody?  Someone is humming it!  The melody from the chimes, from her ... vision?

She stops to look about, and the humming ceases.

Coda freezes.  The realization sets in that the melody - the one unknown to her - originated from her own throat and lips.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The black dots of Coda's vision spin and tighten together, cascading off one another in a steady rhythm, the sound of tiny crystal bells ringing a melody her mind says she knows, but she cannot recall.</p><p>At the center of the dancing black dots in her mind's eye, are a pair of luminescent, blue-gray agates.  The beautiful stones examine her, they watch her, they see inside of her.  </p><p>The gray stones grow misty and dance in rhythm to the bells, and to the unknown melody.  The melody responds to the presence of the stones, encouraged by the agates, and growing in strength and independence.  The blue-gray of the agates pulses in approval of the renewed strength of the melody - the power and verve within the crystal chimes accompanying the melody.  </p><p>Power.  Independence.  Strength.</p><p>Vulnerability.  Kindness.</p><p>Love.</p><p>The dots cease their rhythmic dance and disperse in a whine and tinkling of shattered crystal as the agates burst forward and into Coda herself.  </p><p>Catching herself before she stumbles to the ground, Coda regains her feet and stands straight.  And ... that melody?  Someone is humming it!  The melody from the chimes, from her ... vision?</p><p>She stops to look about, and the humming ceases.</p><p>Coda freezes.  The realization sets in that the melody - the one unknown to her - originated from her own throat and lips.</p>

Oh.

Oh.

Coda blinks one, then twice. She shudders, and slowly extricates her hand from Holloway's. Even though the melody no longer resound in her throat, she can still feel it dimly, thrumming within her flesh, a faint counterpoint to her racing pulse. 

She take a few steps back, unsteadily. She dares not to look at the woman - not yet. After what just happened, everything she could say would seem trivial or contrived. Holloway made her a gift - an intimate, precious gift, and she intends to repay it in the only way she knows - later. Tonight. For all this town to see. 

""I have to go."" She inhales, turns, and walks hastily towards the small shop's exit. ""See you tonight.""

Holloway made her a gift - an intimate, precious gift, and she intends to repay it in the only way she knows - later. Tonight. For all this town to see. </p><p><b style=""background-color: initial;"">""I have to go.""</b> She inhales, turns, and walks hastily towards the small shop's exit. <b style=""background-color: initial;"">""See you tonight.""</b></p>

Holloway nods, with a smile, her eyes sparkling blue-gray as she raises a hand in a departing gesture to Coda.

""Tonight,"" Holloway's voice says, the word seems to appear in Coda's mind ... maybe her ears ... hard to say, though she IS a ways behind her and the voice was softly spoken.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Holloway nods, with a smile, her eyes sparkling blue-gray as she raises a hand in a departing gesture to Coda.</p><p><strong>""Tonight,""</strong> Holloway's voice says, the word seems to appear in Coda's mind ... maybe her ears ... hard to say, though she IS a ways behind her and the voice was softly spoken.</p>

Coda storms out of the tiny shop, still shell-shocked, but determined to not let it show. She steadily retrace her steps through the joyous crowds. And yet, even as she walks, Holloway's last word continues to haunt her.

(TonightTonightTonight)

The word resounds in her head, over and over. At some point, she even has to say it out loud to get rid of the earworm - which earns her some curious stares from across the streets. 

She has to go back to Nero. The evening draws nearer, and so does that concert - whose importance in Coda's eyes obviously tripled since the last half-hour. She has to rehearse, to be. She still doesn't know the lyrics - maybe she'll have to make some up ? Or perhaps Nero knows them. Will she have the guts to ask him about it? About Holloway? She doesn't know yet.

The only thing she's sure of is that she needs to return to Smotherland as fast as she can. Half-walking, half-running, she continues to go forward, hoping with all her heart that nothing unexpected will delay her.

She doesn't know yet.</p><p> The only thing she's sure of is that she needs to return to Smotherland as fast as she can. Half-walking, half-running, she continues to go forward, hoping with all her heart that nothing unexpected will delay her. </p>

Coda makes her way back to Smotherland.  Inside she finds Nero, agitated and anxious to get things ready for the evening.  He does not notice Coda at first.

Tell us a little about Smotherland.  What does it look like from the outside?  The inside?  How far is it from the town center (roughly where the Red Salmon is)?

What problem has Nero so put out?

Describe Nero.  What does he look like?  Does he have any quirks or habits?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Coda makes her way back to Smotherland.  Inside she finds Nero, agitated and anxious to get things ready for the evening.  He does not notice Coda at first.</p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>Tell us a little about Smotherland.  What does it look like from the outside?  The inside?  How far is it from the town center (roughly where the Red Salmon is)?</em></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>What problem has Nero so put out?</em></p><p style=""margin-left: 40px;""><em>Describe Nero.  What does he look like?  Does he have any quirks or habits?</em></p>
The Smotherland. Far more peripheric to town

than the Red Salmon, it is located south-west of the center, near the docks.

 

From the outside, it’s simply a white, rusting door in the corner of a brick building with walled-up windows and a broken

lightbulb above it.

 

If you're allowed access (the wordpass changes one in every two nights), you access to a descending

stairwell, leading to another door, guarded by two members of Nero’s staff.

 

Finally behind that door, you find what an
old-timer would maybe recognize as a former clandestine bar from the Prohibition.
Brick walls, sparse and weak wall lights, round wooden tables, many framed pictures
of persons whose name has fallen into oblivion, one couch or two. The round platform
on which Coda performs is not yet out, nor are the staff he hired back in Denny (Cayd, Bo, Rotschild, and
the other dozen) present. Nero’s been to busy to think about something else to

organize stuff yet.


 

Nero. Drug dealer, manager and impresario. Oblong face, ashy blonde hair, lanky frame. Always seems to be mentally wrapped up in something very important that’s definitely not you, and definitely not your business. Collects stuff from the Time Before. Distinctive quirks: buttons and unbuttons his collar for no apparent reason, never looks anyone in the eyes, sighs and huffs a lot, next-level chain-smoker (although he never touches the drugs he sells).

Right now,
he’s doing what he likes the most: his back turned away from her, he’s sitting
on the floor, finishing yet another cigarette (where in the Hell has he found
flipping through his collection of miraculously preserved books from the

time before: pages after pages or photographies that Coda never was allowed to gaze upon (and never dared to, neither - how could she desobey him?). He’s surely not actually looking at them, at the moment: he knows their content

by heart. Something’s on his mind, and he tries to distract himself from it.

Coda doesn’t
need Holloway strange mind-reading mojo to figure out what’s the deal: it’s
about the show. Nero is on borrowed time. He was supposed to leave earlier – at
least one week and half earlier. He never remains longer in town, usually – and
his presence, as a way for addicts to get supplies, it probably getting on the
nerves of some people: other drug lords, who thoroughly dislike competition on
their home turf, but also the Sheriff and her crew, who turned a blind eye to
Nero’s presence until now, but might as well change their mind and start inquiring.
If either of them were to learn of Nero’s departure rave and decided to attend.
And if both lawgivers and cartel gangs were to find each other there… chaos

would be a light word for what would happen then.

And yet, for whatever reason, he doesn't run.

“Hi, boo”, she softly says, lowering herself to stroke
Wanna know how it went ?”
