Spices, salves, tonics, incense, pigments, implements: a witch's apothecary and ritual supplies in one.</p><p>""Take me,"" she says, as stoutly as she can. But even she can hear the exhaustion in her voice. </p>

The relief in the man's face is palpable. ""Thank you Brigit,"" he says, his shoulders dropping visibly an inch or two. ""It's just... the grey fever...""

All too well did Brigit know the grey fever that had wracked Queen's Haven the winter before. A smog had descended over Dunsmouth, and with it a punishing wave of sickness that had blighted many, and killed dozens. And if it were still lingering...

She hurried through the cramped shantytown of Queen's Haven, ascertaining what she could from the man's garbled chatter. It was not much to go on.

They came at last to a house at the edge of the settlement, cobbled together from an old boat, and river mud, in the Eastern Mountain style. The air here felt damp and cold, and coughing heavily, Brigit's lungs rejected it, unquestioning.

""This way, Witch,"" the man said, using the customary honourific. ""She's in bed.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The relief in the man's face is palpable. ""Thank you Brigit,"" he says, his shoulders dropping visibly an inch or two. ""It's just... the grey fever...""</p><p>All too well did Brigit know the grey fever that had wracked Queen's Haven the winter before. A smog had descended over Dunsmouth, and with it a punishing wave of sickness that had blighted many, and killed dozens. And if it were still lingering...</p><p>She hurried through the cramped shantytown of Queen's Haven, ascertaining what she could from the man's garbled chatter. It was not much to go on.</p><p>They came at last to a house at the edge of the settlement, cobbled together from an old boat, and river mud, in the Eastern Mountain style. The air here felt damp and cold, and coughing heavily, Brigit's lungs rejected it, unquestioning.</p><p>""This way, Witch,"" the man said, using the customary honourific. ""She's in bed.""</p>

The house had two rooms, more or less. The door led into the main room, reeking with smoke from the hearthfire burning in a pit in the center. The lack of proper building materials (and time and energy for construction, for that matter) meant the houses were assembled, like this one, cheaply, hastily, from whatever could be scavenged. Back home, the Red Folk had long ago mastered the trick of building proper flues, that evacuated smoke without letting in cold and wet. But they were tricky, required skilled crafters with time and tools - so here, most people didn't have them

The girl wasn't in the main room, though. The man led Brigit into a small back room, cramped with a curving ceiling and back room, fashioned of timber. Brigit realized they were in the hull of the old, upturned boat. 

The air was musty and damp and chilly. The floor was dirt, and there was only a thin, filthy bed of straw between it and the girl. Brigit shook her head at once. No wonder the child is sick, she thought. ""Why isn't she by the fire?"" she said. She knew she sounded irritated, frustrated, and normally she'd try to cloak that from a worried parent, but damn it, this girl was not being taken care of properly. 

The man winced. ""The smoke, Witch. She coughed terribly while she was in there. And she shivers in here, but in the main room she sweats horribly and throws off her covers. We weren't sure what to do.""

""Alright, alright."" Brigit put a hand to her forehead to think. ""We need to move her. The air here isn't wholesome. We'll take her to..."" She paused, mind racing. She'd been about to volunteer her home, but there was a dead body in it right now; that was no better. Oppida shared a single room with her parents and two siblings, and her parents were getting old - best not to expose them to someone who might have grey fever. Rowena was the same, although maybe she could go stay with another Witch? 

There was no immediate solution; she could speak to the other Witches to find one, but that would take time. She gritted her teeth and shook her head. ""I'll figure it out. Later. Alright."" She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. ""Tell me again. How long has she been sick? And have any of your neighbors or her friends been sick recently?""

The lack of proper building materials (and time and energy for construction, for that matter) meant the houses were assembled, like this one, cheaply, hastily, from whatever could be scavenged. Back home, the Red Folk had long ago mastered the trick of building proper flues, that evacuated smoke without letting in cold and wet. But they were tricky, required skilled crafters with time and tools - so here, most people didn't have them</p><p>The girl wasn't in the main room, though. The man led Brigit into a small back room, cramped with a curving ceiling and back room, fashioned of timber. Brigit realized they were in the hull of the old, upturned boat. </p><p>The air was musty and damp and chilly. The floor was dirt, and there was only a thin, filthy bed of straw between it and the girl. Brigit shook her head at once. <em>No wonder the child is sick</em>, she thought. ""Why isn't she by the fire?"" she said. She knew she sounded irritated, frustrated, and normally she'd try to cloak that from a worried parent, but damn it, this girl was not being taken care of properly. </p><p>The man winced. ""The smoke, Witch. She coughed terribly while she was in there. And she shivers in here, but in the main room she sweats horribly and throws off her covers. We weren't sure what to do.""</p><p>""Alright, alright."" Brigit put a hand to her forehead to think. ""We need to move her. The air here isn't wholesome. We'll take her to..."" She paused, mind racing. She'd been about to volunteer her home, but there was a dead body in it right now; that was no better. Oppida shared a single room with her parents and two siblings, and her parents were getting old - best not to expose them to someone who might have grey fever. Rowena was the same, although maybe she could go stay with another Witch? </p><p>There was no immediate solution; she could speak to the other Witches to find one, but that would take time. She gritted her teeth and shook her head. ""I'll figure it out. Later. Alright."" She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. ""Tell me again. How long has she been sick? And have any of your neighbors or her friends been sick recently?""</p>

The mother, pale and shaking with worry, nodded quickly. ""Yes,"" she says. ""After Duanstidesmas, when the smoke came back, the fishermen got sick suddenly. But they didn't die. Then Afren got sick-"" she indicates the father. ""-and then me, but we didn't die, so we didn't think it was anything...""

She trails off, missing serious from the sentence.

""Can you save her?"" the man asks, and then adds: ""Is it the grey fever?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The mother, pale and shaking with worry, nodded quickly. ""Yes,"" she says. ""After Duanstidesmas, when the smoke came back, the fishermen got sick suddenly. But they didn't die. Then Afren got sick-"" she indicates the father. ""-and then me, but we didn't die, so we didn't think it was anything...""</p><p>She trails off, missing <em>serious</em> from the sentence.</p><p>""Can you save her?"" the man asks, and then adds: ""Is it the grey fever?""</p>

Brigit's head is spinning. She thinks back to the height of the grey fever; it was chaos, all the Witches short of sleep. She's having trouble recalling exactly what they figured out about how it spread. The image of Gitta's body sitting unattended back in her house won't leave her head now; too much is happening all at once. 

But she does know that not everybody who caught the grey fever died. People were so afraid of it, though, that not everyone understood that.

""Just a moment,"" she says, to buy herself time to think. She kneels by the girl's bed. She's not really asleep, but not really conscious; her eyes are slightly opened and she makes a vague sound when she sees Brigit, but that's it. Brigit takes a deep breath to focus. She's tired, she's reeling from the news about Gitta - but she's needed here now. 

She knows signs to check for grey fever, and she goes through them one at a time. The fever is severe, among the worst Brigit has ever seen. There are swollen lumps in her neck - that's common with any type of fever, but these are especially pronounced. But though the girl's breathing is shallow and fast, when Brigit puts an ear to the girl's chest and doesn't hear any of the fluid sounds typical of the grey fever.

The signs are mixed, but the girl is clearly in danger. Usually the Red Witches mix magic with more mundane treatments (specific herbs, dietary changes, and of course always rest and water) for the best results. There are some tonics that help with grey fever, but they're useless in most other cases. 

But without a clear sense of exactly what's wrong, magic will have to suffice alone - which will make the spell more difficult and more dangerous.

""I'm not sure if it's grey fever,"" she says finally. ""She's in peril. I need privacy."" They'll know what that means; the restrictions on the uninitiated observing magic are well understood. But there are provisions for situations like this one, particularly involving children. ""One of you may stay,"" she tells them.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Brigit's head is spinning. She thinks back to the height of the grey fever; it was chaos, all the Witches short of sleep. She's having trouble recalling exactly what they figured out about how it spread. The image of Gitta's body sitting unattended back in her house won't leave her head now; too much is happening all at once. </p><p>But she does know that not everybody who caught the grey fever died. People were so afraid of it, though, that not everyone understood that.</p><p>""Just a moment,"" she says, to buy herself time to think. She kneels by the girl's bed. She's not really asleep, but not really conscious; her eyes are slightly opened and she makes a vague sound when she sees Brigit, but that's it. Brigit takes a deep breath to focus. She's tired, she's reeling from the news about Gitta - but she's needed here now. </p><p>She knows signs to check for grey fever, and she goes through them one at a time. The fever is severe, among the worst Brigit has ever seen. There are swollen lumps in her neck - that's common with any type of fever, but these are especially pronounced. But though the girl's breathing is shallow and fast, when Brigit puts an ear to the girl's chest and doesn't hear any of the fluid sounds typical of the grey fever.</p><p>The signs are mixed, but the girl is clearly in danger. Usually the Red Witches mix magic with more mundane treatments (specific herbs, dietary changes, and of course always rest and water) for the best results. There are some tonics that help with grey fever, but they're useless in most other cases. </p><p>But without a clear sense of exactly what's wrong, magic will have to suffice alone - which will make the spell more difficult and more dangerous.</p><p>""I'm not sure if it's grey fever,"" she says finally. ""She's in peril. I need privacy."" They'll know what that means; the restrictions on the uninitiated observing magic are well understood. But there are provisions for situations like this one, particularly involving children. ""One of you may stay,"" she tells them.  </p>

The father nods to the mother, who bows to the witch and shuffles back out of the room.

""How can I help?"" he mumbles. ""What can I do? Please, Witch, save her.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The father nods to the mother, who bows to the witch and shuffles back out of the room.</p><p>""How can I help?"" he mumbles. ""What can I do? Please, Witch, save her.""</p>

""Just...stay. Hold her hand,"" Brigit says. ""Be here for her. Her danger is real. But we can save her.""

And she begins the casting.

The magic of the Red Witches is a physical thing. She lights incense to sweeten the air and sweeps the floor. There is no overcoming their environs, the cramped dark boat-room or the foul air, but these small things are important nonetheless.

Next, she anoints the girl with a fragrant oil, and draws on her face and arms with dark red pigment, thick and greasy so it stays in place despite her feverish, sweaty skin. The shapes are important - sacred geometric shapes, mystic letters and sigils, some of the same signs that are worked into her tattoo - but not as important as the pigment itself, or her intent as the caster.

As she makes these preparations, she can't stop her mind from drifting to how fragile the Witch's supplies of these sacred substances is. The oil, for instance, is made from a flower that used to grow back home, although of course it doesn't any more. It doesn't grow here, but apparently it does away to the south, and a little bit of the oil makes its way to Dunmouth's apothecaries and grocers. Such a small supply of something that used to be so abundant...

She does her best to push this gloomy thought aside. While she works, she speaks, murmurs, hums and sings by turn, and this continues when she finishes with the girl and anoints herself. She begins drawing more signs on herself. 

Any casting is a long, involved process, and the whole spell takes perhaps two hours - perhaps longer, because it doesn't come easy. At first, to any outside observer she's just a woman praying while she works with her hands; Afren looks by turns anguished and bored. But after the first hour or so, even he has picked up on the subtle change that's coming over the room, the magic that's rising. There's an electric charge on the air, and Brigit's senses seem sharper. 

But the magic is not coming easily tonight, or gently. As she works, she starts to feel...well, different things. Some of the feelings make sense, though they rise spontaneously out of nowhere. Gitta comes to mind, and she wants to cry. That makes her think of the Eyes, and she's mad. But the emotions become more strange, and more powerful, as the spell advances. She thinks of Oppida and feels sad; she watches Afren, watching dutifully over his daughter, and feels afraid. She thinks of the man who came for her mother the other night and feels a strange, unnatural sense of euphoria.

Strong feelings, even strange feelings, are always a part of casting. But this night they're stronger and stranger than ever. The magic doesn't want to come, and it isn't coming quite right in this hateful, alien place. 

But Brigit plunges on, determined. Something must be done for this girl.
dice roll

But we can save her.""</p><p>And she begins the casting.</p><p>The magic of the Red Witches is a physical thing. She lights incense to sweeten the air and sweeps the floor. There is no overcoming their environs, the cramped dark boat-room or the foul air, but these small things are important nonetheless.</p><p>Next, she anoints the girl with a fragrant oil, and draws on her face and arms with dark red pigment, thick and greasy so it stays in place despite her feverish, sweaty skin. The shapes are important - sacred geometric shapes, mystic letters and sigils, some of the same signs that are worked into her tattoo - but not as important as the pigment itself, or her intent as the caster.</p><p>As she makes these preparations, she can't stop her mind from drifting to how fragile the Witch's supplies of these sacred substances is. The oil, for instance, is made from a flower that used to grow back home, although of course it doesn't any more. It doesn't grow here, but apparently it does away to the south, and a little bit of the oil makes its way to Dunmouth's apothecaries and grocers. Such a small supply of something that used to be so abundant...</p><p>She does her best to push this gloomy thought aside. While she works, she speaks, murmurs, hums and sings by turn, and this continues when she finishes with the girl and anoints herself. She begins drawing more signs on herself. </p><p>Any casting is a long, involved process, and the whole spell takes perhaps two hours - perhaps longer, because it doesn't come easy. At first, to any outside observer she's just a woman praying while she works with her hands; Afren looks by turns anguished and bored. But after the first hour or so, even he has picked up on the subtle change that's coming over the room, the magic that's rising. There's an electric charge on the air, and Brigit's senses seem sharper. </p><p>But the magic is not coming easily tonight, or gently. As she works, she starts to feel...well, different things. Some of the feelings make sense, though they rise spontaneously out of nowhere. Gitta comes to mind, and she wants to cry. That makes her think of the Eyes, and she's mad. But the emotions become more strange, and more powerful, as the spell advances. She thinks of Oppida and feels sad; she watches Afren, watching dutifully over his daughter, and feels afraid. She thinks of the man who came for her mother the other night and feels a strange, unnatural sense of euphoria.</p><p>Strong feelings, even strange feelings, are always a part of casting. But this night they're stronger and stranger than ever. The magic doesn't want to come, and it isn't coming quite right in this hateful, alien place. </p><p>But Brigit plunges on, determined. Something must be done for this girl. </p>

Afren looks fearful and concerned as the witch seems to waver in her ritual. He knows better than to say anything, but the energy in the room points to a nebula of possibility.

No, the casual onlooker cannot see the ends of the web woven by the spell, except the two anchor points - life on the one hand, and death on the other.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Afren looks fearful and concerned as the witch seems to waver in her ritual. He knows better than to say anything, but the energy in the room points to a nebula of possibility.</p><p>No, the casual onlooker cannot see the ends of the web woven by the spell, except the two anchor points - life on the one hand, and death on the other.</p>

Slowly, the possibilities close - and Afren can see Brigit relax as they do. The uncanny energy in the room gives way to something still potent, but not so disturbing. 

Brigit is done anointing and painting, but she still sits for a long while, one hand laid on the child's forehead, singing and speaking and humming by turns. At long last, she stops, and allows herself one brief smile. The child is sleeping peacefully now, rather than staring blindly in a fevered delirium. She takes Afren's hand and lays it across her daughter's forehead; her fever is broken. 

Brigit leads him back into the main room. She starts coughing in the smoke, but Afren's wife (sitting restlessly by the fire) brings her some water, which helps. ""She's out of danger for now,"" Brigit says gently, and the woman breaks into tears, choking back sobs so as not to wake her child in the next room. 

""We must bring her somewhere more wholesome,"" Brigit says. ""Her, and anyone else in the area who's sick or getting sick. I...know of a place that might be available. After tomorrow."" Someone will have to come for Gitta's things; she knows a few of Gitta's cousins but she's not sure who her next of kin is. ""I'll send someone tomorrow, or come myself."" 

""Thank you,"" Afren says. He takes one of her hand, and his wife takes the other. Their eyes are shining. ""Thank you so much,"" Afren adds. ""We won't forget this."" 

""It's what we do,"" Brigit tells them. She smiles again, but it's weak this time - she's so exhausted, and with the magic done, her task complete, it's suddenly catching up with her.

Afren and his wide exchange glances. ""Witch, we'd be honored if you'd spend the night here,"" the wife says. ""You must be tired...""

""No, no,"" Brigit says. ""Have to get home. Gitta...""

But magic has this effect, sometimes - especially when it doesn't come easy. And the room is hot and smoky, and suddenly Brigit's eyes won't stay open. 

Her last dim memory of that night is of being placed gently on a hard straw mattress, of a thin blanket being tucked around her shoulders, not that she really needs it in the hot room. She murmurs a weak protest, and something soothing is muttered back, and then she knows no more.

Gitta...""</p><p>But magic has this effect, sometimes - especially when it doesn't come easy. She murmurs a weak protest, and something soothing is muttered back, and then she knows no more. </p>

column4:
Palais de Nueva Parma

27 février 2030

Le capitaine Kao Kin-Bo, du bataillon de BattleMechs de la NPDF est reçu par le comte Asimodeo Di Grado, seigneur de Nueva Parma.

Nous faisons notre maximum, comte. Bien que le sergent Alvaro Mancini ai
disparu, il a laissé son BattleMech à sa fille, qui devrait pouvoir
prendre la relève. Quand à la future recrue…
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Nous faisons notre maximum, comte. Bien que le sergent Alvaro Mancini ai
disparu, il a laissé son BattleMech à sa fille, qui devrait pouvoir
prendre la relève. Quand à la future recrue…</p>
J'ai cru entendre qu'elle était arrivée, oui. C'est une étrangère,
j'espère que vous savez ce que vous faites. Vous me transmettrez leurs

dossiers, à jour. Et avec vos appréciations.

Le comte se leva, et fit le tour de son bureau, s'arrêtant quelques
instants devant l'une des toiles de maître qui ornent cette pièce
décorée avec goût. Il se dirigea ensuite vers un petit bar, pour remplir

deux verres d'amaretto, qu'il déposa sur son bureau.

Ainsi, mon cher capitaine, la troisième guerre de succession s'est

éteinte d'elle-même.

column4:
Panel 1: The scene is from the end of Issue #5, next to Morales' Warehouse and docks on Sedgewick Street in Red Hook. Long shot of TEMPUS and LI FENG on a foggy night-time rooftop as they survey the black sedans of the SI-FAN below. The cargo ship Heavenly Pearl can barely be seen through the fog, docked and with gangplank down.

SWEETS (off-panel, through two-way radio): ""The crew - they're all dead, but they're still standin' here!""

Panel 2: LI FENG, crouching, watches the unfolding action below with an intense glare. TEMPUS is just behind her.

LI FENG: Bao Cheng-ho -- he is here!

TEMPUS: That's my cue...

Panel 3: Extreme close-up of TEMPUS' temporal field regulator sparking with a strange electromagnetic energy.

SOUND EFFECT: ka-KRAKKK!

Panel 4: A bright blue flash, casting TEMPUS in a Kirby-esque psychedelic silhouette. LI FENG is semi-transparent against him as she turns half-way toward him, shielding her eyes from the flash.

LI FENG: What is -- ?!

Panel 5: TEMPUS is in the same pose as Panel Two, but his surroundings have changed. He stands in what looks like a concrete basement with pockmarked, unadorned cement walls. A metal janitor's bucket and mop stand in the corner, shrouded in spiderwebs and dust. The only light, aside from that generated by his temporal control harness, is dim red light shed by a caged emergency light bulb mounted in a nearby corridor. 

A metal ladder descends from the top of that corridor, going down into the darkness of the shaft below. A sign mounted next to it reads AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY BEYOND THIS POINT. 

The corridor also extends further into the darkness, turning a hard 90-degree corner toward the right. Another sign hangs on the wall at that corner beneath another caged light bulb, only this one isn't lit. This sign reads BOMB SHELTER, with an arrow pointing down the hall toward the right.

No one else appears to be present. It is cold and quiet, save for a distant, echoing dripping sound.

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-280515""><div class=""row"">

Blinking and reeling, Sebastian lays a hand on the wall.

It hasn't been this bad since the first tests. What on Earth went wrong?

He glances around, making doubly sure that no one is about. Then he pulls the connectors, unlocks the latches, and takes of his helmet. He runs his hands through his hair, then adjusts his glasses and surveys his regulator, checking it for external damage.

I'm positive it's in working order. All the status checks were easily within tolerance when I ran the tests...

Seeing nothing obviously wrong, he reluctantly puts his concerns aside for the moment and dons the helmet again.

Why here? Where is here? Much as I'd like to solve this mystery, the more important step is to find out where I am. The plan--such as it was--may go sideways if I can't find my way back.

Keeping a wary eye on his surroundings, he makes his way to the ladder, climbing up to see what lies above.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Blinking and reeling, Sebastian lays a hand on the wall.</p><p><em>It hasn't been this bad since the first tests. What on Earth went wrong?</em></p><p>He glances around, making doubly sure that no one is about. Then he pulls the connectors, unlocks the latches, and takes of his helmet. He runs his hands through his hair, then adjusts his glasses and surveys his regulator, checking it for external damage.</p><p><em>I'm positive it's in working order. All the status checks were easily within tolerance when I ran the tests...</em></p><p>Seeing nothing obviously wrong, he reluctantly puts his concerns aside for the moment and dons the helmet again.</p><p><em>Why here? Where is here? Much as I'd like to solve this mystery, the more important step is to find out where I am. The plan--such as it was--may go sideways if I can't find my way back</em>.</p><p>Keeping a wary eye on his surroundings, he makes his way to the ladder, climbing up to see what lies above.</p>

Scaling the ladder, Sebastian climbs up through the open shaft. By the cool air that blows in, he can tell it leads to the outdoors; artificial light shines down from what appears to be an open booth built atop the shaft. It seems like a cylindrical phone booth, only it has no door or phone. Outside the booth is night sky, but due to light pollution and slight cloud cover few stars are visible. Immediately surrounding the booth is an industrial-looking neighborhood, with cranes, silos, and chain-link fences defining its character.

A roaring sound echoes overhead, as though the sky were being rent in two. A massive aircraft soars through the night sky, with wings swept back at a 45-degree angle and what appear to be rockets mounted under each wing. However, the rockets have no visible exhaust. It reminds him of prototype designs he's seen in Popular Mechanics for turbojets, which would be consistent with what he's seeing. But he's never seen a working model before, and this jet-powered plane would rival the size of a Boeing 314 Clipper.

The enormous jet plane descends, its landing gear extending, and as Sebastian peeks over the rim of the shaft, he sees a city skyline drastically different from the one he was looking at moments before. The skyscrapers which define the skyline are stark, unadorned concrete monoliths, with some lesser buildings seemingly made mostly of glass. Gone are the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building. Skylights wave across the cloudy sky. The floor of the city is elevated from the channel, lined with towering dyke walls, though there are numerous ships docked at their base. Much smaller flying craft with mounted searchlights swarm the harbor like fireflies.

It takes a moment's observation, but it begins to dawn on Sebastian that his vantage point is the same as it was before the bright blue flash engulfed him. He is in Red Hook, looking out at Manhattan Island - but it's no Manhattan he's ever been in before.

A glance to the west, beyond Governor's Island, confirms this. Where once the towering green-tinted spectacle of the Statue of Liberty stood, holding her torch aloft to welcome weary immigrants arriving from overseas, now there is a statue of a stern woman holding a banner topped by a double-headed eagle, giving a Roman salute toward the east.

column4:
The partying went well, she found a couple of buds and they started drinking, having fun. It was rather easy to sneak in a few kisses with them, and one of them pulled out an interesting vial of white stuff. 

""Got this from a friend..."" he said... ""some new drug, supposed to practically raise the dead back to the living"" he laughed. ""or at least that's how he called it. Anyways, wanna try, I'd gladly split with you, Doli."" 


He said smiling.

Doli could immediately tell something's wrong, she could smell blood within the vial.

""Not sure if I'd be able to get more, so... it's now or never""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""Not sure if I'd be able to get more, so... it's now or never"" </p>

Doli breathed in again savouring the smell and thinking. Finally, she snatched the vial from his hand. Instead of downing it though, the vial got pocketed into her jacket. To quell any objections the beast snapped at the man commandingly: ""Gift it to me.""

column4:
Location: Ashes of Nell's Pub

Three times she had walked past that building, with its scorch-marked wood paneling, dark paths arching out of windows or away from the door -- a clear map of where the fire had once been blazing brightly.  But that was a long time ago, and surely he hadn't meant to send her to an abandoned building.  And yet she finally stopped on her forth pass, checking her phone once more before stepping uncertainly up to the ruined bar.  It was late in the day, though the muted sunlight still struggled to its way through gray cloud cover.  But it did little to warm the streets against the harsh lingering nip of winter even as spring drew ever nearer.

The young woman clutched her coat tight against her body, a dress patterned with faded flowers beneath it.  She looked to be in her early forties and of East Asian descent, with dark hair cut short around her shoulders.  Her jaw was stiff and her face was dry, but the woman's eyes were red, as she moved up to one of the intact windows and peered through at the room beyond.

The only notice the crew had to her visit was the message Johnny had received from Old Liu nearly an hour before.  

""Hey Johnny, I'm sending a young woman to that little clubhouse of yours.  Her daughter died recently -- a terrible tragedy, she was way too young -- and she's desperate for some answers.  Her name's Mei Lin Chen.  Do me a favor and lend her a hand, yeah?""


Burned Crew Tags: Ashes of Nell's Pub, Hungry for Answers

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-280119""><div class=""row"">

Johnny was already formulating his response in his head before he finished reading Old Liu's message.

""You got it, Uncle Louie. Whatever you need.""

Johnny sent word back right away. On his way out the door, Johnny asked one of the kids shooting hoops outside his apartment building to run his own message back to Liu. The kid knew the place without any directions. The narrow, four story building smack in the middle of 88th street in Chinatown: the 88th Street Association, the heart of immigrant activity in the neighborhood, and where Liu roosts even in his off time.

With word sent, Johnny put out the word to the Circle. The word, as ever, was meetup.

At Nell's, Johnny waited for the Circle to close, for everyone to show up. He was behind the bar, digging out the lone bottle of bourbon that had survived whatever tore the whole damn place apart. The glass was scorched, the label was gone, but it was there, under the bar. Johnny pulled it out and put it where everyone could reach, and he made his pitch. 

Mrs. Chen, her deceased daughter, and a favor for a friend. And if that friend wasn't enough, Johnny let on just a bit about the job's ties to the Scarlet Prosperity Tong, as the street criminals Old Liu ran were known. Whoever in the Circle of Truth wasn't motivated by morality, Johnny thought to himself, might be tempted by favors and alliances.

""...and that's why I asked you all here. She's going to be walking through those doors any second and dropping a case in our laps that made Old Liu think of us: not the police, not some private dick. Us."" Johnny unscrewed the top of the bourbon and took a short albeit thoughtful sip.

""I say let's find out why that is.""

well into this part of the City as the two broad-shouldered, rough-looking men on
the front seats fitted into a car like this, despite their tailor-made suits.
Despite that, none of the few passers-by bothered with a closer look. The men
didn't look like they would appreciate curiosity.
The passenger got out and slowly turned on the spot, sending a glower in every
direction before stepping up to the rear compartment with its toned windows and
dressed as elegant as ever, wearing a dark blazer and skirt that all but
screamed 'Big Business'. She headed for the entry of Nell's without a glance
back as the man closed the door behind her. He took one step after her,
obviously used to looming behind her, but then stopped and got back into the
Noone followed the boss into Nell's, ever. Instead, the two goons drove off to

side-walk who was heading the other way...
the head of the Tongs thinks he can order me around then I have a far more
serious issue. So far, we have not been stepping on each other's toes. If that
changes..."" Maura's smile was neither pleasant nor genuine. ""Then
again, having him owe me could reap all sorts of benefits...""

Maximus was finally in the zone after being in the meeting for five minutes, probably missing important information. His pen was flying across his paper with information that his boss might need later on. Numbers and statistics, business relationships and changes filled his paper. Anything remotely important was written down. For close to three hours with two breaks in between, Max was in the zone. Of course that would be when his phone would vibrate in his carrier bag. A little buzz that no one noticed besides him. That ruined the rest of his day. Max's focus was thrown all because of one little buzz.

The pub looked just like it did that last time that Max had dragged himself there. Worn and abandoned. Before even stepping out of his car he pressed his face against the wheel and sighed. Being here always meant helping a poor unfortunate soul and more often than not there wasn't much compensation besides a few thank you's and some unwanted hugs. But with a reluctant groan the car was parked and he got out. Most of his day was ruined with that stupid message and now he needed a drink.

""Good Lord. We take on all the charity cases dont we."" Max says with his hand holding his head up, bored expression very prevalent. ""Next we should start taking in the homeless. But this is probably more because your old Liu asked you."" Max couldn't help but jab at Johnny, but in all seriousness he couldn't really find a good reason to do the job. He had more important things to deal with.

He had more important things to deal with.</span></span></span></span></p>

It was Ms. Mei Lin Chen who was standing outside of the pub now, still uncertain.  But the address was right, and as she peered through the window she could have sworn she'd spotted some figures inside, through the dirty glass.  And so Ms. Chen straightened her shoulders, gathered her resolve amidst her grief and -- with one last glance up at the broken sign for the pub -- pulled open the front door.

She stepped inside, and suddenly those murky shapes she'd spotted through the window became clear, all hanging out at the bar.  ""Mr. Kwan?  I'm looking for Johnny Kwan?"" she said, stepping forward, the floor creaking beneath her.  Ms. Chen didn't even wait for an answer as she stepped right up to the bar, dropping her purse on the bartop and digging through it.  Her hands were shaking, and her eyes were wet.  ""My daughter... I need you to find out who killed my daughter.""

Ms. Chen pulled out a photo of her daughter, its edges slightly bent, and placed it on the bartop for them all to see.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>It was Ms. Mei Lin Chen who was standing outside of the pub now, still uncertain.  But the address was right, and as she peered through the window she could have sworn she'd spotted some figures inside, through the dirty glass.  And so Ms. Chen straightened her shoulders, gathered her resolve amidst her grief and -- with one last glance up at the broken sign for the pub -- pulled open the front door.</p><p>She stepped inside, and suddenly those murky shapes she'd spotted through the window became clear, all hanging out at the bar.  ""Mr. Kwan?  I'm looking for Johnny Kwan?"" she said, stepping forward, the floor creaking beneath her.  Ms. Chen didn't even wait for an answer as she stepped right up to the bar, dropping her purse on the bartop and digging through it.  Her hands were shaking, and her eyes were wet.  ""My daughter... I need you to find out who killed my daughter.""</p><p>Ms. Chen pulled out a photo of her daughter, its edges slightly bent, and placed it on the bartop for them all to see.</p><p><img src=""https://i.pinimg.com/564x/56/a7/c2/56a7c2738b2ad191180de0fac1247408.jpg"" style=""width: 230px;""></p>

Johnny had words for Max, and he was about to get an earful — but that was when Mei Lin Chen walked into the bar. Instead, Max was on the receiving end of gritted teeth and a firm stow it glare. When Chen made like an arrow for Johnny, he tore his eyes away from the brusque businessman, and gave the grieving mother all of his attention.

“I promise you, Ms. Chen, my associates and I are going to figure this out,” he says, reaching out and placing a consoling hand over one of her own. “Liu wouldn’t send you to us if he didn’t know for a fact you would get your answers.”

Johnny holds her gaze a little longer, keeping his voice soft, his sounds round and soothing. He made his own breathing a little more audible, subtly — a technique he had picked up working with the more troubled youths at the community center. If done right, one could bring another’s breathing into sync with their own, without them being aware of it... very useful for those who don’t believe they should, or need, to calm down.

Meanwhile, without even looking — without breaking eye contact — Johnny slid the photo down the bar towards Maura and Max. “My partners here are going to take a look at this, all right, Ms. Chen? In the meantime, maybe you can tell us a little about what happened to your daughter, and I can ask you a few questions, if I may.”
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Johnny had words for Max, and he was about to get an earful — but that was when Mei Lin Chen walked into the bar. Instead, Max was on the receiving end of gritted teeth and a firm <em>stow it </em>glare. When Chen made like an arrow for Johnny, he tore his eyes away from the brusque businessman, and gave the grieving mother all of his attention.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">“I promise you, Ms. Chen, my associates and I are going to figure this out,”</span></strong> he says, reaching out and placing a consoling hand over one of her own. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">“Liu wouldn’t send you to us if he didn’t know for a fact you would get your answers.”</span></strong></p><p>Johnny holds her gaze a little longer, keeping his voice soft, his sounds round and soothing. He made his own breathing a little more audible, subtly — a technique he had picked up working with the more troubled youths at the community center. If done right, one could bring another’s breathing into sync with their own, without them being aware of it... very useful for those who don’t believe they should, or need, to calm down.</p><p>Meanwhile, without even looking — without breaking eye contact — Johnny slid the photo down the bar towards Maura and Max. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">“My partners here are going to take a look at this, all right, Ms. Chen? In the meantime, maybe you can tell us a little about what happened to your daughter, and I can ask you a few questions, if I may.”</span></strong></p>

Ms. Chen looked uncertainly around the small group.  She hadn't exactly expected professionalism, but she could practically taste the tension in the air between them.  But Old Liu had never steered her wrong, and she pushed her doubts aside for now, nodding to Johnny.  

""My daughter, she...she fell from the roof of our apartment building.""  And it was so hard for the woman to talk about this.  Her hand was tense on the bartop, beneath Johnny's own, her eyes fixed down on the clean wood.  

""The police, they say she must have jumped.  That she committed suicide.  That's what makes sense to them.  But they don't know my daughter the way I do.""  Her eyes turned hard, and her hand shifted, clutching at Johnny's.  

""She would never kill herself.  Emily was happy, and she had so much drive.  So many goals and dreams.  But the police are just brushing it off as a suicide.  But it's not.  I swear to you, it's not.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Ms. Chen looked uncertainly around the small group.  She hadn't exactly expected <em>professionalism</em>, but she could practically taste the tension in the air between them.  But Old Liu had never steered her wrong, and she pushed her doubts aside for now, nodding to Johnny.  </p><p>""My daughter, she...she fell from the roof of our apartment building.""  And it was so <em>hard</em> for the woman to talk about this.  Her hand was tense on the bartop, beneath Johnny's own, her eyes fixed down on the clean wood.  </p><p>""The police, they say she must have <em>jumped</em>.  That she committed suicide.  That's what makes sense to them.  But they don't know my daughter the way I do.""  Her eyes turned hard, and her hand shifted, clutching at Johnny's.  </p><p>""She would <em>never</em> kill herself.  Emily was <em>happy</em>, and she had so much drive.  So many goals and dreams.  But the police are just <em>brushing it off</em> as a suicide.  But it's not.  I swear to you, it's <em>not</em>.""</p>

Johnny let her squeeze his hand as hard as she needed, even when he felt his palms pinch beneath her fingernails. He nodded, listening to everything she said.

“We’ll figure this out,” he said when she finished.

He collects from Ms. Chen the name and age of her daughter, asking along the way what kind of things she meant when discussing her daughter’s goals and drives.

Finally, he begins to dig in: “Have you noticed any change in your daughter’s routine? Anything unusual in her day to day?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Johnny let her squeeze his hand as hard as she needed, even when he felt his palms pinch beneath her fingernails. He nodded, listening to everything she said.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">“We’ll figure this out,”</span></strong> he said when she finished.</p><p>He collects from Ms. Chen the name and age of her daughter, asking along the way what kind of things she meant when discussing her daughter’s goals and drives.</p><p>Finally, he begins to dig in: <strong><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">“Have you noticed any change in your daughter’s routine? Anything unusual in her day to day?”</span></strong></p>

Ms. Chen had nothing but good things to say about her daughter.  Emily was 16, and was just your average girl in high school.  She'd always been outgoing, loved musical theater and had joined her high school's drama club at the very first chance she got.  The girl that Ms. Chen described was full of life, one who wanted to make it big in theater someday and thrived in the spotlight.  

But with Johnny's question, she hesitated for the first time.  Mei Lin shook her head almost immediately, but then paused, a little uncertain.  Her fingers fidgeted, pulling back from Johnny's.  

""No, nothing.  She was...she was happy.  I can't even imagine that she might have been...but the police said that...""  It was hard for her to get her thoughts out, hard to reconcile her girl with what everyone wanted to believe about her.  But she took a shuddering breath, forcing the words out.  

""There were cuts on her arms, old and recent ones.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Ms. Chen had nothing but good things to say about her daughter.  Emily was 16, and was just your average girl in high school.  She'd always been outgoing, loved musical theater and had joined her high school's drama club at the very first chance she got.  The girl that Ms. Chen described was full of life, one who wanted to make it big in theater someday and thrived in the spotlight.  </p><p>But with Johnny's question, she hesitated for the first time.  Mei Lin shook her head almost immediately, but then paused, a little uncertain.  Her fingers fidgeted, pulling back from Johnny's.  </p><p>""No, nothing.  She was...she was <em>happy</em>.  I can't even imagine that she might have been...but the police said that...""  It was hard for her to get her thoughts out, hard to reconcile her girl with what everyone wanted to believe about her.  But she took a shuddering breath, forcing the words out.  </p><p>""There were cuts on her arms, old and recent ones.""</p>

She pulled her fingers away, and Johnny let them go. He was silent as she forced out what she had to say, making ample room for her pain. When she finally mentioned the cuts, Johnny nodded gravely. Taking a moment to look beyond their client, exchanging glances with Maura and Max, the marshal let the gears in his head turn... before finally:

""...but you don't believe Emily would... that she would have hurt herself. Is there someone that could have? Hurt her?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>She pulled her fingers away, and Johnny let them go. He was silent as she forced out what she had to say, making ample room for her pain. When she finally mentioned the cuts, Johnny nodded gravely. Taking a moment to look beyond their client, exchanging glances with Maura and Max, the marshal let the gears in his head turn... before finally:</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""...but you don't believe Emily would... that she would have hurt herself. Is there someone that could have? Hurt her?""</span></strong></p>

""No, I can't think of anyone who would want to hurt her.  I can't even imagine why anyone would want to hurt her.  She's a good girl.""  Mei Lin was insistent.  

But Johnny remembers being a 16, and there wasn't a single teenager in this world who told everything to their parents or guardians.  And if there was anything she didn't share with her mother, any secrets she was keeping, her friends might have known.

Despite not wanting to even be there Max knew the importance of information and had started to take notes when Ms. Chen arrived. Everything important was written down along with the woman's reaction to the questions and information she was giving. He didn't know what could be important later on in this case.

When Maura had gestured if he wanted another drink he gave a curt nod and continued with the notes. During the lulls in the conversation Max would sip his drink, watch the woman. She seemed to have noble intentions but that didn't particularly matter because people were deceitful and liars. People tend to look out for themselves and not much else.

With a drink in hand a brief overview of the notes already taken Max in a low voice murmured back to Maura. ""Not much to go by. Sounds like she can't handle to truth."" Max had said it out of preservation really. He didn't want to get wrapped up in more cases that baffled the mind, but the pull to know the truth most of the time outweighed to need to be safe. Max started tapping his pencil while thinking of possible ideas. ""Could be a homicide."" He mentioned softly almost to himself.

The more Max thought the more possibilities came to mind and the smaller the chances of success were. He could potentially get information about the daughter through school records or hospital records. The daughters friends would have information too. Searching her room might be a wise idea as well, but all in time.

Johnny seemed to have a personality that people were drawn to, and Max had no intention or ruining the steady flow of information that the Ms. Chen was giving with his rather upfront and blunt questions that he had in mind.

Johnny wrapped up his questioning of Ms. Chen, taking care to get the workhorse information the Circle would need: the school that Emily attended, the names of the teacher running the drama club and Emily's friends in that club, and similar. While doing so -- when Ms. Chen had her momentum and was speaking without pause -- Johnny paid her perfect attention; more often, however, her words were broken up by her own sadness. This was when Johnny would spare a look past her towards where the others were seated. Max's note-taking earned a nod from Johnny. Finally:

""Thank you, Ms. Chen. You did the right thing, coming to us."" He gave her hand one last squeeze, saying ""Excuse me for just a moment,"" before he stepped out from behind the bar and joined the others. 

His laid his hands flat on their shared table, leaning forward over it, his voice quiet. ""All right, I've got what I want, and I don't think I'm going to learn anything else right now. If you two have any ideas, go ahead and ask her -- politely,"" Johnny adds as a sudden afterthought, eyeballing Max. 

""Frankly, I think our best play is to put a couple of us on our leads, and someone escort Ms. Chen home, just to be safe... maybe take a look around.""

""Could be."" Maura agreed, swirling the bourbon in her glass.It desperately needed ice. Maybe she should buy the ruin, rebuild it. Or at least hide an icemaker somewhere in the back.
""There is one more thing I can try here - from the more nebulous side of things."" Rising from her seat, Maura gave Johnny an almost impercebtible nod and stepped up to the distraught mother. ""Ms. Chen, if you don't mind, could I have the photo for a moment? We will need a copy of it.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(79, 97, 40);"">""Could be."" </span></strong>Maura agreed, swirling the bourbon in her glass.It desperately needed ice. We will need a copy of it.""</span></span></strong></p>

As Maura approaches Chen, she might as well be gliding as far as Johnny is concerned. He tilts his head, just enough to watch her go from the corner of his eye. Maura was intimidating, she was cold, she was downright frightening, and not someone to be messed with or underestimated or even trusted necessarily...

However.

However.

It was a quiet, fascinated however that sounded in the back of Johnny's mind. It sounded like a siren call, a string of words that were enough to bend his mood and his will, despite them being on different sides of the law. It was a tune that went a little like this: she's got fucking magic, Johnny. She's got this in the bag -- what the hell would you do, big guy? You gonna punch this problem, Johnny? 

The marshal grit his teeth and snapped his head around the other direction, replacing the image of the sorceress with the gutted wall of the pub. Black streaks of soot had traced their way up and inside it, like a crawling and twisting tattoo penned in remembrance of violence, sunk deep into the building's bones. The thought of the bar's destruction, of lives and livelihood lost, and of what it might or might not have to do with the Circle, stripped some of the glamour Maura in Johnny's mind.

Heh. Glamour. 

Damn it.

With a deep breath to clear his mind, Johnny instead focused his thoughts and his eyes on Max: ""You've been quiet, man. Not necessarily, y'know, more quiet than usual, I guess.""

""I was thinking... depending on what Maura comes up with... what do you think about walking Ms. Chen home, making sure she's safe? I mean, you did do a good job looking out for my mom, after all.""

I mean, you did do a good job looking out for my mom, after all.""</span></strong></p>

Watching Maura talk to Ms. Chen was a sight to behold. The way Maura's cold demeanor, and frightening aura manifested made Max envious. Her confident walk,  deadly looks, the way she controlled her part of the underground created an appreciation for her in Max.

After a moment of watching her Max made the mistake of looking at Johnny. Boy scout was looking at him with the same face he gave him when he wanted Max to do something worthless.

""I prefer to reserve my breathe for things worthwhile.""

Then Johnny suggested he do more. Take Ms. Chen home? What purpose does that serve? The woman got here just fine herself. 

""I'm sure she could get home just fine boy scout. She got here just fine herself. But if your so worried walk her yourself. Got things to do that are of actual benefit. "" 

Max finished his statements with a condescending smile, grabbing his notepad and putting it away.

"" </span></strong></p><p>Max finished his statements with a condescending smile, grabbing his notepad and putting it away. </p>

Ms. Chen looked uncertainly at Maura a moment, the woman's cold demeanor off-putting next to Johnny's openly comforting warmth.  But she nodded after a moment, pulling the photo off of the bartop and offering it to Maura.  And yet Ms. Chen seemed hesitant to actually release it to the woman, though she eventually did.  

""Please, you don't have to worry about me,"" she said, looking back at Johnny and Max.  ""Just focus on my daughter.  That's all I ask.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Ms. Chen looked uncertainly at Maura a moment, the woman's cold demeanor off-putting next to Johnny's openly comforting warmth.  But she nodded after a moment, pulling the photo off of the bartop and offering it to Maura.  And yet Ms. Chen seemed hesitant to actually <em>release</em> it to the woman, though she eventually did.  </p><p>""Please, you don't have to worry about me,"" she said, looking back at Johnny and Max.  ""Just focus on my daughter.  That's all I ask.""</p>

Johnny was pulled away from his conversation by Ms. Chen's words, looking in her direction. Though in his peripheral vision he watched Maura hold the photo of Emily, his eyes were locked on the poor girl's mother: ""All right. We'll take care of this. I promise.""

After that, once Johnny is sure that everyone has had their say, he shows Ms. Chen out of Nell's Pub with some final kind words. He locks the door behind her, and leans on the door frame: now, alone, they can try employing the strangeness that drew them together in the first place. With his arms crossed over his chest, Johnny looks down at his right hand: VERITAS inked over his knuckles, and the small circle of a snake devouring its own tail emblazoned over his thumb.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Johnny was pulled away from his conversation by Ms. Chen's words, looking in her direction. Though in his peripheral vision he watched Maura hold the photo of Emily, his eyes were locked on the poor girl's mother: <span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);""><strong>""All right. We'll take care of this. I promise.""</strong></span></p><p>After that, once Johnny is sure that everyone has had their say, he shows Ms. Chen out of Nell's Pub with some final kind words. He locks the door behind her, and leans on the door frame: now, alone, they can try employing the strangeness that drew them together in the first place. With his arms crossed over his chest, Johnny looks down at his right hand: VERITAS inked over his knuckles, and the small circle of a snake devouring its own tail emblazoned over his thumb.</p>

Maura smiled at the mother, noticing the hesitation. And here she had tried to play all nice and approachable. Either Ms. Chen was just very good at seeing through acts, or Johnny's pureness interfered with her bullshit mana. But the good Marshal was kind enough to see the woman out soon enough, which made her job a bit easier. No need to try to hide what she was doing.

Sitting down at one of the tables she put the photo down in front of her and opened her bag. Somewhere else she would have done at least some minimal cleaning and thus cleansing, but Nell's had just recently been cleansed by fire in the most literal sense. There was little worry of residual magic interfering with her attempt.
Which by no means guaranteed success. Casting a spell by ritual recquired foci - after all, that was the whole point of a ritual, the use of foci totake some strain off the caster,whether they were items, careful preparations or a certain litany. Maura always carried with her a couple of small items that could be used as general foci for a wide variety of spells, but that strength was also their weakness. The more specific the focus was to a spell or situation, the easier it was for the caster.

Max and Johnny would see her arrange a number of items around the photo. Directly between it and herself she put a small stick of incense, using a glass to hold it, and lit it. Then, going clockwise, she placed a small pocket mirror - a general focus for seeing and scrying - , a small plastic crown from a child's toy - acting as a focus for the sovereignity aspect of the Morrígan - , the feather of a raven - another general focus for her Mythos - , and lastly a pistol round for murder and death, and the Morrígan's war aspect.

The items were arranged in a circle around the photo, evenly apart - or, for those who could pick up on such details at the tips of a five-pointed star, with the Photo in its center.
With eyes half-closed, Maura kept her breath even and calm and focused on the spell, hoping to see something useful in the smoke rising from the incense or the reflections in the mirror...
dice roll

Then, going clockwise, she placed a small pocket mirror - a general focus for seeing and scrying - , a small plastic crown from a child's toy - acting as a focus for the sovereignity aspect of the Morrígan - , the feather of a raven - another general focus for her Mythos - , and lastly a pistol round for murder and death, and the Morrígan's war aspect.</p><p>The items were arranged in a circle around the photo, evenly apart - or, for those who could pick up on such details at the tips of a five-pointed star, with the Photo in its center.<br>With eyes half-closed, Maura kept her breath even and calm and focused on the spell, hoping to see something useful in the smoke rising from the incense or the reflections in the mirror...</p>

Lips twitching with silent incantations, Maura watched the swirling smoke through half-lidded eyes until her focus shifted to what lay beyond it, but not behind, a strange sensation she could not explain any better...

column2: Johnny pushed himself off the door frame, gently -- slowly -- hearing the wood groan as he moved. His eyes were locked on Maura, on the pentagram, on the smoke. His mouth was dry, and Johnny thought maybe he could feel his skin tingling as power coalesced and answered Maura's call. ""...is there anything... is there anything Max and I should be... doing? Maura?""
Look, you need a ghost punched? Call Johnny. You need police info? Call Johnny.
You need someone to just play it cool during a seance? Probably call somebody else.

column1: ""Yes."" Maura replied, still squinting at the smoke. ""Stay quiet and don't distract me."" She was trying to guide the spell now, focus it on the moment of the girl's death and what lay just before it, trying to catch a glimpse of her jump - or the person to shove her off the roof.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><span style=""color: rgb(79, 97, 40);""></span><strong><span style=""color: rgb(79, 97, 40);"">""Yes."" </span></strong>Maura replied, still squinting at the smoke.<span style=""color: rgb(79, 97, 40);""></span><strong><span style=""color: rgb(79, 97, 40);""> ""Stay quiet and don't distract me.""</span></strong> She was trying to guide the spell now, focus it on the moment of the girl's death and what lay just before it, trying to catch a glimpse of her jump - or the person to shove her off the roof.</p>

Max stayed quiet liked Maura asked, having nothing to say or no input. He also didn't want to ruin the. . .thing she was doing. Whatever Maura was doing was causing the atmosphere around him feel stuffy, uncomfortable. In a small attempt to distract himself from the uncomfortable feeling he looked at Johnny and immediately regretted it.

Johnny looked like how he acted in Max's opinion. The good guy who follows the rules and sticks to the script, and by God did Max hate it. Max expression scrunched in distaste and turned his attention back to Maura, whatever she was doing.

column3: Prologue B ~ The Tangled Webs We Weave

column4:
Waxing Crescent - Cycle 8 (Toad), Red Row (Ratcatch)

Across the mossy cobbled courtyard that lies outside the old Ratcatch Vermissian station, lies a tunnel entrance, sealed by a large round steel hatch.

Inside, a cool light washes over rows and rows of translucent eggs that line the walls and ceilings of the old sewer tunnels. Old dry blood crusts around the base of each egg, but no spot of it can be seen on the soft thick shells themselves. Their constant thirst never lets it stain them for long. 

Goodsister Rhaecyn stares over the rows of eggs, some kicking, some humming, one or two chattering, near to hatching. Thin legged black spiders move across the smallest eggs, piercing the shells and depositing life affirming fluids. Smaller, thicker spiders crowd about failed eggs, consuming the remains and clearing the space.
