column4:
One of the first things Stone-Parting-River does after going on a tour of the fascinating area called the Dojo is hit the books.  Stone, very much aware of the glaring disadvantage he is currently at, is determined to puzzle out learning Old realm to the near exclusion of everything else the first few weeks his time here.  Stone will not rely on someone else to do something as simple as read a sign.

Retracing his steps, he finds himself in the library.  Like everything else he has seen in this fascinating and yet slightly terrifying place, it is grandiose beyond anything he has experienced.  Stacks of scrolls and bound books nearly beyond sight both outward and upward, and for some reason spiralling downward as well.  Beams of light meandering around, lighting for those within researching some topic or another.  Unfortunately, there was little in the way of recognisable organization and direction for Stone.  What may be gods or spirits flitted about, or they could just be sentient sheets of paper for all Stone knows about this place.  Stone begins to wander about, looking for something resembling a Librarian or information desk to get some direction - and hope they understand a more mortal tonuge .

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-280529""><div class=""row"">
(Perception + Awareness to start looking for a librarian)
dice roll
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>(Perception + Awareness to start looking for a librarian)</p>

A flitting shadow pulled Stone's eyes skyward, where a grape colored teardrop stretched down before him. Great chitinous spindle legs spun out and rested delicately on the ground from it's top third mass, while two smaller, three fingered white claws fractaled out from the bottom. Four cloudy green spheres blinked from the drop's center.

It hung paitently, the legs keeping it from turning, steeped its claws together patiently, and spoke in a cacophony of whispers between Stone's ears. 

assistance?

The fact that Stone could not identify a mouth on the thing did not escape his notice, nor the fact that the top of the teardrop didn't seem to exist; the... thing just stretching upward out of sight.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>A flitting shadow pulled Stone's eyes skyward, where a grape colored teardrop stretched down before him. Great chitinous spindle legs spun out and rested delicately on the ground from it's top third mass, while two smaller, three fingered white claws fractaled out from the bottom. Four cloudy green spheres blinked from the drop's center.</p><p>It hung paitently, the legs keeping it from turning, steeped its claws together patiently, and spoke in a cacophony of whispers between Stone's ears. </p><p><strike style=""background-color: initial;"">assistance?</strike></p><p>The fact that Stone could not identify a mouth on the thing did not escape his notice, nor the fact that the top of the teardrop didn't seem to exist; the... thing just stretching upward out of sight.</p>

Stone's breath catches for a moment.  Of all the forms a Librarian could take, a spider of sorts was not on that list.

""Um..yes.  I am looking for a way to learn Old Realm, do you have some form of instruction for the mortals that come to the tournament to do so?""


The curiously shaped spider thinks for a moment.. and speaks again

newcomer, follow

The ""librarian"" begins to skitter away, with Stone following behind.  A meandering path among the stacks and stacks of scrolls later does the librarian lead Stone to what appears to be a small shelf of rather dusty scrolls, as if they haven't seen much use in some time.  Thankfully however, these were actually labeled in common.

here, learn, goes the librarian who then again retracts from sight.

Stone spends several minutes picking through the group of scrolls, looking for where to begin.  Grabbing a few scrolls that look promising, he makes his way back to the main area where he saw a few desks.

""In a dojo of the gods, here to train, and yet here I am reading and researching.  Hopefully I can get through this quickly and move on to other matters.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Stone's breath catches for a moment.  Of all the forms a Librarian could take, a spider of sorts was not on that list.</p><p><em>""Um..yes.  I am looking for a way to learn Old Realm, do you have some form of instruction for the mortals that come to the tournament to do so?""</em></p><p><em><br></em></p><p>The curiously shaped spider thinks for a moment.. and speaks again</p><p><del>newcomer, follow</del></p><p>The ""librarian"" begins to skitter away, with Stone following behind.  A meandering path among the stacks and stacks of scrolls later does the librarian lead Stone to what appears to be a small shelf of rather dusty scrolls, as if they haven't seen much use in some time.  Thankfully however, these were actually labeled in common<del>.</del></p><p><del>here, learn</del>, goes the librarian who then again retracts from sight.</p><p>Stone spends several minutes picking through the group of scrolls, looking for where to begin.  Grabbing a few scrolls that look promising, he makes his way back to the main area where he saw a few desks<del>.</del></p><p><em>""In a dojo of the gods, here to train, and yet here I am reading and researching.  Hopefully I can get through this quickly and move on to other matters.""</em></p>

Very quickly Stone-Parting-River learned that nothing here was ever simple or straight forward.  The scrolls he started with were riddled with metaphor!  How one turns what should be a simple alphabet into unclear metaphor, let alone what twisted mind thought that was a good idea, was not a series of thoughts that Stone ever thought he would have to contemplate.

*tear*, a rip, of moving past..

*drip*, a drop of  sweet vitae!..

*woosh*, a sound, that weapons make..

*grk*, a deep dark wound is made...

*splat*, its all about the floor...

*thud*, its time to get away...

*gasp*, a new mark has been seen...

and it brings us back to... 

However, he does find it kind of catchy at points.  Doing wonders for his pronunciation once he started getting the hang of it.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Very quickly Stone-Parting-River learned that nothing here was ever simple or straight forward.  The scrolls he started with were riddled with metaphor!  How one turns what should be a simple alphabet into unclear metaphor, let alone what twisted mind thought that was a good idea, was not a series of thoughts that Stone ever thought he would have to contemplate.</p><p><em>*tear*, a rip, of moving past..</em></p><p><em>*drip*, a drop of  sweet vitae!..</em><em><br></em></p><p><em>*woosh*, a sound, that weapons make..</em></p><p><em>*grk*, a deep dark wound is made...</em></p><p><em>*splat*, its all about the floor...</em></p><p><em>*thud*, its time to get away...</em></p><p><em>*gasp*, a new mark has been seen...</em></p><p><i style=""background-color: initial;"">and it brings us back to... </i></p><p>However, he does find it kind of catchy at points.  Doing wonders for his pronunciation once he started getting the hang of it.</p><p><em><br></em></p>

Several more days and weeks pass, and Stone finishes each scroll one by one.  As the time passes he starts getting fits and spurts of conversation out of people, learns more about what is actually going on around him, what is expected of him as a tournament participant, and can finally read the damn signs (though he will continue to dispute with whichever god came up with the signs for the bathroom that any of that makes sense).

The included intelligence gathering capability also allowed Stone to more fully explore the ""Dojo"".  While some aimless wandering did help, it became apparent that the tour provided at the beginning was anything but.  Additional Training areas, some more specialized towards one lesson or another were found and noted for later use.  Rocky Waterfalls and their related pools of water were found, Pitch black rooms filled with obstacles, oratorium's with the occasional debate or verbal sparring match, and the off quite spot for meditation.

It is the last two that Stone would be later making use of when introducing himself to his Paisho and going back and forth with PanDao.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Several more days and weeks pass, and Stone finishes each scroll one by one.  As the time passes he starts getting fits and spurts of conversation out of people, learns more about what is actually going on around him, what is expected of him as a tournament participant, and can finally read the damn signs (though he will continue to dispute with whichever god came up with the signs for the bathroom that any of that makes sense).</p><p>The included intelligence gathering capability also allowed Stone to more fully explore the ""Dojo"".  While some aimless wandering did help, it became apparent that the tour provided at the beginning was anything but.  Additional Training areas, some more specialized towards one lesson or another were found and noted for later use.  Rocky Waterfalls and their related pools of water were found, Pitch black rooms filled with obstacles, oratorium's with the occasional debate or verbal sparring match, and the off quite spot for meditation.</p><p>It is the last two that Stone would be later making use of when introducing himself to his Paisho and going back and forth with PanDao.</p>

Training with PanDao for oratory was... almost certainly the wrong term. The colorfully monochrome giant was actually a decidedly terrible speaker; often losing his train of thought and picking up wandering colloquialisms. At least twice he stopped mid conversation to stare up at a tree, once for nearly a minute.He had no understanding or interest in the right ways of speaking, only recognizing the most blunt of insults as such. More often, he'd simply smile at the 'purdy words.'

Still, his jovial nature and sheer boisterous volume exerted a kind of social force; it was hard not to smile near the man, and his enthusiasm was infectious. He just had this presence about him that made it hard not to follow along. Stone was not a leader of men type, but tricks to inspire confidence are always useful. Smiling, the odd bobbing of PanDao's head to evoke nodding, even just speaking from the bottom of one's lungs instead of the back of their throat; all of these held lessons to unpack.

The giant was learning from him as well. Or maybe George was... these things are difficult to tell. After a few 'hiding sessions,'Stone-Parting-River' had to start trying to hide, instead of simply standing on that club. He could follow the poison vial almost a fourth of the time now, instead of simply being amazed at how Stone's ""magic!"" He was still impossible to hide; vast landscapes of sharp contrast fur tend to stand out. But maybe he, or more likely George, could find the target for a hidden blade or two?

(Training with Stone-Parting-River for training montage 1 increased PanDao's Perception to 2, and heightened George's awareness, giving PanDao a Specialty: Awareness: George)

column4:
The quick list of things (try) to grab.

The marines' gear: battle dress and combat armor, weapons / ammo, and tech (tactical gear, electronics, night vision, sighting aids, etc.)

Robots: warbots, engineering 'bots, etc.  leaving behind those with lesser capabilities.

Computer data:  I assume that the 3I spooks will grab everything before releasing the ship, but I would like to try to get copies before they have a few weeks to sterilize the data.

Cargo: Check the manifest to see what they were carrying and grab the best stuff.  May also include missiles and other ship scale ammo.

One or more of the removable turrets, if possible.

Starship weapons: turret sized particle beams, fusion guns or similar heavy hitters.

Ships' locker contents: Cash, weapons, and high-end vacc suits primarily.

Other stuff as it presents itself. . .

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-280767""><div class=""row"">

Assuming the deployable turrets are not missile turrets, as those would want a magazine for extended combat, the next most expensive would be an Ult. T4 Deployable Beam Laser Turret-14 at 6MCr and 3Td each. T5 does not have any turret sized particle, plasma or fusion starship weapons. The most we could carry would be 8, 6 in the main cargo bay and 2 on the Gig.

Something else to look for would be if there are any Obs./Ult. T4 Pulse/Beam Laser firmpoint weapons used as point-defense as those could be mounted on the Osprey itself.

Any warbots are I think our best bet, even more so than starship grade weapons.  They would have the advantage of probably being in storage for the last 21 years.

We definitely want to check the ship's safe.

Some sample gear and values:

Adv. Combat Armor-14, 48kg, 160KCr

Mod. Very light Combat Armor-14, 32kg, 192KCr (Guards issue?)

Imp. FGMP-14, 33KCr

Mod. Gauss Rifle-14, 3.24kg, 1.2KCr

Mod. Gauss Pistol-14, 0.59kg, 720Cr

Ult. Laser Rifle-14, 3.36kg, 4.2KCr

Ult. Laser Pistol-14, 0.92kg, 420Cr

Adv. Heavy Hostile Environment Suit-10, 12kg, 32KCr (Would have seen heavy use or been cannibalized in the 21 years I think)

Their pharmacy would be very depleted, not to mention 21 years old.

More as I think of it.

There is also the possibility of a few sniper type weapons and grenades and such, Survival Kits are also high-value compact items.

All I can think to say is any psionic devices that would be useful. Also, crew and officer personal data devices, photographs, anything that might reveal information that would normally not be in too much danger of being found by Imperial spies. Other than that I think most of the bases have been covered as far as material. If we have anyone who'd understand the science and technology behind how they put together the  hydroponics stuff. In case any of it was a previously unknown innovation.

column4:
The invitation, in the charcoal grey envelope of central court, arrived at night when the household - bar Sir Ian Grenville, busy cooking the books - were sleeping. Slipped beneath the door, like a wisp of fog, but with greater import.

The next morning it was laid before Ian's place at the breakfast table, with the other post. But it almost made him choke on his eggs - for within the envelope was a note from the king's personal servant.

Sir Ian,

You are invited to attend interview with his Imperial Majesty, King Brynn-av-Alice.

Instructions for attendance, including a request to come without others, followed - and finally, a date and time.

He had barely time to finish breakfast - but it would not do to keep the king waiting.

A dash through the streets to the citadel, and, showing his invitation at every gate, it was not long before Sir Ian stood before the great grey doors of the king's reception room. Doors through which he had never been; doors which, in truth, he never expected to enter.

He knocked loudly, three times, as instructed.

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-281878""><div class=""row"">

Despite the short notice, Ian had taken precious time to dress for the occasion. High fashion for the Dunmothian gentleman was by and large a sober affair of blacks, greys and crisp whites, with here and there a hint of color afforded by a sash or cravat. The one exception to this rule was that men who had served were permitted to wear their regimental dress uniforms on formal occasions. Before dashing out to meet the boy king, Sir Ian had availed himself of this privilege. 

Now he stood before the doors to the royal audience chamber with his lean frame clad in the salmon and canary velvet of the Queen's Second Colonial Hussars-- the Dawn Regiment, so named for having been stationed at the farthest eastern reaches of the empire. Bright golden thread lined his doublet and the seams of his trousers; his riding boots were like polished onyx. After some consideration, he had girded his dress saber as well. A boy, he reasoned-- even a royal one-- might be taken with such things. 

When the doors opened to admit him, Sir Ian swept impetuously to the center of the chamber like some exotic bird. Once there, he dropped a bow so deep that his greying hair brushed the polished granite beneath his soles. 

""Your majesty,"" he declared, with eyes averted, ""Sir Ian Grenville-- ever a servant to Dunmouth-av-Alice and her crown-- hastens to obey your summons."" Only then did he risk a glance up at the scene that awaited him.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Despite the short notice, Ian had taken precious time to dress for the occasion. High fashion for the Dunmothian gentleman was by and large a sober affair of blacks, greys and crisp whites, with here and there a hint of color afforded by a sash or cravat. The one exception to this rule was that men who had served were permitted to wear their regimental dress uniforms on formal occasions. Before dashing out to meet the boy king, Sir Ian had availed himself of this privilege. </p><p>Now he stood before the doors to the royal audience chamber with his lean frame clad in the salmon and canary velvet of the Queen's Second Colonial Hussars-- the Dawn Regiment, so named for having been stationed at the farthest eastern reaches of the empire. Bright golden thread lined his doublet and the seams of his trousers; his riding boots were like polished onyx. After some consideration, he had girded his dress saber as well. A boy, he reasoned-- even a royal one-- might be taken with such things. </p><p>When the doors opened to admit him, Sir Ian swept impetuously to the center of the chamber like some exotic bird. Once there, he dropped a bow so deep that his greying hair brushed the polished granite beneath his soles. </p><p>""Your majesty,"" he declared, with eyes averted, ""Sir Ian Grenville-- ever a servant to Dunmouth-av-Alice and her crown-- hastens to obey your summons."" Only then did he risk a glance up at the scene that awaited him. </p>

The chamber was indeed opulent, but not entirely as Sir Ian had imagined. Already intimately acquainted with the polished marble floor, the stonework extends almost seamlessly from floor to ceiling, but changing at the boundary of floor and wall into a black onyx which Grenville would recognise from his sejourns in the Western Mountains, where such stone would be left in the wake of Anu'u.

The walls too were adorned with the eighteen banners of the provinces, eight of which flanked each of the left and right walls, and two of which were behind the throne dais in front of him. Grenville's eyes are drawn to these: on the right, the long grey banner of Dunsmouth-av-Alice, adorned with the city symbols; and to the left, the mahogany banner of the Red Mountain province. Unusual placement, Sir Ian would note, as this was the most recent acquisition in the imperial campaigns.

If his eyes managed to stray to the ceiling, they are vaulted and high, affording thick, deep shadows in whatever balconies and lofts might cut into the stone depths. They are carved from the sandstone taken from the uplands of Dunmouths's own province.

Sir Ian knows that there are large windows in the recesses of this room, but they admit no light today, being covered with luxuriant thick drapery which must be imported from one of the southern merchant cities, the style being unfamiliar to him. This again would attract comment, were this fact to be known outside of this room, for it suggests infealty to the Shepherdesses of Amberley province, who tirelessly and ceaselessly produce fine wool for the production of soft furnishing. Indeed, the interdiction demanding that courtiers dress entirely in woolen clothing and furnish their house with Amberley wools had only recently been lifted. Instead, the room is lit by large candelabras which hang suspended by ropes unseen from the vaulted ceilings; light is cast in small pools in this manner, such as the one occupied by Sir Ian himself, and those illuminating the banners of the provinces.

Another pool of light is ahead, and is by far the largest, although perhaps not the brightest. Its yellow light illuminates the throne dais, which contains the three wooden thrones of state, arrange in a loose arc. In the best of times, these thrones would hold the reigning monarch, their spouse, and their named heir. Today, and presumably throughout this epoch, only one throne is occupied. It would be assumed that the monarch would sit in the central throne, but this is not the case, and instead the Boy-King sits in the left-hand throne, that of the named heir, slouching and leaning in that way common to most teenagers, despite that the Boy-King is in fact 17 years old, and shortly to come of age.

He is dressed not in the regal clothes of state, but in fashionable but sombre mourning robes - still, after all this time, missing his mother.

""Sir Ian Grenville,"" he shouts, from the other side of the room. The sound echoes around for a few moments, then is deadened by the thick curtains. ""It amuses me that, unlike the other snivelling courtiers, you arrive exactly at the hour of summoning, and not before. For this, you have my thanks.""

He claps twice, and figures step forward from the shadows - the royal guardsmen. Standing tall in their ceremonial armour, clasping pikes, they step into the central aisle of the room, turn towards the door, and march out in synchronous time. A few other figures, for the most part servants, join the parade at the back. The guardsmen look forth, through and past Sir Ian, as they go by; the servants look down, not meeting his eye. Only one, a woman in a dark cloak, looks up as she passes. Was that a smile, a smirk? It's hard to tell in the gloom.

""Step forth, Sir Ian,"" the Boy-King says, more quietly, as the heavy doors slam shut behind him. ""Come hither, and tell me why Dunmouth should spare you the indignity of trial.""

Already intimately acquainted with the polished marble floor, the stonework extends almost seamlessly from floor to ceiling, but changing at the boundary of floor and wall into a black onyx which Grenville would recognise from his sejourns in the Western Mountains, where such stone would be left in the wake of Anu'u.</p><p>The walls too were adorned with the eighteen banners of the provinces, eight of which flanked each of the left and right walls, and two of which were behind the throne dais in front of him. Grenville's eyes are drawn to these: on the right, the long grey banner of Dunsmouth-av-Alice, adorned with the city symbols; and to the left, the mahogany banner of the Red Mountain province. Unusual placement, Sir Ian would note, as this was the most recent acquisition in the imperial campaigns.</p><p>If his eyes managed to stray to the ceiling, they are vaulted and high, affording thick, deep shadows in whatever balconies and lofts might cut into the stone depths. They are carved from the sandstone taken from the uplands of Dunmouths's own province.</p><p>Sir Ian knows that there are large windows in the recesses of this room, but they admit no light today, being covered with luxuriant thick drapery which must be imported from one of the southern merchant cities, the style being unfamiliar to him. This again would attract comment, were this fact to be known outside of this room, for it suggests infealty to the Shepherdesses of Amberley province, who tirelessly and ceaselessly produce fine wool for the production of soft furnishing. Indeed, the interdiction demanding that courtiers dress entirely in woolen clothing and furnish their house with Amberley wools had only recently been lifted. Instead, the room is lit by large candelabras which hang suspended by ropes unseen from the vaulted ceilings; light is cast in small pools in this manner, such as the one occupied by Sir Ian himself, and those illuminating the banners of the provinces.</p><p>Another pool of light is ahead, and is by far the largest, although perhaps not the brightest. Its yellow light illuminates the throne dais, which contains the three wooden thrones of state, arrange in a loose arc. In the best of times, these thrones would hold the reigning monarch, their spouse, and their named heir. Today, and presumably throughout this epoch, only one throne is occupied. It would be assumed that the monarch would sit in the central throne, but this is not the case, and instead the Boy-King sits in the left-hand throne, that of the named heir, slouching and leaning in that way common to most teenagers, despite that the Boy-King is in fact 17 years old, and shortly to come of age.</p><p>He is dressed not in the regal clothes of state, but in fashionable but sombre mourning robes - still, after all this time, missing his mother.</p><p>""Sir Ian Grenville,"" he shouts, from the other side of the room. The sound echoes around for a few moments, then is deadened by the thick curtains. ""It amuses me that, unlike the other snivelling courtiers, you arrive exactly at the hour of summoning, and not before. For this, you have my thanks.""</p><p>He claps twice, and figures step forward from the shadows - the royal guardsmen. Standing tall in their ceremonial armour, clasping pikes, they step into the central aisle of the room, turn towards the door, and march out in synchronous time. A few other figures, for the most part servants, join the parade at the back. The guardsmen look forth, through and past Sir Ian, as they go by; the servants look down, not meeting his eye. Only one, a woman in a dark cloak, looks up as she passes. Was that a smile, a smirk? It's hard to tell in the gloom.</p><p>""Step forth, Sir Ian,"" the Boy-King says, more quietly, as the heavy doors slam shut behind him. ""Come hither, and tell me why Dunmouth should spare you the indignity of trial.""</p>

From the corner of his eye, Sir Ian watches the young king's courtiers depart. How should he respond to Brynn-av-Alice's challenge?  Not that the true culprit in the embezzlement was the matronly Lady Wilhelmina Grives. Such a tale might serve to impeach her testimony in a court of law, but was not tuned to please the ear of a boy-- a young man, Ian supposes-- still awkwardly mourning the death of his mother. No, it would have to be something else. But what?

Grenville slowly approaches the dais, making a show of straightening one gilded cuff. Speak, man, he urges himself. Chin up and speak. Any courtier worth his snuff could give a reason why his own dignity should not be besmirched. 

Ian would give the child two. 

""Two reasons, your majesty,"" he says. Sir Ian raises his head high enough to look down his rather prominent nose at the lounging monarch. ""First, because I have committed no crime. If I have drained the jeweled goblet of the Queen's Haven Charitable Society, it was only in order to fill the humble cup of the Eastland refugees. That is more, I fear, than can be said for many of my fellow directors, who are concerned mainly to add more jewels to the goblet. But all this by the by. Second--""

The second reason. The second reason--

Images flash before Grenville's frantic mind: the Red Mountain banner hung close by the throne; the cloaked lady, smiling as she passes; Brynn and Ian alone, in the first private audience ever granted to him despite years of service to the crown. 

Sir Ian delicately clears his throat. ""Second,"" he proceeds, feeling his way, ""if it should chance that your majesty has an... interest, in the Eastern tribesfolk who now dwell among us, there is no one better positioned to be informative and useful to the crown than I. Nor anyone, I may add, with more fruitful and-- for lack of a better term, varied-- connections in Queen's Haven.""

A dangerous game, this. Ian forces himself to inhale and exhale slowly, to meet the boy king's eyes without fear in his own.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>From the corner of his eye, Sir Ian watches the young king's courtiers depart. How should he respond to Brynn-av-Alice's challenge?  Not that the true culprit in the embezzlement was the matronly Lady Wilhelmina Grives. Such a tale might serve to impeach her testimony in a court of law, but was not tuned to please the ear of a boy-- a young man, Ian supposes-- still awkwardly mourning the death of his mother. No, it would have to be something else. But what?</p><p>Grenville slowly approaches the dais, making a show of straightening one gilded cuff. <em>Speak, man, </em>he urges himself. <em>Chin up and speak. </em>Any courtier worth his snuff could give a reason why his own dignity should not be besmirched. </p><p>Ian would give the child two. </p><p>""Two reasons, your majesty,"" he says. Sir Ian raises his head high enough to look down his rather prominent nose at the lounging monarch. ""First, because I have committed no crime. If I have drained the jeweled goblet of the Queen's Haven Charitable Society, it was only in order to fill the humble cup of the Eastland refugees. That is more, I fear, than can be said for many of my fellow directors, who are concerned mainly to add more jewels to the goblet. But all this by the by. Second--""</p><p><em>The second reason. The second reason--</em></p><p>Images flash before Grenville's frantic mind: the Red Mountain banner hung close by the throne; the cloaked lady, smiling as she passes; Brynn and Ian alone, in the first private audience ever granted to him despite years of service to the crown. </p><p>Sir Ian delicately clears his throat. ""Second,"" he proceeds, feeling his way, ""if it should chance that your majesty has an... interest, in the Eastern tribesfolk who now dwell among us, there is no one better positioned to be informative and useful to the crown than I. Nor anyone, I may add, with more fruitful and-- for lack of a better term, varied-- connections in Queen's Haven.""</p><p>A dangerous game, this. Ian forces himself to inhale and exhale slowly, to meet the boy king's eyes without fear in his own. </p>

Brynn waves his left hand dismissively as the man before him outlines his first excuse; with the second, he narrows his eyes, and his other hand grips the armrest of his throne more tightly.

""You,"" he says, with a little mirth, a little malice. ""You dain to wonder what the interests of a king might be? What might be my concerns, my follies, my worries? I,"" he repeats, jabbing his left forefinger down on its respective armrest. ""I am concerned for the wellbeing of my court, my city, my country. And that my mother's memory is preserved.""

An odd point to make - quite a juxtaposition from the others. Balancing the memory of one dead monarch with the future preservation of the people and politicians of the entire kingdom. Perhaps in the eyes of the Boy-King, the two issues are entwined, but it is not how the threatened populous feel.

""I am not concerned with the particulars of your trial, Sir Grenville. You can be royally excused - did you know that? - on whatever grounds I see fit."" Brynn is clearly agitated, and annoyed, but the reason isn't entirely clear. ""You are right, I suppose, in that I am interested in the Eastern tribesfolk. And you are correct that I have summoned you here as one with particular knowledge and experience. I understand you were a colonial agent in the Red Mountains, and of course your position now is well-known - and appreciated by - the court and myself.""

""I would greatly value your insight and advice, Sir Ian Grenville, but I cannot employ you if you are imprisoned, innocent or otherwise. And whilst I do have the power to excuse you, the Regent has a right of veto. So, you see, you would have to be working towards an aim which the Court would find acceptable.""

""Let me be candid with you, Sir Grenville - and should any of this reach external ears, yours shall be removed."" This threat of gruesome violence is rather glossed over as the boy-king continues at full pelt. ""The Regent does not see me as a suitable monarch, child or not. Tradition states that I would reach the age of majority at 16, but this was bypassed, and now I must wait until I am 18 to rule. I have no reason to believe, and plenty of hearsay to imply, that they will delay this further, until I am 21. What's to say they do not castrate me further, and deny me the right to rule until I am 25, 30, one hundred years old?""

Brynn maintains a cool composure, but his voice is quaking with barely restrained anger. ""This is unacceptable, Sir Grenville, and it snubs my mother, who is not here to defend herself. She would not see her heir treated like this. And so, little pawn, you and I must hatch a cunning plan. How can we make the regent see that I am an adult and a suitable monarch who must be treated with respect?""

The question hangs in the air like a poison dart.

And so, little pawn, you and I must hatch a cunning plan. How can we make the regent see that I am an adult and a suitable monarch who must be treated with respect?""</p><p>The question hangs in the air like a poison dart.</p>

Contemplating the young king's challenge, Ian is reminded of an adage he learned from his fellow colonial officers in the Red Mountains.  A clock has many moving parts; a dagger none. Simple violence has few points of failure.  The natives might accuse the Dawn Regiment of brutality when a thief's hand was crushed by a hammer, or when one of the Red Folk's more vocal medicine women disappeared only to turn up as a battered corpse between the corn rows.  But there was very little theft in colonial Eastland.  And the malcontents were careful to whisper.

If the Lord Regent stood between Brynn-av-Alice and genuine rule, then the direct course would be through the Regent's gut.  A dead man wields no veto.  But surely this option would have occurred to Brynn, and the Lord Regent-- whether through the boy king's fear, principle or self-restraint-- still drew breath.  It would be capital treason for Sir Ian even to voice such a suggestion.  Did he dare place himself so entirely in this child's trembling hands?

Such dark thoughts play across Grenville's features: a sullen brow, followed by a pained wrinkling of the nose.  He turns away from the dais and paces the room, hands clasped behind his waist, his trim body mirrored in marble.  No, he would not suggest an assassination.  Ian had already thrown the dice once in this interview; to do so again, and at such high stakes, would be madness.

Brynn-av-Alice wasn't a killer, however he might fancy himself.  Ian is reminded of the Dunmothians who came to the Red Mountains on holiday, imagining themselves to be great hunters.  Grenville would have the natives trap and hobble some bear or mountain cat, then drive the poor creature down to the hunting party so that the visiting dignitaries could enjoy all the thrill of the kill with none of the danger.  That's what the boy king needs: a guaranteed victory, with no personal risk.

""If your majesty will indulge me,"" Ian says, speaking slowly and pacing as he speaks.  ""What you require is a signal triumph of policy, one where your view carries the day against the Lord Regent's advice and before all the world.""  Sir Ian pauses, spreads his palms parallel to the floor as if preparing to play the invisible instrument of state.

""I will withdraw from the board of the Queen's Haven Charitable Society during the pendency of my trial.  I shall have it reported that this was at the private request of the Lord Regent; he may deny it if he likes, but the scribblers will scribble and the talkers will talk.  Meanwhile, do you let it be known that you oppose my removal from the board, and suspect some mischief in the whole legal proceeding against me.""

Grenville flexes and spreads his fingers over the phantom keys of his machination.  ""I have... reason to believe, that once I am down there will be unrest in Queen's Haven and the neighboring boroughs.""  His 'friends' among the Eastlanders will make it so, or so Ian prays.  ""Acts of vandalism, a few of violence.  Defacements of property, with scrawls against the crown and mutterings upon government's miserliness towards the poor refugees.""

""Here your majesty emerges once more,"" Ian declares, wheeling back sharply to face the thrones.  He seeks and holds the young monarch's gaze, his own bright with the assumed excitement of this moment.  ""You deride the Charitable Society for its corruption and mismanagement, and the unrest they have fomented.  You declare that I am free of the charges falsely leveled against me by these venal and self-dealing persons.  At a stroke, you dissolve the board-- as you may, for the society exists under a charter granted by your royal mother of late memory.  In its place, you install your good servant-- myself-- as sole director.""

Ian allows himself the twitch of a smile.

""Henceforward the floodgates of civic generosity are opened.  The Charitable Society performs signal good works among the refugee community.  The unrest, I make bold to assure you, vanishes as if it never was. And all credit for having put down this burgeoning calamity in Dunmouth goes to your majesty's wisdom alone, in defiance of the bad advice and guidance of the Lord Regent.""

Grenville draws a deep breath after his speech.  ""After such a public victory, the Lord Regent would be hard pressed to veto a declaration of your majesty's majority,"" he concludes.  Standing once more before the king's dais, Ian studies the boy's expression for his reaction.
dice roll

a dagger none.</em> Simple violence has few points of failure.  The natives might accuse the Dawn Regiment of brutality when a thief's hand was crushed by a hammer, or when one of the Red Folk's more vocal medicine women disappeared only to turn up as a battered corpse between the corn rows.  But there was very little theft in colonial Eastland.  And the malcontents were careful to whisper.</p><p>If the Lord Regent stood between Brynn-av-Alice and genuine rule, then the direct course would be through the Regent's gut.  A dead man wields no veto.  But surely this option would have occurred to Brynn, and the Lord Regent-- whether through the boy king's fear, principle or self-restraint-- still drew breath.  It would be capital treason for Sir Ian even to voice such a suggestion.  Did he dare place himself so entirely in this child's trembling hands?</p><p>Such dark thoughts play across Grenville's features: a sullen brow, followed by a pained wrinkling of the nose.  He turns away from the dais and paces the room, hands clasped behind his waist, his trim body mirrored in marble.  No, he would not suggest an assassination.  Ian had already thrown the dice once in this interview; to do so again, and at such high stakes, would be madness.</p><p>Brynn-av-Alice wasn't a killer, however he might fancy himself.  Ian is reminded of the Dunmothians who came to the Red Mountains on holiday, imagining themselves to be great hunters.  Grenville would have the natives trap and hobble some bear or mountain cat, then drive the poor creature down to the hunting party so that the visiting dignitaries could enjoy all the thrill of the kill with none of the danger.  That's what the boy king needs: a guaranteed victory, with no personal risk.</p><p>""If your majesty will indulge me,"" Ian says, speaking slowly and pacing as he speaks.  ""What you require is a signal triumph of policy, one where your view carries the day against the Lord Regent's advice and before all the world.""  Sir Ian pauses, spreads his palms parallel to the floor as if preparing to play the invisible instrument of state.</p><p>""I will withdraw from the board of the Queen's Haven Charitable Society during the pendency of my trial.  I shall have it reported that this was at the private request of the Lord Regent; he may deny it if he likes, but the scribblers will scribble and the talkers will talk.  Meanwhile, do you let it be known that you oppose my removal from the board, and suspect some mischief in the whole legal proceeding against me.""</p><p>Grenville flexes and spreads his fingers over the phantom keys of his machination.  ""I have... reason to believe, that once I am down there will be unrest in Queen's Haven and the neighboring boroughs.""  His 'friends' among the Eastlanders will make it so, or so Ian prays.  ""Acts of vandalism, a few of violence.  Defacements of property, with scrawls against the crown and mutterings upon government's miserliness towards the poor refugees.""</p><p>""Here your majesty emerges once more,"" Ian declares, wheeling back sharply to face the thrones.  He seeks and holds the young monarch's gaze, his own bright with the assumed excitement of this moment.  ""You deride the Charitable Society for its corruption and mismanagement, and the unrest they have fomented.  You declare that I am free of the charges falsely leveled against me by these venal and self-dealing persons.  At a stroke, you dissolve the board-- as you may, for the society exists under a charter granted by your royal mother of late memory.  In its place, you install your good servant-- myself-- as sole director.""</p><p>Ian allows himself the twitch of a smile.</p><p>""Henceforward the floodgates of civic generosity are opened.  The Charitable Society performs signal good works among the refugee community.  The unrest, I make bold to assure you, vanishes as if it never was. And all credit for having put down this burgeoning calamity in Dunmouth goes to your majesty's wisdom alone, in defiance of the bad advice and guidance of the Lord Regent.""</p><p>Grenville draws a deep breath after his speech.  ""After such a public victory, the Lord Regent would be hard pressed to veto a declaration of your majesty's majority,"" he concludes.  Standing once more before the king's dais, Ian studies the boy's expression for his reaction.</p>

For a moment, King Brynn's eyes brighten with the scene that Ian has painted for him.  He straightens and leans forward in his throne.  He seems almost ready to smile.

And for that moment-- fragile and iridescent as a bubble floating on the scum of the Dun river-- Sir Ian Grenville allows himself to hope.

Then the bubble bursts.

The boy king's nascent smile twitches into a smirk.  Ian can see him going back over all that Ian has said, with the deep skepticism of a child who has spent most of his life as a political plaything.  Sifting Grenville's proposal for the holes, the angles, the things left unsaid.  Soon enough, he finds what he's looking for.

""So,"" Brynn drawls.  ""My path to glory is to make you, Sir Ian, sole master of the crown's charity in Queen's Haven?""

Ian holds his breath an instant too long before answering.  ""Only so that I might--""

Brynn-av-Alice forestalls him with a regal palm.  ""No, sirrah, let me answer.  'Only so that I might better serve your majesty.'"" Brynn's voice drips faux sincerity.  ""'This power, your majesty, this office, this preferment, is to be placed entirely at your disposal.  Not for myself-- not for myself, your majesty-- do I take up this honor, but for you.'""

Ian grits his teeth.

""Do you think me dense, Ian Grenville?"" the monarch snaps.  ""Do you think that I have lived from my birth amongst hangers-on like yourself, amongst vines that entwine the royal trunk only so that they may climb to the light, and cannot feel their coils?""  His voice rises with each sentence, bounding back from the distant, marble walls.  ""You would dare to use me-- to use me-- in settling your own scores, putting down your own rivals?!  Have I shown you some, some--- weakness that you make bold to exploit?""

This last thought seems to infuriate the youth; the muscles around his mouth spasm, and his knuckles whiten on the arm of his throne.  ""No sir,"" Brynn-av-Alice spits.  ""No.  You claim that you will be the scalpel to cut out a cancer in Queen's Haven; but you are the cancer, Grenville.  And I will cut you out.""

The king draws a shuddering breath, then plunges on, ""Henceforth you are removed from the board of the Queen's Haven Charitable Society.  Do not think to show your face there, and do not dream to show it here at court.  I will see you tried to fullest extent of the law, sir, and when you are convicted for your embezzlement-- I say when, and not if-- I will make certain that you are tossed deep into Ditchbend Prison.  You will not see the light of day again until you are far grayer than you already are.  Queen's Haven will prosper in spite of you, not because of you.  Let that be my triumph, and my recommendation to the Lord Regent.""

""Now go,"" Brynn declares, uncoiling a finger to point at the distant door.  ""Place your affairs in order.  Reconcile yourself to the dishonor that is coming for you.  Your banners are down, Grenville.  They are down utterly.""

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-280986""><div class=""row"">

Naked save a piece of sheer silk wrapped partly around her body, fluttering in the wind, Ayesha Williams stood proudly on a mountaintop, chill, clean air filling her lungs and caressing her skin. The clarity before her eyes was like nothing she had ever seen. It was staggering, literally breathtaking. She could see every crease in every mountainside, every needle on every tree, every track left in the snow, every particle carried on the wind. It was like there was a hundred mile wide tapestry being woven in front of her, and she could set every thread moving in magnificent concert, winding with others, moving independently, moving in unison.

She did not understand, but she was -- perhaps for the first time in her life -- awake.

Dawn was breaking as the Victorious Talon sliced through the air at frightening speed, propelled by its transverse magnetic field generator and its fusion core engines, and by alien technology that had recently been incorporated into the ship. That same technology had effected repairs in a remarkably short period of time, and the ship not only no longer listed, but had full power restored to its weapons and defense fields. She was a fighting ship to be reckoned with, and had gotten her second wind.

Tilottama sat at the heart of the huge vessel, bonded with it, literally fused with its metals and alloys. She was silent, inert, but conscious in her way, communicating with her friends and the crew in subtle but unmistakable ways. Despite fears that petty human concerns might bore the gorgeous alien and drive her from the planet, or that Jia would dissect her, Tilo had not abandoned the cause just yet.

Dang Jia had not been displeased at the result of the pairing, and had tripled her damage control teams in an effort to keep up with the alien's progress. She stood on the bridge now, back in her armor, flanked on either side by her sister and the leader of the Aegisean field team, Nano Girl. All three were discussing the strategy that had come together in an all-night planning session... a strategy that would try to split the attention of Fzercole and his powerful Generals. Tu would infiltrate, incite the populace and attack the city by land; Jia and the Talon would busy Dang Shui's defenses and press the attack on Dang's palace itself.  A third team would attempt to free Chao and others from the prison beneath the palace, but as the trio discussed who was best suited for that mission, Physician Ling, who had been charged with monitoring Sublime's condition, rushed up the stairs to the bridge.

""She's awake!"" he exclaimed as the unlikely trio turned to look at him.

""Has she evolved?"" Jia asked squarely, doubt thick in her voice.

""You... should come and see for yourself, your Eminence,"" Ling said, hesitating a beat before turning to head back down the stairs.

Liz moved before Jia could, half a step behind Dr. Ling as he sprinted back to his patent. She didn’t say a word, the grim expression on her face speaking volumes for her.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Liz moved before Jia could, half a step behind Dr. Ling as he sprinted back to his patent. She didn’t say a word, the grim expression on her face speaking volumes for her.</p>

The night had been quite something. After talking with Captain Stone for a time (a gloriously non-combat filled time), she had been summoned to the War Room, with Jia and Liz already at odds about their tactics when they got to Dang Shui—and what was an ""acceptable"" loss of life. Needless to say, there was a wide spectrum between their views on that one, from Liz's (basically none) to Jia's (basically everyone, up to and including most of her family). 

Once they'd been able to sort that one out, things went surprisingly well. Jia seemed surprised at Liz's quick grasp of the tactics in play. And Tu and Jia had always worked well together, like dagger in glove, when Jia's pettiness and jealousy hadn't gotten the better of her. 

Many hours and cups of green tea later, they had come to a chimera of a plan—many-headed, devious, and with some attempt to save life rather than simply end it all. 

Tu still wasn't sure how to feel about her part in this. Jia had told her, thin-lipped about the Children of the Swan, the ""idiots who had been inspired by your insubordination and ill regard for their betters"", in Jia's own words. A rebel movement had been the last thing on her mind when she had escaped, and she felt a little guilty for what was almost certainly a harsh punishment for anyone caught in such an uprising. 

Still, for now, it could work in their favour—a rebel movement would have the structures in place that they needed right now, even if the rulers were a little different. And afterwards, she could see about taking as many of her 'children' with her as she could.

With Physician Ling's news, she looked up sharply but did not follow Little Girl. She wanted to see her friend, but her tactical mind also knew she couldn't help on that battlefield. If Sublime was well, she would see her soon enough. 

Instead, she turned back to the maps of Dang Shui, memorising streets, alleys, entry points, sewers, anything that might give them an advantage in the fight to come.

Needless to say, there was a wide spectrum between their views on that one, from Liz's (basically none) to Jia's (basically everyone, up to and including most of her family). </p><p>Once they'd been able to sort that one out, things went surprisingly well. Jia seemed surprised at Liz's quick grasp of the tactics in play. And Tu and Jia had always worked <em>well</em> together, like dagger in glove, when Jia's pettiness and jealousy hadn't gotten the better of her. </p><p>Many hours and cups of green tea later, they had come to a chimera of a plan—many-headed, devious, and with some attempt to <em>save</em> life rather than simply end it all. </p><p>Tu still wasn't sure how to feel about her part in this. Jia had told her, thin-lipped about the <em>Children of the Swan</em>, the ""idiots who had been inspired by your insubordination and ill regard for their betters"", in Jia's own words. A rebel movement had been the last thing on her mind when she had escaped, and she felt a little guilty for what was almost certainly a harsh punishment for anyone caught in such an uprising. </p><p>Still, for now, it could work in their favour—a rebel movement would have the structures in place that they <em>needed </em>right now, even if the rulers were a little different. And afterwards, she could see about taking as many of her 'children' with her as she could.</p><p>With Physician Ling's news, she looked up sharply but did not follow Little Girl. She wanted to see her friend, but her tactical mind also knew she couldn't help on that battlefield. If Sublime was well, she would see her soon enough. </p><p>Instead, she turned back to the maps of Dang Shui, memorising streets, alleys, entry points, sewers, anything that might give them an advantage in the fight to come.</p>

""Your new companions lack conviction. Lack decisiveness,"" Dang Jia said to her sister when Nano Girl slipped away after Physician Ling. ""The one, the alien -- she is useful. The others, I wonder about your judgment, sister."" Noticing that Tu was pouring over virtual maps of the city and its surroundings, ignoring her, the imperious princess changed topics, knowing that the graceful Swan wasn't going to rise to her bait.

""Are you looking forward to returning home?"" she instead asked.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""Your new companions lack conviction. Lack decisiveness,""</span> Dang Jia said to her sister when Nano Girl slipped away after Physician Ling. <span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""The one, the alien -- she is useful. The others, I wonder about your judgment, sister.""</span> Noticing that Tu was pouring over virtual maps of the city and its surroundings, ignoring her, the imperious princess changed topics, knowing that the graceful Swan wasn't going to rise to her bait.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""Are you looking forward to returning home?"" </span>she instead asked.</p>

Tu was deep in her own memory palace, ironically, modeled on Dang's own literal palace. The general structures of Dang Shui looked the same but quite a lot had changed under the surface—some of it presumably in response to her escape. 

Dang's penchant for remodelling was akin to a bored millionaire housewife, albeit with a lot more slavery. He had once famously demolished and rebuilt a nearby skyscraper so that his garden would get more light. 

""<... and on Lotus Way, this alley connects to Enlightenment Tower ...>"" she murmured, folding the mental images into waypoints on her mental map. There was a kind of comfort to this, a rhythm and repetition, an immersion into her own mind, and an excursion into the geography of another place. A relief to be away from—

""Are you looking forward to returning home?"" Jia interjected, in a tone that purposefully derailed her mental train of thought. A peevish tone that would have been amusing in a five year old, somewhat less so in a megalomaniac genius. 

Tu sighed, and straightened her back. Jia was always looking to spar, in one way or another. 

""I'm not going home. Dang Shui has never been my home, in any real sense of the word."" 

Jia opened her mouth, probably to say words like ungrateful, slattern, or traitor. Tu kept on going. 

""The question you should ask is if it has ever really been your home. Whether anyone there has ever treated you with any welcome. Anything other than disdain.

""You could do almost anything in this world, dear sister. Why do you use your life to fight a battle for affection that you can never win?

""When all this is done—why don't you come with me, and see what a home actually is.""

The general structures of Dang Shui looked the same but quite a lot had changed under the surface—some of it presumably in response to her escape. </p><p>Dang's penchant for remodelling was akin to a bored millionaire housewife, albeit with a lot more slavery. He had once famously demolished and rebuilt a nearby skyscraper so that his garden would get more light. </p><p>""<... and on Lotus Way, this alley connects to Enlightenment Tower ...>"" she murmured, folding the mental images into waypoints on her mental map. There was a kind of comfort to this, a rhythm and repetition, an immersion into her own mind, and an excursion into the geography of another place. A relief to be away from—</p><p>""Are you looking forward to returning home?"" Jia interjected, in a tone that purposefully derailed her mental train of thought. A peevish tone that would have been amusing in a five year old, somewhat less so in a megalomaniac genius. </p><p>Tu sighed, and straightened her back. Jia was always looking to spar, in one way or another. </p><p>""I'm not going home. Dang Shui has never been my home, in any real sense of the word."" </p><p>Jia opened her mouth, probably to say words like ungrateful, slattern, or traitor. Tu kept on going. </p><p>""The question you should ask is if it has ever really been your home. Whether anyone there has ever treated you with any welcome. Anything other than disdain.</p><p>""You could do almost anything in this world, dear sister. Why do you use your life to fight a battle for affection that you can never win?</p><p>""When all this is done—why don't you come with me, and see what a home actually is."" </p>

Indeed, Jia's vitriolic response died on her lips as her sister didn't allow her to interrupt, and her mouth closed slowly as Tu's words sank in, to the bone. A twitch at the corner of one eye, an expression that came unbidden to Jia's face -- it was plain for the Swan to see that she had drawn blood as surely as if she'd plunged a dagger into the woman's chest.

Unclenching one armored fist, Jia encircled the two women on the bridge in a wavering sphere of silence, a globe that blocked all sound moving inside or out of its confines. The Emperor's daughter's voice sounded strange when she spoke, like it was both muffled and too close somehow, amplified and slightly distorted.

""What do you know of my plight?"" she asked through perfect teeth that were almost bared. ""You and the other eight. You all have your purpose. My brother has his purpose. Only I stand apart -- only I have to earn my place. And so I shall. Father will see, one day, he will. He will understand that only I am able to carry his legacy forward.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Indeed, Jia's vitriolic response died on her lips as her sister didn't allow her to interrupt, and her mouth closed slowly as Tu's words sank in, to the bone. A twitch at the corner of one eye, an expression that came unbidden to Jia's face -- it was plain for the Swan to see that she had drawn blood as surely as if she'd plunged a dagger into the woman's chest.</p><p>Unclenching one armored fist, Jia encircled the two women on the bridge in a wavering sphere of silence, a globe that blocked all sound moving inside or out of its confines. The Emperor's daughter's voice sounded strange when she spoke, like it was both muffled and too close somehow, amplified and slightly distorted.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""What do you know of my plight?""</span> she asked through perfect teeth that were almost bared. <span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""You and the other eight. You all have your purpose. My <em>brother</em> has his purpose. Only I stand apart -- only I have to <em>earn</em> my place. And so I shall. Father will see, one day, he will. He will understand that only <em>I</em> am able to carry his legacy forward.""</span></p>

Where did you even start? Tu knew this fight—a fight where she was trying to turn Jia against her own monolithic ego, her sense of her destiny, against every half-life and distorted truth that Father had instilled in them since birth—was probably not a fight that she could win. But an uneven fight had never stopped her from fighting.

Tu responded, not in kind, but with a near-unnatural calmness that projected from her physical bearing, and radiated out from her, through her pheremonic field: ""Firstly, I know your plight better than just about anyone else in the world. In case you forgot. Secondly, you're a scientist, Jia. If your hypothesis is that Father will 'understand', and yet your previous experiments have all failed to prove it, where does that leave you? Will you repeat it again and again until you die? 

""Or begin something new—a legacy of your own, away from Father's poisonous shadow?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Where did you even start? Tu knew this fight—a fight where she was trying to turn Jia against her own monolithic ego, her sense of her <em>destiny</em>, against every half-life and distorted truth that Father had instilled in them since birth—was probably not a fight that she could win. But an uneven fight had never stopped her from fighting.</p><p>Tu responded, not in kind, but with a near-unnatural calmness that projected from her physical bearing, and radiated out from her, through her pheremonic field: ""Firstly, I know your plight better than just about anyone else in the world. In case you forgot. Secondly, you're a <em>scientist, </em>Jia. If your hypothesis is that Father will 'understand', and yet your previous experiments have all failed to prove it, where does that leave you? Will you repeat it again and again until you die? </p><p>""Or begin something new—a legacy of your own, away from Father's poisonous shadow?"" </p>

Maintaining the shimmering sphere of solitude, Jia considered the Dragon's words carefully. Somewhere in her black heart, she knew they were as true as any arrow loosed by the Viper... that no matter what she did, she would never, ever win her father's approval. Not truly. Tu Wei was right -- Dang Jia already had a list of accomplishments filling heavy tomes in the Great Library... what more could she possibly do to sway the Emperor?

Her eyes narrowed. What more, other than saving all of Dang Shui, than driving off invaders who had somehow deposed the great Patriarch? This -- this decisive action they were now undertaking -- this would be her redemption, her opportunity to finally ascend to her rightful place.

""You are right, sister,"" the dark-haired woman said with a slight smile. ""I have been throwing myself against this iron wall for years, expecting other than blood and broken bones. You are right -- the time has come for me to write my own story... to step out from the shade of the man who made us all, and found us all lacking."" She turned away for a moment, but her smile did not fade. When she turned back, her eyes were lit with ambition.

""What will you do when this is over? You are the Uncharted Map. Your destiny is unwritten. Will you join me in shaping a new world? A world where we forge what is to come?""

Something felt off balance, askew. Like throwing a strike and having the target move away rather than meet with resistance. 

This was what she had wanted Jia to say ... wasn't it? 

""<Assuming that we get there alive, assuming that our family isn't all dead, assuming there is some way out of this mess>,"" Tu had switched abruptly to their native tongue, the harsh edge of the syllables crackling a little in the vagaries of the field. ""<Assuming that we can defeat these intruders with minimal loss of life, assuming that Father will even let me go at the end of all of this ...>"" 

She looked her sister hard in the face, brown eyes meeting brown, heart to heart. 

Then in English: ""I'll do what I've done since I was born, Jia. I'll keep fighting for what is righteous. I will gladly fight with you, if we are fighting for the same cause.""

<""Our cause will be righteous, Dragon, have no doubt of that."">

Abruptly, the privacy field was gone, whisked away with a swipe of one of Jia's guantlets. ""And you are right, sister. There is much to do before we can concern ourselves with our great game of Xaingqi. You do not need to answer now, Tu. Once our enemies have been driven out of Dang Shui, our path will be clear.""

Ling lead Nanogirl deckside, wordlessly gesturing up at the
to one of the antennae that craned gracefully up into the sky, clad
only in a white sheet from the infirmary bed, loosely knotted around
her like a college student's attempt at a toga. As the airborne
warship crashed through the clouds like billowing waves she had
become quite soaked by the damp air, and her skin goosebumped from
the cold. Yet her expression was... dreamy, transported, almost
delirious as she surveyed the skyscape like she was the figurehead of the
ship, keeping it from hazardous shoals.

only in a white sheet from the infirmary bed, loosely knotted around

delirious as she surveyed the skyscape like she was the figurehead of the
ship, keeping it from hazardous shoals.<br></p>

It took a moment to adjust, Liz’s eyes fighting the sudden brightness of being outside after hours stuck inside of the dimly lit corridor’s of Jia’s floating battleship. When she saw the brilliant white of Sublime’s billowing... toga... she mistook it for just another fluctuation of her eyes, before realizing what she was truly seeing before her.

“Ayesha?” she asked, cautiously.

She cursed herself for taking off her grapple gauntlet with its focused gravity field generator. Suddenly, it felt very useful.

Liz raised her voice. “Ayesha... can you hear me?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>It took a moment to adjust, Liz’s eyes fighting the sudden brightness of being outside after hours stuck inside of the dimly lit corridor’s of Jia’s floating battleship. When she saw the brilliant white of Sublime’s billowing... toga... she mistook it for just another fluctuation of her eyes, before realizing what she was truly seeing before her.</p><p>“Ayesha?” she asked, cautiously.</p><p>She cursed herself for taking off her grapple gauntlet with its focused gravity field generator. Suddenly, it felt very useful.</p><p>Liz raised her voice. “Ayesha... can you hear me?”</p>

Sometime during her evolutionary fever dream Ayesha's hair had come loose from most of the braids it had been woven into, and she now sported a dark, damp, frizzy cloud around her slack and faintly smiling face. At the sound of Liz's voice she looked down, hanging loosely from the metal pylon at arm's length, bare feet perched on the edge of the superstructure tower roof.

“Nano Girl! You look so small down there.” Ayesha giggled – Liz had certainly never heard her do that before. “Of course, you look so small everywhere.”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Sometime during her evolutionary fever dream Ayesha's hair had come loose from most of the braids it had been woven into, and she now sported a dark, damp, frizzy cloud around her slack and faintly smiling face. You look so small down there.”</strong></span> Ayesha giggled – Liz had certainly never heard her do that before. <span style=""color: rgb(155, 187, 89);""></span><strong><span style=""color: rgb(155, 187, 89);""><span style=""color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"">“Of course, you look so small everywhere.”</span></span></strong></p>

Liz’s look of concern, all furrowed brow and twisted lip, began to thaw at hearing Ayesha’s voice, eventually melting into a genuine, if bemused smile.

“Yeah... looking small is kind of my thing,” she answered, amused, but then suddenly she became serious again. Her friend looked different, weightless in a way, but Liz knew from her medical training that the kind of elation Ayesha displayed could be dangerous, perhaps a symtopm of a hidden danger, some invisible wound. “I think our hosts are a little concerned about having you up there, Ayesha. Especially after what you did to the Longfang. Why don’t you come down here so we can talk? Gently, I mean. Why don’t you come down here slowly, so we don’t panic anyone. Okay?”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Liz’s look of concern, all furrowed brow and twisted lip, began to thaw at hearing Ayesha’s voice, eventually melting into a genuine, if bemused smile.</p><p>“Yeah... looking small is kind of my <em>thing</em>,” she answered, amused, but then suddenly she became serious again. Her friend looked different, weightless in a way, but Liz knew from her medical training that the kind of elation Ayesha displayed could be dangerous, perhaps a symtopm of a hidden danger, some invisible wound. “I think our hosts are a little concerned about having you up there, Ayesha. Especially after what you did to the Longfang. Why don’t you come down here so we can talk? Gently, I mean. Why don’t you come down here slowly, so we don’t panic anyone. Okay?”</p>

“The Longfang? Looong. Faaaang,” Ayesha repeated in a sing-song voice. “I fell through it. Blip. Blop. Like a balloon. All the air went out and all the people went down with the ship.” A flicker of a darker emotion crossed her face, leaving her brow creased. “Okay. I'm coming down!”

Her expression calming, Ayesha relaxed her hold on the antenna tower, throwing herself into a swan dive towards the deck.

Tu and Jia watched with knit brows as the one-time density controller plummeted past the command deck, bare-assed and streaming what looked like a long white cape behind her.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>When Ling showed Nano Girl the fix her teammate had gotten herself into, high above the heavily armored and <em>very hard</em> deck, he was able to say, <span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0);"">""The last readings we had on her showed that she is healthy, but powerless,""</span> just as Ayesha jumped.</p><p>Tu and Jia watched with knit brows as the one-time density controller plummeted past the command deck, bare-assed and streaming what looked like a long white cape behind her.</p>

Time slowed.

Elizabeth heard the sound of Ayesha’s makeshift toga snapping in the wind. She heard Dr. Ling mutter something in a tongue she couldn’t yet understand. She heard the faint fluttering of the Talon’s otherworldly drives cutting and swimming through gravitrons, then she heard a sharp inhalation of air, a shocked gasp, and was stunned by the realization that it was her own.

“Ayesha!” she cried out.

But, it was too late. She reached out, instinctually reaching for Ayesha with her open hand, surprised that her gauntlet wasn’t there to help her stop her friend’s fall, her fingers empty, just filled with the air that did little to slow her friend’s fall..

“No!”

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Time slowed.</p><p>Elizabeth heard the sound of Ayesha’s makeshift toga snapping in the wind. She heard Dr. Ling mutter something in a tongue she couldn’t yet understand. She reached out, instinctually reaching for Ayesha with her open hand, surprised that her gauntlet wasn’t there to help her stop her friend’s fall, her fingers empty, just filled with the air that did little to slow her friend’s fall..</p><p>“No!”</p>
Time was at a standstill, frozen before Liz's eyes, Ayesha
falling scarcely an inch as the diminutive woman watched in horror, hand
outstretched to her. Her mind flooded with adrenaline, and therefore, simple
instinct, fight or flight or maybe something else eradicating her otherwise
logical mind in the raw burst of simple impulse.
Her logical mind wouldn't think to reduce her own size. It
made no sense, but blasted with a shaking, electric need to do something, she
drew upon her inner, mysterious workings and began to collapse inside of
herself, the distance between her outstretched hand and friend growing.
Realizing her mistake, even on an instinctual level, she reversed her change in
size, growing back to her normal size again. Then, still desperate, still
irrational, she began to shrink again.
Liz had been an only child, the sole daughter of Andrew and
Patsy Weiss. It was a misconception that a ""loner"" chose a life of solitude.
Sometimes it just worked out that way. Sometimes circumstances pushed a person
in one direction or another, the life of the party or the quiet observer of
that same celebration. It wasn't a role that bothered her, not one that weighed
on her shoulders, but something inside of her had started to move after her
encounter with the Wind Wizard, shift towards something different than her
She hadn't thought about Wind Wizard for years, probably
more than a decade, but finding him broken in the rubble of the shattered
super-prison had changed something within her. She hated the idea that someone
who meant something to her could simply disappear. Ayesha and Liz haven't had
the time to become close, haven't been able to spend time off-the-clock in an
effort to strengthen their bond, but Ayesha was a friend, had the potential to
be a close friend. Liz wouldn't lose that. Not today.
She expanded her size again, growing to her normal size
again from her brief slip into her smaller, shrunken form, but something
happened, something strange. She stopped at her normal size, paused at her
typical 5'5"" for a moment like there was a groove there, a divot where she
caught herself for a beat, but then she continued to grow, expanding still
more, the distance between her reaching hand and Ayesha finally shrinking as
Liz's eyes widened, unsure of what was happening, but it
didn't matter. If it helped, if she could catch her friend, whatever was

In her short time with Aegis, Tu Wei had witnessed some incredible things. Assaults from invisible assassins; skyscrapers held up by her teammates; underground fortress-like prisons telekinetically pulled from the ground; one of her father's aerial dreadnoughts broken in half as it fell into the ocean... and for some inexplicable reason, none of them matched what she now witnessed for sheer element of what the!?

On the front deck of the Victorious Talon, her sister's damaged but still monstrously powerful flagship, Tu witnessed little Liz Weiss grow into a giantess and catch her plummeting friend in mid-air. Trailing her sheet behind her like a streamer in the sun, Ayesha fell right into Nano Girl's now massive hands, landing safely in her palms instead of slamming into the steel deck with what would have been an awful finality.

It was the look on Liz's face -- no one was more surprised than she was at what had transpired... but as she gazed down at her suddenly very small friend, her expression changed. Mass and surface area and air pressure interplayed, and the size-changer found herself off-balance, catching way more wind than she'd been expecting. She took one massive,slow-motion step, then another, trying to regain her balance, and just when it seemed like she was about to turn into the wind and find steady footing, the ship changed course hard to port -- sending the giantess overboard, along with her hand-held teammate.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>In her short time with Aegis, Tu Wei had witnessed some incredible things. Assaults from invisible assassins; skyscrapers held up by her teammates; underground fortress-like prisons telekinetically pulled from the ground; one of her father's aerial dreadnoughts broken in <em>half</em> as it fell into the ocean... and for some inexplicable reason, none of them matched what she now witnessed for sheer element of <em>what the!?</em></p><p>On the front deck of the <em>Victorious Talon</em>, her sister's damaged but still monstrously powerful flagship, Tu witnessed little Liz Weiss <em>grow into a giantess and catch her plummeting friend in mid-air</em>. Trailing her sheet behind her like a streamer in the sun, Ayesha fell right into Nano Girl's now massive hands, landing safely in her palms instead of slamming into the steel deck with what would have been an awful finality.</p><p>It was the <em>look</em> on Liz's face -- no one was more surprised than she was at what had transpired... but as she gazed down at her suddenly very small friend, her expression changed. Mass and surface area and air pressure interplayed, and the size-changer found herself off-balance, catching <em>way</em> more wind than she'd been expecting. She took one massive,slow-motion step, then another, trying to regain her balance, and just when it seemed like she was about to turn into the wind and find steady footing, the ship changed course hard to port -- sending the giantess overboard, along with her hand-held teammate.</p>

It was strange the way perspective could play tricks on you sometimes.

As Ayesha fell, it seemed like the deck was expanding to meet her, stretching into a gunmetal horizon. But it appeared that Nano Girl expanded even faster, even higher, stretching out of the deck like a pop-up from a children's book. Voicing a wild and wordless cry of exultant freedom, Ayesha plunged through the air, landing in a bouncy tangle in Nano Girl's gloved hand.

And then perspective was up to its old games again.

The Victorious Talon dwindled above them and the Pacific opened its sapphire arms beneath. Cold air buffeted Ayesha even as the giantess' fingers curled around her, tearing at her flimsy sheet, streaming her unbound hair, and she laughed in delight at the vision they must present: blonde King Kong clutching ebony-tressed Fay Wray, plunging from the Metro State Building to the asphalt ocean below.

“Don't worry, Nano Girl...” Ayesha screamed out, her voice somehow audible above the wind. She stretched her arms wide...

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>It was strange the way perspective could play tricks on you sometimes.</p><p>As Ayesha fell, it seemed like the deck was expanding to meet her, stretching into a gunmetal horizon. But it appeared that Nano Girl expanded even faster, even higher, stretching out of the deck like a pop-up from a children's book. Voicing a wild and wordless cry of exultant freedom, Ayesha plunged through the air, landing in a bouncy tangle in Nano Girl's gloved hand.</p><p>And then perspective was up to its old games again.</p><p>The <em>Victorious Talon</em> dwindled above them and the Pacific opened its sapphire arms beneath. Cold air buffeted Ayesha even as the giantess' fingers curled around her, tearing at her flimsy sheet, streaming her unbound hair, and she laughed in delight at the vision they must present: blonde King Kong clutching ebony-tressed Fay Wray, plunging from the Metro State Building to the asphalt ocean below.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(195, 214, 155);"">“Don't worry, Nano Girl...”</span></strong> Ayesha screamed out, her voice somehow audible above the wind. She stretched her arms wide...<br></p>

...and caught on to the fabric of nothing and everything, wrapping it around them to be their parachute.

How simple she'd been before. How limited! To control her own density, to slip through atomic mesh like a ghost or harden herself into a hypersolid battering ram was the merest party trick. It was all connected: density, energy, mass, magnitude. Dang Jia's elixir of life had torn the scales from her eyes, the caul from her brow and shown her the scalar landscape that Einstein had only glimpse from afar.

Gravity relaxed its hold on Nano Girl and Ayesha. Their fall gentled – slowed – arrested, leaving them cushioned in mid air, the warlike dart of the Victorious Talon's prow high above, the ocean lapping invitingly below.

Nano Girl felt her fingers prised apart by an irresistible force, and Ayesha rose slowly from the palm of her hand, levitating like some classical goddess, her toga-sheet coiled around her hips and shoulders, diagonally across her body in some vestige of modesty. The very air around Ayesha was warped, the light lensed to create a distortion that made her skin seem darker, the sheet paler. Globules of utterly black meta-energy, what could only be called a krackle bled from her skin and seethed in an aura around her, as dark as the hearts of distant galaxies.

Ayesha smiled at her plus-sized friend beatifically. “...no matter how big you are, you're still so small to me,” she said, her voice thrumming with a resonance Nano Girl had never heard before. Lifting her palms skywards the smallest degree, Ayesha began to levitate them towards the flying ship, rising to the heavens like a darkly beautiful and brilliantly terrible angel.
dice roll
