Globules of utterly black meta-energy, what could only be called a <em><strong>krackle </strong></em>bled from her skin and seethed in an aura around her, as dark as the hearts of distant galaxies.</p><p>Ayesha smiled at her plus-sized friend beatifically. <span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0);""><strong>“...no matter how big you are, you're still so small to me,”</strong> </span>she said, her voice thrumming with a resonance Nano Girl had never heard before. Lifting her palms skywards the smallest degree, Ayesha began to levitate them towards the flying ship, rising to the heavens like a darkly beautiful and brilliantly terrible angel.</p>

The two sisters watched from the bridge—a conclusion that not even Jia could have projected or suspected. A camera caught the moment that Ayesha rose from Nano Girl's palm, a perfect image of beauty, lifting herself then, somehow, Nano Girl's massive form, back up toward the cruiser. 

Tu patted Jia lightly on the armoured shoulder. 

""I'll just let you explain to her why you just threw her off the ship, shall I?"" she said sweetly, and stepped off the bridge, Jia's mouth still agape.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The two sisters watched from the bridge—a conclusion that not even Jia could have projected or suspected. A camera caught the moment that Ayesha rose from Nano Girl's palm, a perfect image of beauty, lifting herself then, somehow, Nano Girl's massive form, back up toward the cruiser. </p><p>Tu patted Jia lightly on the armoured shoulder. </p><p>""I'll just let you explain to her why you just threw her off the ship, shall I?"" she said sweetly, and stepped off the bridge, Jia's mouth still agape. </p>

Weightless, but with the impetus of irresistible acceleration the two heroines rose swiftly back to the Victorious Talon. Ayesha gently lowered the towering Nano Girl to the deck, seemingly ungainly in hew unfamiliar giant form, then glided down to land herself. Only she didn't quite touch the deck – her bare feet hovered an inch above the metal. The undulating aura of dark energy droplets coruscating around her from head to toe but its intensity diminished as she ceased actively using her powers, and Ayesha swept the deck with an imperious gaze that the staring Dang marines seemed to avoid instinctively.

Catching sight of Jia in the bridge, Ayesha strode towards her, still levitating. Any crew in the way were gently pushed aside by the envelope of gravitational force that preceded her, and she ignored Black Swan as she entered the command tower. Ayesha stood before the daughter of Dang, her cloud-damp bedsheet dripping on the ground, hovering enough to almost balance the height difference between them. She met Jia's gaze cooly, levelly.

Then she threw her arms around Jia's shoulders and embraced her like a sister, crushing her chest against the armoured breastplate of the other woman.

“Thank you,” Ayesha whispered.

Any crew in the way were gently pushed aside by the envelope of gravitational force that preceded her, and she ignored Black Swan as she entered the command tower. Ayesha stood before the daughter of Dang, her cloud-damp bedsheet dripping on the ground, hovering enough to almost balance the height difference between them. She met Jia's gaze cooly, levelly.</p><p>Then she threw her arms around Jia's shoulders and embraced her like a sister, crushing her chest against the armoured breastplate of the other woman.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0);"">“Thank you,”</span></strong> Ayesha whispered.</p>

Dang Jia's expression had gone from smug -- when Nano Girl's rescue had gone south -- to concerned as Supermassive rose back up, bringing the giantess with her. When the evolved being that had been Sublime approached the bridge, then actually entered it, the imperious warrior-princess' face became unreadable, though her posture spoke of both aggression and defensiveness. The Swan detected actual doubt in the set of her sister's armored shoulders.

And then Ayesha hugged Dang Jia, the woman who had ground tens of thousands beneath her heel. Hugged the sociopath daughter of the world's greatest megalomaniac and most reviled eugenicist. And Jia let her, uncertain how to react, unclear on how to respond.

When Supermassive whispered, though, a smile curled Jia's terrible, beautiful features, and she uttered a simple response as she looked at Tu Wei meaningfully through Ayesha's dark hair.

""You are welcome, my sister.""

When the evolved being that <em>had</em> been Sublime approached the bridge, then actually entered it, the imperious warrior-princess' face became unreadable, though her posture spoke of both aggression and defensiveness. The Swan detected actual doubt in the set of her sister's armored shoulders.</p><p>And then Ayesha <em>hugged</em> Dang Jia, the woman who had ground tens of thousands beneath her heel. <em>Hugged </em>the sociopath daughter of the world's greatest megalomaniac and most reviled eugenicist. And Jia <em>let</em> her, uncertain how to react, unclear on how to respond.</p><p>When Supermassive whispered, though, a smile curled Jia's terrible, beautiful features, and she uttered a simple response as she looked at Tu Wei meaningfully through Ayesha's dark hair.</p><p><span style=""color: rgb(192, 80, 77);"">""You are welcome, my sister.""</span></p>

column4:
Augustus writes up his report and hands it to the clerk responsible for passing the report to the Chief Inspector with a sigh. Were this woman from another district, the murder would be investigated, trialled and reported. But that she were from Queen's Haven...

His position in the Lantern Men didn't leave him copious free time, but today he decides he'll ask Marcus, that wayward brother and sensationalistic journalist, whether he'd seen or heard anything that might be useful fit investigating Gitta's murder.

So it's off to The Ambleton Lass, the roughest pub in the docklands, and probably the best place to find that drunken scoundrel.

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-281008""><div class=""row"">

Alleria made her way to the back of the cart as two labors carried the body of the guard whom was watching over her. For a few moments she felt guilt... maybe if she'd just taken the two silver he'd offered ... which was her cut of her fee... he'd spend less time trying to catch a peek of her, and might have avoided his fate. 

Of course the people around her didn't need a mopey courtesan right now, they needed someone with the air of authority. She sat on the back corner of the cart, giving every laboror that looked her way a reassuring smile.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Alleria made her way to the back of the cart as two labors carried the body of the guard whom was watching over her. For a few moments she felt guilt... maybe if she'd just taken the two silver he'd offered ... which was her cut of her fee... he'd spend less time trying to catch a peek of her, and might have avoided his fate. </p><p>Of course the people around her didn't need a mopey courtesan right now, they needed someone with the air of authority. She sat on the back corner of the cart, giving every laboror that looked her way a reassuring smile. </p>

Well sheiße.

Valentin had not known what to expect on the way to Südessen. The bandits were not entirely surprising, they had heard tales of the lecherous gangs of outlaws during their travels and felt confident that it was nothing they and Ameline couldn’t handle. Running into the halfling barber in places they didn’t expect had stopped being a surprise a long time ago; in fact, Valentin had almost come to expect it at this point. Reuniting with Rex and his sister (or was Tex the brother’s name? They could never remember...) had been a surprise, but given their destination it was hardly a shocking one.

But what in the world was Alleria doing here?!

They kept their sword drawn and their gaze on the path ahead of them, occasionally looking out to the trees for any trace of the bandits that had attacked the caravan — and specifically avoiding looking in the direction of the elf riding in the cart.

“Stay alert,” they said to Ameline, loud enough for their other companions to hear as well. “I can’t see the archer’s trail anymore, but they may circle back.”

column4:
The Tazatel agent hurries through the street, not wishing to be caught after curfew, for fear an over-inquisitive watchman would have to fall foul of an accident too. Of course, Evagail felt indifferent about the plight of the city and its denizens - but an overly bloody trail of collateral would reflect badly on her work, and Thatcher would not approve.

Having planned for violence, she had naturally planned for injury, and knew in exquisite detail one or two routes through the arse-ends of Dunsmouth that would get her to the door of preferred physician, Professor Baltimore.

An interesting old salt, he was neither truly an ally nor an adversary. Instead, he offered agents in distress no-questions-asked surgical assistance - usually with a heady dose of laudanum on either side - in exchange for certain favours. He was not thought to be any kind of threat to the Tazatel, on account of his questionable reputation - were any allegations made, he could be made to look like a devil much sooner than the useless authorities could bring down a boot on the Nendmen.

Breathless, with her slashed face stinging in the clinging evening air, she reached the door in the narrow, cramped street where Baltimore held his surgery. A bronze plaque marked the building. Naturally, it was after surgery hours - but she knew better. She picked up the heavy door knocker, the shape of a wolf's maw, and dropped it heavily against the wooden door three times.

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-282564""><div class=""row"">

The walk from the tidy, stylishly appointed streets of Hearthside to the strictly ordered passages of grimy Cinderfall had taken a lot out of Evagail and she's tottering just a bit as she reaches Baltimore's door. This neighborhood is so named because of its position on the leeward side of the foundries and manufactories of the industrial sector and there is a perpetually sooty weariness about the place that keeps eyes downcast and footsteps on the shortest path to one's destination. The tightly-stacked architecture primarily houses laborers and servicemen, still setting Cinderfall several notches above downtrodden Queen's Haven in terms of quality of life but there is a cloying closeness to the atmosphere here that Evagail finds distracting. Even the liberating perspective from Alfie's rooftop eyries up above the dirty brick tenements does nothing to mitigate her unease when visiting this district.  

Multiple stab wounds provide little by way of additional comfort, as it happens, she reflects ruefully, with gritted teeth.

As she drops the heavy knocker to clunk with dull and ominous reverberations against the sturdy oak of Baltimore's door, she identifies her oversight. The crafty surgeon prefers his after-hours patients to employ the rear entrance, she remembers, limiting any troublesome conclusions to which his neighbors might arrive. It's too late now to amend her plan of ingress, of course, and a quick study of her surroundings reveals no suspicious onlookers. Still, Evagail is embarrassed at how easily her injuries have shaken her professionalism.

At least she'd been sharp enough to elude any unwanted encounters after leaving the greenhouse. 

Glancing down at herself under the guttering light of the nearby streetlamp as she awaits Baltimore's response to her summons, Evagail gravely tries to ignore the pain and gauge the damage she'd taken. The left sleeve of her coat hangs in tatters below the elbow though she'd done her best to restrict the flow of blood from that limb, if only to avoid leaving an incriminating trail. The gouge beneath her right breast doesn't feel quite so bad but there's a cool, gummy layer sticking a wide section of her dress to her skin there that reminds her all too clearly of Teague's blade scraping against her ribs. Worst of all is the rip in her cheek, letting out a sluggish but so far unrelenting seepage of vital fluid to trickle down her neck and soak the shoulder of her garments. All those brutal new additions to her appearance come with an assortment of less serious nicks and bruises from her protracted scuffle. Speckled with potting soil, bits of ornamental foliage, and splinters from Teague's wooden shelving, Evagail imagines she ought to tell quite a story upon first impression but is too beaten at the moment to care.

No really valuable real estate hit, she tells herself for the fifteenth time, in regard to her major organs, honestly more hopeful than clinical. And if he'd clipped an artery, I'd be lost and leaking by now all over Hearthside's fanciest stonework, would I not? 

Like so many members of the Tazatel before her, there's a part of her that turns to the organization's quasi-religious connections when pushed beyond her limits. The irony of the on-again, off-again veneration always feels like whistling past the graveyard but it also presents a practical exercise in continuing to assess information and maintain the security of focused detachment in the face of annihilation.    

Will I stave off infection? she wonders, with the internal cadence of a mantra or prayer to the indifferent and ever-watchful God of Enquiry ... and less of a jest than she might care to admit aloud. How much of my own face will I know tomorrow? More bitterly, the part of her that hurts the most cannot help but interject, Was Teague better off in the final tally? What have I truly won today? Will it matter?

Furrowing her brow in consternation at that—and grimacing as invisible strings of torment threaded through her wounded cheek twist cruelly with the expression—Evagail steers away from this troubling and unproductive consideration. 

Am I strong enough to see this through? She nods vehemently in reply to that one as it's an answer she believes she already knows. Yes. There is no one stronger.

Professor Baltimore's door swings open an instant later and she flinches as a rectangle of soft yellow light falls like a net around her. Alfie had previously sent her here by way of introduction but, up until now, she's never needed the man's attentions. The wily surgeon has not yet girded himself for bed and her mind's eye concocts an image of him hard at work on some nefarious procedure hidden away in his cellar. It suddenly bothers her a great deal to find herself on this man's doorstep, like so many supposedly lesser agents before her.

The anatomist's jowly visage betrays no emotion as the inky black pinpoints of his gaze scour her ragged countenance, seeming to penetrate her very being before readily dismissing her obvious need.

""Professor Baltimore, I presume,"" Evagail announces in a surreptitiously cheerful tone her heart can't match. With the fingers of her right hand—the less gory of the two—she makes a very subtle gesture that any trusted Dunmothian co-conspirator will recognize at once. She repeats the signal once more, just in case, before covering it with a vague flourish at her torn and blood-stained garb. ""I'm afraid I must look a proper fright. I should be ever so grateful if you'd piece me back together once more.""

With that, the last vestiges of strength leave her and her knees turn to mud, pitching her forward to make a fumbling grab at the doorjamb on her way down.

Even the liberating perspective from Alfie's rooftop eyries up above the dirty brick tenements does nothing to mitigate her unease when visiting this district.  </p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">Multiple stab wounds provide little by way of additional comfort, as it happens,</span></em></strong> she reflects ruefully, with gritted teeth.</p><p>As she drops the heavy knocker to clunk with dull and ominous reverberations against the sturdy oak of Baltimore's door, she identifies her oversight. What have I truly won today? Will it matter?</span></em></strong></p><p>Furrowing her brow in consternation at that—and grimacing as invisible strings of torment threaded through her wounded cheek twist cruelly with the expression—Evagail steers away from this troubling and unproductive consideration. </p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">Am I strong enough to see this through?</span></em></strong> She nods vehemently in reply to that one as it's an answer she believes she already knows. <strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">Yes. There is no one stronger.</span></em></strong></p><p>Professor Baltimore's door swings open an instant later and she flinches as a rectangle of soft yellow light falls like a net around her. Alfie had previously sent her here by way of introduction but, up until now, she's never needed the man's attentions. The wily surgeon has not yet girded himself for bed and her mind's eye concocts an image of him hard at work on some nefarious procedure hidden away in his cellar. It suddenly bothers her a great deal to find herself on this man's doorstep, like so many supposedly lesser agents before her.</p><p>The anatomist's jowly visage betrays no emotion as the inky black pinpoints of his gaze scour her ragged countenance, seeming to penetrate her very being before readily dismissing her obvious need.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""Professor Baltimore, I presume,""</span></strong> Evagail announces in a surreptitiously cheerful tone her heart can't match. With the fingers of her right hand—the less gory of the two—she makes a very subtle gesture that any trusted Dunmothian co-conspirator will recognize at once. She repeats the signal once more, just in case, before covering it with a vague flourish at her torn and blood-stained garb. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""I'm afraid I must look a proper fright. I should be ever so grateful if you'd piece me back together once more.""</span></strong></p><p>With that, the last vestiges of strength leave her and her knees turn to mud, pitching her forward to make a fumbling grab at the doorjamb on her way down.</p>

""Oho,"" the Professor says, as she collapses in a heap at his feet. ""I had heard of swooning fans, but to experience it, well."" It's exactly the sort of bedside manner one might expect from the ageing professor, by all accounts, but to experience it, well...

He crouches down, and does his best to move her battered frame inside, out of the street. It takes a moment or two, in which time he glances left and right up the road to ensure they are not observed; they are not. Next, he closes the door, and sits next to her, breathing heavily after the exertion. There are traces of blood on his clothes now, or perhaps they were already there; who's to tell. 

""This may be difficult,"" he tells her. ""You are heavier than you look, and I am older than I look. I would prefer not to drag you across the carpet, as I have just had it cleaned after..."" Baltimore trails off here, looking her over. ""Can you stand, or should I fetch my manservant?""

The professor does not wait for an answer, and once he has regained his composure, stands again and steps back, examining her injuries in the way one might critique a painting in a gallery. ""This is quite the set of injuries,"" he informs her. ""I remember you. And I wondered when you might choose to come by."" Choose is an interesting turn of phrase, but it passes. ""I hope you took care; soil in wounds can lead to infection, which can be as fatal as the wounds themselves. Still, you've made it here. You must be a strong specim---person.""

Baltimore takes a ceramic jug on the sideboard and a doily from an armchair, and pours clean water onto it. ""Here,"" he says. ""Wash your arm as best you can. I shall return anon."" With this, he disappears from the room with a flourish, as if excited by something.

On his return, he carries white linen bandages, a second, larger jug of clean water, and tucked into his armpit, a small leather pouch, presumably containing the tools of his craft. ""I fear your clothes are ruined,"" he says, absently, still assessing her injuries curiously. ""My cook is about your size; we will find something of hers for you, later.""

A moment or two later, he looks at her face, although it is with the impression of one looking at the wound rather than the person. ""Tell me, curious one, how did you come to be injured in this way? I need not the details that an inspector might need,"" - here he loosens his red cravat, and removes it - ""But an idea of the weapon, and perhaps the stature of the perpetrator, would certainly be useful for my, aha, procedures.""

It's exactly the sort of bedside manner one might expect from the ageing professor, by all accounts, but to experience it, well...</p><p>He crouches down, and does his best to move her battered frame inside, out of the street. ""This is quite the set of injuries,"" he informs her. ""I remember you. And I wondered when you might choose to come by."" <em>Choose</em> is an interesting turn of phrase, but it passes. ""I hope you took care; soil in wounds can lead to infection, which can be as fatal as the wounds themselves. Still, you've made it here. You must be a strong specim---<em>person</em>.""</p><p>Baltimore takes a ceramic jug on the sideboard and a doily from an armchair, and pours clean water onto it. ""Here,"" he says. ""Wash your arm as best you can. I shall return anon."" With this, he disappears from the room with a flourish, as if excited by something.</p><p>On his return, he carries white linen bandages, a second, larger jug of clean water, and tucked into his armpit, a small leather pouch, presumably containing the tools of his craft. ""I fear your clothes are ruined,"" he says, absently, still assessing her injuries curiously. ""My cook is about your size; we will find something of hers for you, later.""</p><p>A moment or two later, he looks at her face, although it is with the impression of one looking at the wound rather than the person. ""Tell me, curious one, how did you come to be injured in this way? I need not the details that an inspector might need,"" - here he loosens his red cravat, and removes it - ""But an idea of the weapon, and perhaps the stature of the perpetrator, would certainly be useful for my, aha, <em>procedures</em>.""</p>

With her head feeling as if it's barely treading water and her limbs only obeying her commands as if they're floating leagues away, Evagail musters the strength to rise once more just as he returns to her. She peers with distaste at the clotted handprint she leaves on the wall of Baltimore's entryway. The venerable surgeon moves, as if to restrain her activity perhaps, but something about the hard set of her typically soft and inoffensive gaze subdues his protests and he takes her arm instead.

""He had ... a pruning blade ... "" she reports as Baltimore relents, guiding her into the kitchen where the floor is tiled and thus more appropriate to the task of enduring any additional blood loss. ""Perhaps a single palm in length. No more than that. Nothing by way of toxins I could discern ... "" Faintly, Evagail is aware of how silly it sounds to describe her adversary's plain armament in this fashion but there's little to be done about it if she's to give her unlikely savior an accurate synopsis on the method of injury. ""He was very good. Better than I expected, it seems.""

Shaking her head ruefully and pitching her voice somewhere between vexation and amusement, almost too low to be heard, she breathes, ""Jeden zasraný květinář ... ""

It matters little what she shares. The Professor is certainly canny enough to piece her actions together on the morrow, if he pays any heed to rumors abounding throughout the districts. A violent crime committed against a respected citizen won't go unreported for long. That Baltimore has been marked out by her superiors as deserving a degree of transparency—as near as possible, at least—is enough for her even if it feels off. 

Odd that he could almost certainly identify more Tazatel operatives from other cells than I, it occurs to her. Aside from those in her own cell—and the recently departed Harlan Teague, of course—Evagail can count the number of her colleagues she has personally seen positioned in this nation on the fingers of one hand. With digits left over. 

""There may be shards from numerous flower pots pricking my arse as well,"" she murmurs with uncharacteristic gallows humor. ""If you've any urge towards engaging a less humdrum challenge."" 

The Nendrish woman begins unfastening her garments almost immediately upon reaching their destination. It is not, of course, the first time she has disrobed before a dangerous man who seemingly holds all the power in a room, though her motivations and desired outcome are quite different in this particular scenario. There's simply no leverage at all in pride or modesty and she had dutifully forsaken those troublesome traits many years ago. She accepts that she has no control over his impulses should he enjoy the gruesome sight of her, anatomist or no, and staying covered up hadn't even crossed her mind. Recuperation requires that he'll have his hands all over her in the next few moments in any event. 

The surgeon assists her, claiming her bloodied garments as she goes and keeping up his clamorous commentary. Deftly, Baltimore whisks her Lariini knife away from her and out of sight so fluidly she scarcely notices. She is too light-headed and worn out to fight him on the matter. The old anatomist's liver-spotted hands are steady as millstones despite his earlier declaration of infirmity, she notes, and some distant, frosty part of her can appreciate his manipulative grace.

I could learn a thing or two about the double-life from this one. Darkly, she amends with, I'll hold out hope I've no need to garrote the sly codger once we're done.

Once she has been stripped to the waist—coaxing rivulets of crimson anew from her arm and chest as the ruined fabric is peeled away—Evagail stumbles towards a chair. Baltimore stops her, directing her to lie down on the many-notched and unfinished wooden tabletop instead. Eyeing the man suspiciously, the spy does as directed, groaning at myriad tiny agonies as she settles into place. For reasons she can't quite fathom, he props her feet up higher.

How many lives has he saved right in this very spot? she ponders as she stretches out before him. How many did he exchange for intriguing discoveries instead?

Suddenly, as Baltimore leans over her to ministering to her slashed flesh, tears of anger sting her eyes. The undeniable warmth of relief that has been swelling slowly but surely inside her at someone else's intervention makes her feel desperate and feeble and she positively loathes it. This is far too much like surrender.

""My face,"" she says, despising the croaking sob she hears shuffling along the edge of her tone. ""Do whatever you can for my face, Professor."" She wants to assert some dominance over this interaction but can't imagine how for the life of her. ""I'm acutely aware that I have earned myself a rather nasty scar today that will be quite difficult to conceal in future. Any efforts you expend in this regard will be ... remembered.""

I am no longer an approximation of ""that pretty maid"" but more precisely ""the woman with the scar"", she reflects, silently lamenting her former treasured semi-anonymity.

And then, trying to focus on more pertinent concerns—and those over which she might actually have some sway—she reminds herself that she will surely owe a debt to the Professor no matter what he accomplishes on her behalf tonight. The amoral master surgeon's favors are to be employed as needed, based on his singular relationship with the Tazatel, but they certainly shouldn't be taken for granted. Alfie had been very clear in the past that agents who wish to remain in his good graces should take pains to pay all debts in a timely fashion. Vague hints at his sinister predilections are enough to suggest plenty of ethical quandaries in the days ahead. And the currency of dastardly deeds is always in high demand.

What dreadful task will he ask of me? What does a man like this consider fair trade for stoppering a leaking animate vessel?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>With her head feeling as if it's barely treading water and her limbs only obeying her commands as if they're floating leagues away, Evagail musters the strength to rise once more just as he returns to her. She peers with distaste at the clotted handprint she leaves on the wall of Baltimore's entryway. The venerable surgeon moves, as if to restrain her activity perhaps, but something about the hard set of her typically soft and inoffensive gaze subdues his protests and he takes her arm instead.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""He had ... a pruning blade ... ""</span></strong> she reports as Baltimore relents, guiding her into the kitchen where the floor is tiled and thus more appropriate to the task of enduring any additional blood loss. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""Perhaps a single palm in length. No more than that. Nothing by way of toxins I could discern ... ""</span></strong> Faintly, Evagail is aware of how silly it sounds to describe her adversary's plain armament in this fashion but there's little to be done about it if she's to give her unlikely savior an accurate synopsis on the method of injury. <span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);""><strong>""He was very good. Better than I expected, it seems.""</strong></span></p><p>Shaking her head ruefully and pitching her voice somewhere between vexation and amusement, almost too low to be heard, she breathes, <strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""Jeden zasraný květinář ... ""</span></strong></p><p>It matters little what she shares. The Professor is certainly canny enough to piece her actions together on the morrow, if he pays any heed to rumors abounding throughout the districts. A violent crime committed against a respected citizen won't go unreported for long. That Baltimore has been marked out by her superiors as deserving a degree of transparency—as near as possible, at least—is enough for her even if it feels off. </p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">Odd that he could almost certainly identify more Tazatel operatives from other cells than I,</span></em></strong> it occurs to her. Aside from those in her own cell—and the recently departed Harlan Teague, of course—Evagail can count the number of her colleagues she has personally seen positioned in this nation on the fingers of one hand. With digits left over. </p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""There may be shards from numerous flower pots pricking my arse as well,""</span></strong> she murmurs with uncharacteristic gallows humor. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""If you've any urge towards engaging a less humdrum challenge."" </span></strong></p><p>The Nendrish woman begins unfastening her garments almost immediately upon reaching their destination. It is not, of course, the first time she has disrobed before a dangerous man who seemingly holds all the power in a room, though her motivations and desired outcome are quite different in this particular scenario. There's simply no leverage at all in pride or modesty and she had dutifully forsaken those troublesome traits many years ago. She accepts that she has no control over his impulses should he enjoy the gruesome sight of her, anatomist or no, and staying covered up hadn't even crossed her mind. Recuperation requires that he'll have his hands all over her in the next few moments in any event. </p><p>The surgeon assists her, claiming her bloodied garments as she goes and keeping up his clamorous commentary. Deftly, Baltimore whisks her Lariini knife away from her and out of sight so fluidly she scarcely notices. She is too light-headed and worn out to fight him on the matter. The old anatomist's liver-spotted hands are steady as millstones despite his earlier declaration of infirmity, she notes, and some distant, frosty part of her can appreciate his manipulative grace.</p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">I could learn a thing or two about the double-life from this one.</span></em></strong> Darkly, she amends with, <strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">I'll hold out hope I've no need to garrote the sly codger once we're done.</span></em></strong></p><p>Once she has been stripped to the waist—coaxing rivulets of crimson anew from her arm and chest as the ruined fabric is peeled away—Evagail stumbles towards a chair. Baltimore stops her, directing her to lie down on the many-notched and unfinished wooden tabletop instead. Eyeing the man suspiciously, the spy does as directed, groaning at myriad tiny agonies as she settles into place. For reasons she can't quite fathom, he props her feet up higher.</p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">How many lives has he saved right in this very spot?</span></em></strong> she ponders as she stretches out before him. <strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">How many did he exchange for intriguing discoveries instead?</span></em></strong></p><p>Suddenly, as Baltimore leans over her to ministering to her slashed flesh, tears of anger sting her eyes. The undeniable warmth of relief that has been swelling slowly but surely inside her at someone else's intervention makes her feel desperate and feeble and she positively loathes it. This is far too much like surrender.</p><p><strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""My face,""</span></strong> she says, despising the croaking sob she hears shuffling along the edge of her tone. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""Do whatever you can for my face, Professor.""</span></strong> She wants to assert some dominance over this interaction but can't imagine how for the life of her. <strong><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">""I'm acutely aware that I have earned myself a rather nasty scar today that will be quite difficult to conceal in future. Any efforts you expend in this regard will be ... remembered.""</span></strong></p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">I am no longer an approximation of ""that pretty maid"" but more precisely ""the woman with the scar"",</span></em></strong> she reflects, silently lamenting her former treasured semi-anonymity.</p><p>And then, trying to focus on more pertinent concerns—and those over which she might actually have some sway—she reminds herself that she will surely owe a debt to the Professor no matter what he accomplishes on her behalf tonight. The amoral master surgeon's favors are to be employed as needed, based on his singular relationship with the Tazatel, but they certainly shouldn't be taken for granted. And the currency of dastardly deeds is always in high demand.</p><p><strong><em><span style=""color: rgb(99, 36, 35);"">What dreadful task will he ask of me? What does a man like this consider fair trade for stoppering a leaking animate vessel?</span></em></strong></p>

Baltimore looks at her face doubtfully. ""It is a terrific gash,"" he says. ""It does spoil your pretty countenance. Facial wounds can heal well, though - there is much blood, and vital corporeal essence, behind our visages.""

The Professor leans in close, and Evagail can smell eels on his breath. A modest meal, she considers. Not cheap, like some of the estuarine fish, but neither expensive, like the freshwater fish. A meal befitting his somewhat precarious place on the social scale.

Very closely, he looks at the wound on her face. ""You are lucky,"" he says. ""Another half inch, and you might have lost your eye. To close the wound is easy, but to heal it requires the steady hand of a master. Luckily, you are in the presence of such mastery.""

He retrieves his needle and surgical thread from his bag, and instructs her to be still. ""This will hurt,"" he says. ""I must wash the wound with clear liquor, and the sutures will be small and uncomfortable to bear. I have laudanum, if you wish...?""

He turns to pour liquor from a bottle into an open syringe. ""It will need good care and hygiene to heal. Aftercare is not my speciality, but if you have a trusted apothecary, seek their advice.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Baltimore looks at her face doubtfully. ""It is a terrific gash,"" he says. ""It does spoil your pretty countenance. Facial wounds can heal well, though - there is much blood, and vital corporeal essence, behind our visages.""</p><p>The Professor leans in close, and Evagail can smell eels on his breath. A modest meal, she considers. Not cheap, like some of the estuarine fish, but neither expensive, like the freshwater fish. A meal befitting his somewhat precarious place on the social scale.</p><p>Very closely, he looks at the wound on her face. ""You are lucky,"" he says. ""Another half inch, and you might have lost your eye. To close the wound is easy, but to heal it requires the steady hand of a master. Luckily, you are in the presence of such mastery.""</p><p>He retrieves his needle and surgical thread from his bag, and instructs her to be still. ""This will hurt,"" he says. ""I must wash the wound with clear liquor, and the sutures will be small and uncomfortable to bear. I have laudanum, if you wish...?""</p><p>He turns to pour liquor from a bottle into an open syringe. ""It will need good care and hygiene to heal. Aftercare is not my speciality, but if you have a trusted apothecary, seek their advice.""</p>

""I have always been lucky, Professor Baltimore,"" Evagail sighs as she settles back down on the table, resigning herself to the unpleasantness of the procedure ahead. ""Comparatively speaking.""

As she closes her eyes, doing her best to summon a sense of calm to still her jangled nerves and weary muscles, she contemplates the surgeon's words. In her line of work, she's come to understand the human anatomy—particularly wounds and healing—better than most. Even in her harried state, she had been able to see at once from the coldly detached glitter in Baltimore's night-black eyes that he would have take little stake in her recuperation aside from tidying her rent flesh. 

No, the less tangible minutiae of my convalescence will fall to gentler hands, Evagail muses, wincing outwardly at the pinpoint callousness of the old man's aid. And more compassionate minds. 

Remembrances of the Red Folk bubble up into her awareness; their wisewomen had proven a most valuable resource during her hastily sought miscarriages in the past. Surely they might provide some arcane rite or miraculous herbal concoction to help with the injuries her vocation had won her today.  

Faintly, almost drowsing off despite the choir of agonies singing across her slim frame, Evagail wonders if someone so dedicated to clandestine betrayals can afford the extravagance of self-interested hope.

column2: Commodore Ratal started the briefing: “Ok, let’s get start without-delay… for a week as of today, the Foxfire Squadron has been conducting campaign against the vast

column1: network of Imperial communications satellites, that are used for passing
intelligence and surveillance… and in effect allow the Empire to maintain its iron
grip on the Outer Rim Territories. They have tirelessly been destroying any and
all satellites we were able to find… jumping in, blowing them to kingdom come
and quickly jumping out… which in turn forced the Empire to pull forces to
guard the rest. Which is the reason why you are here…”

The young Mandalorian raised her hand and started after a moment: ""Pilot Daeh, Checker squadron...Sir I have two questions: Do we have any intel regarding capital ships in the area or in direct jump distance to the target? Would be a shame if we jump in only to find a star destroyer waiting for us. Also do we know how many of these relay stations we would have to take out to effectively cripple imperial comms?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The young Mandalorian raised her hand and started after a moment: ""Pilot Daeh, Checker squadron...Sir I have two questions: Do we have any intel regarding capital ships in the area or in direct jump distance to the target? Purely by habit Amara held back, waiting for Epp to speak up and ask the good questions. Of course he wasn't around to do that anymore, just another painful reminder of his death. It was her job to ask the questions now.

At the bright side at least some of her new pilots had a brain for themselves. She was just hoping that they could switch it off when needed.

Raising her hand Amara stated her own question. ""Yessir. Will I be reinforcing the Foxes, or will I be flying escort with my guys? And if the latter, is there a ship I can borrow a bit better suited for that job?"" 

She'd always defend the Y as a tough, reliable all-around workhorse, and she was convinced that her flying one in Checker drastically increased the squadrons adaptability. But they had a full squadron of Y-Wings with Foxfire this time, and while she could defend herself in battle Amara had to admit that escorting its twins was not really in her Rosie's job description. Also the Foxes S3s were a bit more focused on bombing than her A4. Her flying with them wouldn't make their job that much easier, but having another proper escort along would make a difference. Especially as Checker was still understrength.

Juru rubbed at his beak in thought, mulling over the data in question. It was like a domino effect really; they destroy this relay station, and one by one the Empire's communication network throughout the Outer Rim would fall. That kind of disorder could mean life or death for fighter's throughout the Territories. Success then was instrumental for them.

Still he didn't like going into a fight like this blind. Given how stretched the Imperial war machine was in the region it was unlikely they'd be able to leave a capital ship to defend the relay, but that still left a small army of TIE-Fighters to defend the base. Not to mention that the prospect of flying blind into a minefield was also a point of concern.

When Commander Syrush spoke up to Captain Amara though, Juru saw an opportunity to alleviate some of his concerns. He cleared his throat before raising his hand. ""Lieutenant Juru Tahrong, Checker Squadron. Two points on my end sirs. Is it fair to presume information seizure from the relay isn't on our priority list? Just considering that there might be valuable information stored there, but then again risk might not be worth the reward. My other point would be the availability of that second A-Wing; given the condition of my X-Wing, and if its not too much trouble, I'd request flying the other A-Wing for this mission."" He had been willing to bite the bullet and work with Crippled Kate, but if an opportunity arose for something else he'd take it.

""Information seizure is too dangerous. The longer you stay in that system, the longer they have to alarm the reinforcements. Blow that thing from the sky and get out of there. As for the second point... that A-wing is already on the Salliche mission as part of the Vanguard Squadron and is not available. I have no other Starfighters at the moment. You will have to do with what you got.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>""Information seizure is too dangerous. The longer you stay in that system, the longer they have to alarm the reinforcements. Blow that thing from the sky and get out of there. As for the second point... that A-wing is already on the Salliche mission as part of the <em>Vanguard Squadron</em> and is not available. I have no other Starfighters at the moment. You will have to do with what you got.""</strong></p>

Without raising her hand this time the young mandalorian interjected, while patting her fellow pilot on the shoulder. ""Don't worry Juru, I'll swap fighters with you. I have no problem flying something that is falling apart... I kinda have experience in that."" She smiled under her helmet, knowing this might be a chance to not only show she was not afraid of everything but also create ties with her team. If growing up on Mandalore had taught her anything, then that teamwork makes you stronger as any individual fighter ever could be. ""That is if that is alright with the brass and our squadron leader of course. Don't want to step on anyone's toes here."" she added.

After the statement she turned her head back towards the high officers, pretending to wait for an answer but under her helmet, her eyes burrowed themselves in Kerrick's guts. She imagined the different ways of flaying him alive without killing him, imagined how she fed his insights to the local fauna. Yes she hated the man for what he did but she was too professional to truly show it. She made no remark in that direction nor did her voice betray her when she addressed him directly. ""Kerrick, one last question if you allow... after the meeting if that is alright with you"".

She made no remark in that direction nor did her voice betray her when she addressed him directly. <strong>""Kerrick, one last question if you allow... after the meeting if that is alright with you"".</strong></p>

Juru turned back to face Jessa. He hadn't met the rest of his squad save for Kai at this point, but it certainly inspired confidence that they were willing to take a hit for him like this. Her armoured appearance was certainly intriguing; was it... Mandalorian in design? He'd have never expected to see one of their with the Rebellion, but expectations were mean't to be shattered he supposed. If she was flying with them that was good enough for him.

""I appreciate the gesture Daeh, but that won't be necessary. Can't in good faith put someone out because of my own misgivings. Don't worry though, Crippled Kate shouldn't give me too much trouble."" He chuckled at the name given to his ship to inject some brevity into what was becoming a very tense situation; he didn't know what was going on between people here, but it was making his scales tingle.

He turned back towards the commanding officers. ""Can the uh... facility support just TIE-Fighters? Or would it have a compliment of other craft we might have to deal with?""

""I see. Thank you, sir."" Amara doesn't sound as excited as one would
assume as she lowers her hand and thinks back on what she actually knows
about the A-Wing that isn't rumors likely to be hyped up massively. All

she really knows it that the ship is tiny and looks worryingly fragile.

Hearing Juru voice his concern she raises first one brow, and then a second as Jessa offers to swap. She waits for their exchange to end, and for Jessa to recieve her answer from Kerrick before adressing both of then quietly as a few more questions come in from Foxfire, mostly related to possible weakpoints in the structure.

""While I appreciate and applaud my pilots to support each other, this is not the Empire, where every TIE is a twin to the other. I assume, Lt. Daeh, that your ship has already been adjusted and fine-tuned to your height in your armor, linked to it, possibly switched to display information in Mandalorian and generally set up to your personal preferences. If not, then I suggest you have it done at the earliest opportunity.

Furthermore, Squadron logistics is my responsbility. Now, you will fly your ship. If Lt. Tahrongs ship is indeed not flight-worthy, then he shall have this A-Wing, I shall fly my Rosie after all, and whatever ground-crew finds itself responsible for this shortage will wish they'd never live to meet me.

Now, is your ship ready to fly, Lt. Tahrong, or is it not? I want a honest answer, no heroics. It's not just your own life that is at risk here - we are Foxfires protection, and if we aren't ready to do that job then many of them will die. So?""

Juru had his beak couched in his interlocked hands as he listened to his Captain's words. He hadn't been thinking of the broader context when he made that decision, Foxfire Squadron would need its escort squadron at its best for this mission.... but the shortage of materials wasn't making the decision any easier. No matter how he analyzed things someone somewhere was getting short-changed, and that rankled him. ""Suppose I could look into the administrative side of things, find out where the shortfall is.""

With that he turns his head to the side to address Captain Kariya. ""Yes sir it is. There are still some kinks here and there but the engineers were able to work out the worst of it. Kate's as ready as she'll ever be."" Juru found himself growing rather fond of the ascribed identity of his ship. Kate was a tough old girl, resilient and hard to put down. He was sure they'd be seeing plenty of missions going forward.

Hearing the order of her squadron leader, the Mandalorian nodded ""As you command Mam. I have not considered the work that goes into adjusting a fighter to its individual pilot. I have falsely assumed similarities to the processes used on Mandalore and apologize for that. My fighter has already been configured to my specifications, I shall fly her without hesitation."" With that she gave Amara a short salute and addressed the high brass ""My apologies for the disturbance."" she added. Jessa felt the eyes of the other pilots on her and would have rather been under heavy artillery fire than here. ""I hate being so young"" she thought but then focused back on the briefing.

Jessa felt the eyes of the other pilots on her and would have rather been under heavy artillery fire than here. <em>""I hate being so young""</em> she thought but then focused back on the briefing.</p>

Juru gives Jessa an assuaging look. He wasn't going to fault her for doing what she felt was right, even if others judged her for it. The Ishi Tib were a communal species without a doubt, but there was something an elder, a survivor of Suribran Tu's regime, told him many years ago that to this day still resonated with him;

""Compromise where you can. Where you can't, don't. Even if everyone is telling you that something wrong is something right. Even if the whole world is telling you to move, it is your duty to plant yourself like a tree, look them in the eye, and say, 'No, you move'.""

Juru also salutes alongside Jessa. ""Ready and raring to go as well, sir.""

column2: back then… but three died since and Theebo couldn’t handle it anymore and left…

column1: as he had no fight in him left. Kai wasn’t surprised that baron Syrush allowed
him to be reassigned to non-combat duties… Alliance doesn’t force people to
serve in the frontlines if they don’t want to. In the battle, you want people on
your left and right to be counted upon.

column2: Only Amara, who was now a Squadron

column1: Leader, was a familiar face. Others were newcomers. Ky’ron, the only survivor

and tactitian. He sighed. He was the number two now. It was his job to keep an

problems in the Squadron, so the Squadron Leader doesn’t have to. He made a

doing and if they were ok to fly. He learned that from Skeeter, who was now dead

*after the briefing*

As pilots and officers alike
filed out of the room, the Mandalorian stayed on her seat, waiting for the room
to be empty. As much as she hated the very thought of being in one room with
Kerrick, especially alone, she had questions and as senior intelligence
officer, only he might have the answers to them. Jessa noticed that the man
also waited for the room to empty before he acted. Jessa reached behind her
back and the room was filled by a silent buzzing charging sound. The girl had
activated her heavy blaster and drew it, resting it on her lap while eyeing the

man across the room.

“You
can stay over there thank you very much. I won’t take much of your time
anyways. If It would not concern the safety of this base and with it my new
friends, I would not be here so let’s make this easy. You know…I ask a question
and you answer it not like an intelligence officer but like a normal human
being.” Her eyes narrowed as she continued. “Remember what I told you regarding that Task Force that whipped your
convoy… and nearly me? I was wondering if in the meantime you have found out
where they came from or which ships are involved. I assume you have checked the
sensor logs of the Fate and the checker T-65s….must have turned up something…” The
girl patted her blaster with her left hand while keeping the right on the grip.

Jessa pushed a little button on her blaster and the weapon powered down. ""Maybe I will forgive you eventually...Kerrick... but i will never forget it... that you can be sure of. That being said I appreciate your honesty."" The girl flung a small datachip in the direction of the intelligence officer noting ""This is the full sensor readout of my fighter from the time of the attack on the rebel convoy. Ship registries and rough scans of the two SDs and one Interdictor. I think you can do better with it than I. Sorry for the crappy resolution but the Krayt was an antique before I ever took her..."" The girl holstered her blaster while continuing ""The chip is in mandalorian obviously but I don't see you having a problem with that. The way you describe the Task Force hunting us, it surely contains more ships than what we have seen so far but I assume knowing the registry of at least two capital ships makes tracking them easier. In any case its all my Armor could pull from the damaged ship memory. Hope it helps... I do not want anything in return for the info since I don't know how new it is for you but see it as a gesture of good will. No matter what I might think about you, we are for now on the same side... and unless that changes you may rely on me fully. But if you ever touch me again, better make sure you kill me."" The girl concluded. ""If you have anything to add or ask, do so now. If not... I have a meeting with the engineering crew regarding my T-65.""

""Gar serim..."" the girl muttered as she left the room, heading towards the hangar. Arriving there, she looked around, searching for the spot where her T-65 was parked. As she approached the craft, she saw several mechanics working on her craft and greeted them. “I heard you need my presence for the final steps of configuration and adjustment, so here I am.” After taking a seat in the cockpit and linking her armor to the on-board computer, the Mandalorian heard a familiar voice through the intercom “Statement: it is a pleasant surprise to see you have finally arrived master. Elaboration: I have been here working with these meatb…. Mechanics for some time now,” Jessa raised an eyebrow but ignored her mouthy droid for now and turned her attention to the ground crew. “What do you need me to do guys?” she asked.

*After the Briefing*

Juru sat with his hands steepled as he studied the tactical information the Rebels had on hand for the battle to come. It was certainly thorough, that much Intelligence needed to be lauded for, and thanks to it he was already seeing some potential stratagems forming. ""We'll definitely want to stay close to the bombers, otherwise the TIE's might be able to slip through the cracks and take them out. Dealing with the defenses shouldn't be too hard, if we stay low enough to the surface of the station we might be able to avoid the worst of their anti-aircraft batteries. Ultimately though keeping Foxfire Squadron safe is key, which will necessitate staying close.""

Still Juru couldn't shake the gnawing sensation of unease at the back of his skull, even as he tried to plot things out. That minefield was an unknown quantity, one that could potentially make or break this operation. ""Best we can hope for is that luck is on our side... then again luck has never been my go to."" Juru scratched at his beak passively. He then felt something brush against his leg, something soft and small. He looks down, and the closest facsimile of a smile spreads across his alien face.

A small Bearded Jax plopped down on its back by his leg. ""You're a friendly one aren't you? And an unexpected sight as well in a place like this."" Juru bent down to rub the feline's belly, the creature purring contently all the while as Juru pondered its presence. The Bearded Jax, to the best of his knowledge, was not endemic to this planet. In fact the creature was only really native to the Forest Moon of Endor and Rori, one of Naboo's three moons. ""Little guy seems pretty domesticated. Might be he's someone's pet? Or he could've been before jumping ship and ending up here."" Juru's attention however were increasingly being drawn to petting the creature who, based on how it started biting Juru's gloved hand when his mind began to wander, was insistent that the petting continue.

Jessa listened fascinated to the explanation that Kytra provided and noted ""What do you mean, not interesting? I find it quite interesting indeed! I knew Togruta were the apex predators on their home planet but had no idea that it still carried such an important role in their lives"". The girl had a wide smile, wider than she had in a very long time. ""We Mandalorians pray to the spirits of the far ones... those marching in the great beyond for protection. Usually one would carry a bracelet with small Besket orbs, each representing a fallen clan member that was close to the wearer. A parent, sibling or cousin... but also close friends would be included. I used to have such a bracelet too but it was taken from me and I haven't had the time to make a new one."" The young girl sighed but then renewed her smile and continued ""In the end its just a trinket. I remember the names of my entire clan so I simply pray to them like that."" 

After touching the Togruta's skin she mused ""Girl your skin is soft as silk... either your clay scrub is one hell of a secret tip or your species is just plain lucky. The clay also has a quite fascinating smell... or is that you? I can't tell but it is very pleasant. Also while your gunner has quite the attitude, he is right in one regard...."" Jessa took Kytra's hand and squeezed it lightly ""we should get a room. And uhm... sorry again for before... I uhm... still work through some issues you know? Hope I didn't worry you too much or something"" she said slightly embarrassed. 

Knocking lightly on the side of the Y-Wing, Jessa added ""If you let something happen to her, I'll personally travel to the great beyond and kick your ass, got that fly-boy?""

Jessa shook her head smiling and answered ""Do not worry Kytra... I'm the one having to apologize for my behavior... its just that some things are still incredibly painful for me to talk about or even think about. And those scars... well they remind me every day of what happened... I will never have the luxury of simply forgetting. But I dont know... when I look into your eyes I nearly can... feels good... for the first time in a long time. It might sound really stupid and most people will not understand this at all... I have heard some mechanics talk about how they feel on edge around Togrutas in general... ""it feels like they're constantly hunting something"" they say... well I personally feel at ease when near you... I certainly am not afraid."" Jessa cocked her head slightly, sizing the woman before her up and down before continuing ""Though if we really went at it in earnest you might be the toughest fight of my life... and girl... I have killed a damned Krayt Dragon when I was 12..."" her smile dissipated for a second while remembering her late brother but then she shook her head and continued ""I am not sure if you would consider this as a compliment but I understand why your species was the Apex hunter on your planet. Something that a Mandalorian can appreciate quite a bit, I assure you. But yeah... please forgive my childish behavior from before... I... well... I really needed to vent I guess... too much had happened and It felt good to just... let go for a moment...""

After she finished, the girl looked up at the gunner again and said with a sigh ""You clearly never heard of the Force-magic that the Dathomirians wield... sadly under Maul we Mandalorians got our own little taste of it... The barrier to the great beyond is easily broken for them... If I really wanted to, Id get to you don't you worry flyboy. But you ain't worth the trouble. All talk and no action. Grabbing things that don't belong to you... No self control, no honor. Be glad you can shoot straight... its your one redeeming feature...""

Jessa's eyes narrowed slightly at Kytras comments but she forced herself to smile. ""Don't worry... I would jump into a sarlaac to protect any one of you... including the joker. As you correctly said... we are on the same side."" The girl turned to leave but stopped for a moment and added ""Kytra... Mandalorians do not listen to idle gossip... I judge people by their actions... not by what others might think. So far you have been one of the nicest people on this base... In a way we are in the same boat. Don't think I havn't heard the rumors about the terrible Mandalorian roaming the halls...people fear what they do not understand... but I see you and I see a friend... Take care among the stars... May your fire pierce the cold of space and may the imperials look upon you and despair. Aim true and fly safe my friend. Sa kyr'am Nau tracyn kad, Vode an."" With that Jessa put on her helmet again and headed towards her own craft, ready to strike fear into the hearts of the imperial Navy.

column4:
Once Maenna joined The New Path, she would ask to visit the Source as much as possible. Brining the precious water for the gardens. Maenna had not yet officially gone through the rites and rituals for full membership when Damson tracked her down. But, it was not any surprise that Damson found her at the White Garden, where they tended the special flowers. The New Path started about a week after the bombings. A large faction of the faithful left the main religion and no longer considered themselves orthodox Woven. They called themselves the New Path, or the New Weave. They drank the flowers, had visions and revelations, and if not joy, at least a removal of pain.

Some gangs of militant, traditional Woven, had started assaulting and harassing them, but it had not spiraled into full out sectarian violence, yet. Some of the New Path, around the time Damson came calling for Maenna, though--were starting to sing a new song, less tolerant, more dogmatic. Damson heard rumors of one assassination, a Woven priest shot in the back.

Nasak was one of the first to start the more militant ideas in the New Path sect. Nasak, before all this, before the bombs, before he ever drank of the flower, was Ro’s lover.

Bert, if you’re listening in here, tell us, what was that all about? Why is Nasak still bitter or obsessed or otherwise interested in Ro?

As Damson entered the White Garden she found Maenna speaking quietly to Alieh. It was obvious to Damson that Maenna had just drank a tincture of the flowers and was in trance. Alieh guided Maenna to a set of pillows near an empty pool, and, upon seeing Damson, walked up to her.

column3: Jump to last post

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-281458""><div class=""row"">

“Greetings, my fair Damson, are you here finally to partake?”

She presented a long, narrow flute, like a champagne glass, but made of fine silver. Inside a froth of blended flowers and alcohol sloshed. 

Normally, the sound of water trickled in the background but not today.

In the corner Nasak also eyed Damson as she entered. He kept within earshot. Eager to hear news from the Source, and, possibly Ro.

Damson, you know a secret about the White Garden, right? What is that?

What did Damson do?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>“Greetings, my fair Damson, are you here finally to partake?”</strong></p><p>She presented a long, narrow flute, like a champagne glass, but made of fine silver. Inside a froth of blended flowers and alcohol sloshed. </p><p>Normally, the sound of water trickled in the background but not today.</p><p>In the corner Nasak also eyed Damson as she entered. He kept within earshot. Eager to hear news from the Source, and, possibly Ro.</p><p><strong>Damson, you know a secret about the White Garden, right? What is that?</strong></p><p>What did Damson do?</p>

""Thanks but no thanks, Alieh. As always."" 

Damson liked the New Path alright, actually. They brought people together like few things in the city did, and mostly they helped them. But the flowers skeeved her out. She wasn't above drugging or drinking herself into oblivion every once and a while; she didn't judge. But she didn't like anyone having power over her, and something about the way faithful like Maenna came to depend on the flowers felt uncomfortably like surrendering control.

And then there was the secret entrance to White Garden, of course. Knowing the city was her business. She hadn't known what to make of the people coming and going out of the old drainage outlet in the old canal (both drain and canal depressingly dry now, of course) half a click from the Garden at first. Curiosity piqued, she'd spent some time watching it, and seen senior church members coming and going that way - along with strangers. 

She'd never seen Alieh use it, but Nasak did all the time.

""I was hoping to talk to Maenna,"" she continued, brushing these thoughts aside. ""Any point? She looks pretty zonked. I thought she might want to bring you all back some water, but maybe it's a bad time.""

They brought people together like few things in the city did, and mostly they helped them. But the flowers skeeved her out. She wasn't above drugging or drinking herself into oblivion every once and a while; she didn't judge. But she didn't like anyone having power over her, and something about the way faithful like Maenna came to depend on the flowers felt uncomfortably like surrendering control.</p><p>And then there was the secret entrance to White Garden, of course. ""Any point? She looks pretty zonked. I <em>thought</em> she might want to bring you all back some water, but maybe it's a bad time.""</p>

Once Alieh heard mention of water, her eyes widened. She took a sharp short breath of relief edging on greed, or at least, want. 

""Oh, no. Not a bad time at all. Just in time, if you ask me.""

She gave a weak, almost embarrassed smile. 

""Mae, Mae?"" She moved over to the woman, put an arm around her shoulder. ""Guess who's here? Damson. Can you bring us some source-water, sweetie? Just like last time?"" 

Maenna smiles and nods. Then she stood and slowly walked to Damson, where she finally stumbled into Damson's arms. The smell of her flowerbreath cascaded over Damson's face as she gave out a laugh, and a smile.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Once Alieh heard mention of water, her eyes widened. She took a sharp short breath of relief edging on greed, or at least, want. </p><p>""<strong>Oh, no. Not a bad time at all. Just in time, if you ask me</strong>.""</p><p>She gave a weak, almost embarrassed smile. </p><p><strong>""Mae, Mae?</strong>"" She moved over to the woman, put an arm around her shoulder. <strong>""Guess who's here? Damson. Can you bring us some source-water, sweetie? Just like last time?</strong>"" </p><p>Maenna smiles and nods. Then she stood and slowly walked to Damson, where she finally stumbled into Damson's arms. The smell of her flowerbreath cascaded over Damson's face as she gave out a laugh, and a smile. </p>

Damson frowns as she steadies Maenna on her feet. Nothing's ever simple. This is more witnesses to her departure with Maenna then she was counting on. And the last thing she needs is Nasak tagging along and causing problems. 

""Ah, I don't think so, loverboy,"" Damson says, taking Maenna by the arm. ""Ro lets people into the Source, or not. I have to stay on their good side, and that means no letting awkward ex's tag along.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Damson frowns as she steadies Maenna on her feet. Nothing's ever simple. This is more witnesses to her departure with Maenna then she was counting on. And the last thing she needs is Nasak tagging along and causing problems. </p><p>""Ah, I don't think so, loverboy,"" Damson says, taking Maenna by the arm. ""Ro lets people into the Source, or not. I have to stay on their good side, and that means no letting awkward ex's tag along."" </p>

""What's it to you?"" 

Bert would ask you good-naturely when you inquire about Ro and Nasak while you exchange some scrawny vegetables for the cool, cool water they offer at their stand. Ro actually isn't far but Bert makes no attempt to cover that they're talking about them.

""It's not like they didn't get along. Maybe even too well. Nasak, though, he has a possessive streak, something fierce. It didn't show at first, but it got worse and worse."" They pause as if remembering what that was like.

""Nasak got so jealous that he couldn't stand Ro being with other people, you know, talking to them, sitting next to them, sharing food with them. Ro was trying to assure and appease him at first. Eventually they told him to cool it, but that only made Nasak more jealous, more demanding. So, Ro wouldn't have any of that shit, they told him when he started on that issue a couple of times. Then Nasak tried to force them, wanted to beat them into shape."" Bert laughs and shares a conspiratory look.

""You can imagine how that went."" They laugh again while you alternatingly glance between them and Ro whose rifle's barrel, slung over their shoulder, just catches some rays of the setting sun as they load some tinkling crates into the cart.

""Long story short, they broke up with Nasak running with his tail between his legs. He still thinks, though, that he owns them, no matter how many times Ro makes a point that they're their own person and he should stay the fuck away.""

He still thinks, though, that he owns them, no matter how many times Ro makes a point that they're their own person and he should stay the fuck away.""</strong></p>

Maenna hugs into Damson, putting far too much of her weight on her, as though, should Damson step back Mae would faceplant right there. 

She nuzzled her mouth near Damson's ear. 

""I'm so close. Nasak is about to recommend to Alieh I do the initiation rights. Please, let him come too. I don't want to upset him, not now.""

She had an intense look, a mixture of both worry and impatience.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Maenna hugs into Damson, putting far too much of her weight on her, as though, should Damson step back Mae would faceplant right there. </p><p>She nuzzled her mouth near Damson's ear. </p><p><strong>""I'm so close. Nasak is about to recommend to Alieh I do the <em>initiation</em> rights. Please, let him come too. I don't want to upset him, not now.</strong>""</p><p>She had an intense look, a mixture of both worry and impatience. </p>

Damson can see that involuntary look of regret, anger and frustration on Nasak when Damson mentioned Ro. While Maenna whispered, Nasak replied. 

""Well. I wasn't going to say anything but, I need to make things right with Ro. I have something Ro has wanted for a long time. I want to give it to them. Ro won't mind. I assure you, you'll stay on Ro, and Bert's, good side.""

He brushed his hands along the legs of his pants as though to kick off some dust. Though, his pants were freshly laundered, pressed even. No dust on them at all.

""Hell, they might even thank you for bringing me along after I deliver the gifts I have for them. For Ro. "" 

He smiled.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Damson can see that involuntary look of regret, anger and frustration on Nasak when Damson mentioned Ro. While Maenna whispered, Nasak replied. </p><p>""<strong>Well. I wasn't going to say anything but, I need to make things right with Ro. I have something Ro has wanted for a long time. I want to give it to them. Ro won't mind. I assure you, you'll stay on Ro, and Bert's, good side.""</strong></p><p>He brushed his hands along the legs of his pants as though to kick off some dust. Though, his pants were freshly laundered, pressed even. No dust on them at all.</p><p>""<strong>Hell, they might even thank you for bringing me along after I deliver the gifts I have for them. For Ro. </strong>"" </p><p>He smiled. </p>

Damson extricated herself from Maenna's embrace, taking care to still support her, and shook her head firmly. ""Thanks but no thanks. I'm not showing up at the Source with you as an uninvited guest. But."" She raised a finger. ""I will ask Ro if they mind if I bring you and your gift, and then bring you another day. Or carry that shit myself. I'm not too proud to play courier.""

""Sorry, buddy boy, but I take my access to the Source very seriously and I'm not going to fuck around with it.""

""I mean, you get it, right, Alieh?"" Damson turned to her; maybe she could leash this dog. ""Is it really worth risking Bert's wrath just so Nasak can make nice with his ex?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Damson extricated herself from Maenna's embrace, taking care to still support her, and shook her head firmly. ""Thanks but no thanks. I'm not showing up at the Source with you as an uninvited guest. But."" She raised a finger. ""I will ask Ro if they mind if I bring you and your gift, and then bring you another day. Or carry that shit myself. I'm not too proud to play courier.""</p><p>""Sorry, buddy boy, but I take my access to the Source very seriously and I'm not going to fuck around with it.""</p><p>""I mean, you get it, right, Alieh?"" Damson turned to her; maybe she could leash this dog. ""Is it really worth risking Bert's wrath just so Nasak can make nice with his ex?""</p>

There was a long pause before Alieh replied. She looked at Nasak. 

""Just give the gift to Damson to deliver, Nas. Ro will see and understand. Ro will let you back in."" 

At that point it became obvious that they were already cut off, at least, Ro had cut them off. The White Garden was in need of Source waters.

""Damson's right. We can't have Ro telling Bert, can we? If you go, you risk that just as much as forgiveness."" 

At which point Nasak's phony smile broke. He cast a dark glance at Alieh and took in two sharp breaths, then stormed off. 

Alieh found a small wooden box. Intricate. 

""Don't open it. It's for Ro only.""

Alieh offered it gently to Damson. 

Damson had seen that box before. Damson, who was it's previous owner and what illegal treasure did they need to keep in it?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>There was a long pause before Alieh replied. She looked at Nasak. </p><p>""<strong>Just give the gift to Damson to deliver, Nas. Ro will see and understand. Ro will let you back in.</strong>"" </p><p>At that point it became obvious that they were already cut off, at least, Ro had cut them off. The White Garden was in need of Source waters.</p><p>""<strong>Damson's right. We can't have Ro telling Bert, can we? If you go, you risk that just as much as forgiveness</strong>."" </p><p>At which point Nasak's phony smile broke. He cast a dark glance at Alieh and took in two sharp breaths, then stormed off. </p><p>Alieh found a small wooden box. Intricate. </p><p>""<strong>Don't open it. It's for Ro only</strong>.""</p><p>Alieh offered it gently to Damson. </p><p>Damson had seen that box before<strong>. Damson, who was it's previous owner and what illegal treasure did they need to keep in it? </strong></p>

Damson frowned deeply the moment she saw the case, then tried to cover the expression, and accepted it with a nod. ""Ro only. You got it."" 

She couldn't keep her eyes from straying to the case, though. She was familiar with it, of course; the last time she'd seen it, Lotte had been opening it up, to present Damson with what was inside: a sleek machine pistol, smuggled in from outside and skillfully, illegally modified by Lotte herself. Lotte was as clever with machines as she was stupid with people. That was part of why they hadn't seen each other in some time. 

The other part had to do with Lotte joining up with one of the nastiest, most anti-social gangs out there, and lending them her considerable talents. Damson was hardly one to judge, usually, but Lotte's new friends crossed lines that Damson couldn't deal with. 

Back then she'd been more interested in the pistol, and in the woman giving it to her, than in the box. She tried to remember anything about it's provenance. Had Lotte made it herself? Or maybe the pistol had been smuggled into the city with the box? She couldn't remember. Her curiosity was definitely ablaze, though. 

""Well,"" she told Alieh. ""Guess I've got two jobs to do, then. Unless there's anything else...?""

You got it."" </p><p>She couldn't keep her eyes from straying to the case, though. She was familiar with it, of course; the last time she'd seen it, Lotte had been opening it up, to present Damson with what was inside: a sleek machine pistol, smuggled in from outside and skillfully, illegally modified by Lotte herself. Lotte was as clever with machines as she was stupid with people.
