An sense of relief floods through her — she’s not the only one — but, her amnesia is something that she has been determined to conceal, and perhaps, she thinks, she should be suspicious of Eve.

“I don’t remember anything about my childhood”, she finally admits. The lure of understanding and empathy is just too strong for her in the end.

“I don’t even remember being a child. Is that the same for you?”

“I know, I mean really know, that there something wrong with this”, she holds up Dawn’s hand for scrutiny, “really wrong”, she repeats without elaborating. 

“Do you remember how you got here? I mean to this town, because I don’t…”

She pauses. She could stop now and not reveal anything more about what she is, or rather, what she isn’t, but Eve, hand is firm and gives her confidence that she’ll understand.

“What I said about not remembering my childhood, is only part of it. I don’t remember anything before a few days ago. I don’t remember anything before waking up here.”

“But, you think she does”, she follows Eve’s gaze over to Summer. Summer is suddenly important again.

Cora’s dress drops to the floor as Seth celebrates his $20 win and pushes her back toward the bed. He follows her in as she works her hands up his shirt and pulls it over his head.  She tosses it to the floor and then notices his scars.There aren't many but enough to notice. She runs her hands over them, in a sympathetic way. Studying them. His contract, she remember he saying earlier that night.  Some fae clans are fucked up. I’ve never heard of a clan who writes contracts on skin.  Usually they are just verbal. But, the more she reads about her type, the less surprising it all seems, just unusual.  

She kisses his wrist lightly before staring deep into dark eyes. “Oh, my love, you are the first one...well like us I’ve met in a long time.”  She sneaks a hand around his neck and keeps the other gently running over his scars. “I’ve never met a fae who keeps contracts on their skin.”  She kisses him softly on the lips and wraps both arms around his neck. “I guess it’s part of your bloodline?” Stop asking him questions. You dingbat girl…. He’s half naked, do bad things!

“So, have you ever...chanted before? Or should I start from the beginning?” She whispers in his ear and gently bites his neck.

""I remember a time before the estate, but I feel as though I've always been in this town.""

She shifts uncomfortably. ""It's odd to me, because I have memories...sort of? I have a story in my head that insists that it is my past. Parents dying, being sent to foster care, but I don't remember my foster parents, it's as though something went wrong with my head, I don't even remember their names...but I've met another like us, or maybe she's more like her.""

She nods her head over to Summer. 

""She was the same, yet different, where I took from those around me to become who I am, it seems as though others gave to her, if that made any sense. She remembers being a child, but was unsure if it's merely just another expertly crafted memory.""

She laughs a little. ""It's funny, because her name was Winter. She didn't want to spend much time with me, I think I scared her. But I'm so happy that I'm not the only one, I knew there had to be others like me...""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""I remember a time before the estate, but I feel as though I've always been in this town.""</p><p>She shifts uncomfortably. ""It's odd to me, because I have memories...sort of? I have a story in my head that insists that it is my past. Parents dying, being sent to foster care, but I don't remember my foster parents, it's as though something went wrong with my head, I don't even remember their names...but I've met another like us, or maybe she's more like her.""</p><p>She nods her head over to Summer. </p><p>""She was the same, yet different, where I took from those around me to become who I am, it seems as though others gave to her, if that made any sense. She remembers being a child, but was unsure if it's merely just another expertly crafted memory.""</p><p>She laughs a little. ""It's funny, because her name was Winter. She didn't want to spend much time with me, I think I scared her. But I'm so happy that I'm not the only one, I knew there had to be others like me..."" </p>

Fae. Bloodline. Selkie. Incubus. Druid.

There it is. It was too easy. It was too right. Seth was wrong.

This girl ... doesn't know me. Doesn't know what I am.

The weight of everything hits him all at once. Are all those things ... real? If demons, and ghosts, and zombies, then why not fae? Why not werewolves? Why not ... whatever kind of slenderman shit Allon is supposed to be?

All of this is real, and I'm ...

(Stupid boy, you know what you are.)

I'm a monster.

(You're mine.)

But Cora wants him. Accepts him. Wants to be with him. For now, anyway. Would she still if she knew ... what he is?

Seth is too terrified to find out.

""It's ... part of who I am,"" he says vaguely. ""But enough about that. On to chanting."" He wraps an arm around her. ""I think we'd better take it from the start, and go slow.""

If demons, and ghosts, and zombies, then why not fae? Why not werewolves? Why not ... whatever kind of slenderman shit Allon is supposed to be?</p><p><em>All of this is real, and I'm </em>...</p><p><em>(Stupid boy, you know what you are.)</em></p><p><em>I'm a monster.</em></p><p><em>(You're mine.)</em></p><p>But Cora wants him. Accepts him. Wants to be with him. For now, anyway. Would she still if she knew ... what he is?</p><p>Seth is too terrified to find out.</p><p>""It's ... part of who I am,"" he says vaguely. ""But enough about that. On to chanting."" He wraps an arm around her. ""I think we'd better take it from the start, and go slow.""</p>

His face softens and looks slightly blank as he whispers ""It's ...part of who I am"".  Cora wants to ask more questions, but before she can react or even let her brain process, he wraps his arm around her and kisses her deeply.  All thoughts in that moment are gone, she feels safe.  He feels right.  

She breaks away from his kiss for a second, ""Well Mister Chapel"" she pushes him over onto his back and rolls on top of him.  ""You may want to buckle up for safety, this is going to be a wild ride."" She leans in and kisses him again.  ""Tonight, my love, you're mine""

“That’s exactly what they told me. Parents died, so i was sent here, to foster parents.”

“The doctors, my foster parents, even my phone tell me that my name is Dawn”, she shrugs, “So that’s who I am, I guess.”

“You, me and Summer, we’re the same. It’s almost like we’ve been jammed in here. Like we’re the wrong pieces of a jigsaw puzzle, but someone was just determined to make us fit.”

“What happened to the other girl Winter? Is she still around? Did she leave?”

“Oh, and did you get a weird vision earlier this evening? Just before I arrived. Like really strange, human sacrifice sort of thing.”

Eve shakes her head. “I didn’t, but the far here place wards against any sort of outside magical influence, so I might not have gotten it.”

She leads Dawn over to the trash can wine and scoops herself a drink. She downs it quickly and keeps gulping long after the wine is swallowed. Eve is scared.

“Winter didn’t want to believe, when I spoke to her she denied me, said she wanted to be left alone from people like me, like us, like any of these people. I did, and I haven’t seen her since. There was a dark about her I didn’t want to trifle with, that’s for sure.”

They leave the two of them there to their own business, the Fallen has never been the type to watch. Lust is the most banal of sins.

Luckily...there are so many more pieces on the chessboard...

column3: Hard Time in Ordo Dracul Prison (Scene Over 4/27/18)

column4: “In the middle of a difficulty lies opportunity.”

column1:
– Albert Einstein

The three Prometheans are all locked in the same cell.  It has featureless concrete walls, ceiling, and floor.  There is no furniture of any kind in the cell.  You have been here for a few weeks while one of the vampires, known only as Dr. Park, has been experimenting on you in painful ways.  You know nothing of the layout of the building you are in only ever seeing the hallway outside of your cell.  There are two guards in the hallway at all times, they interact with you as little as possible.

Santiago holds his hand to the open wound on his throat, his face still smiling even as his eyes show pain and sorrow. ""I've seen worse-... But, I do wish I had my book.""

He looks over to Roxy a moment, still mystified at having met another of his Lineage. He could see how similar they were, but also how different.

""I don't think words are enough, manita."" Santiago had been too busy studying his fellows to feel true anger at his imprisonment, but he could see how the other hated it. ""Still, there must be some way out.""

Xavier had been compiling all the results of the tests on his laptop from another room beyond the guards.  He could hear the prometheans complaining and wanting to be free.  He figured that made sense.  His mentor was cruel and torturous to these.... Creatures.

Perhaps his mentor was going about his studies in all the wrong ways.  How could he study them while they were trapped in a cage?  Granted you could get some useful information on them like that, but eventually the cage would bind even the experiments.

The best route to take would be to study them in their natural habitat, doing natural things, experiencing what they would outside of the cage.  Xavier relaxed back in his chair and stroked his chin as he thought about how to proceed. 

Xavier grabbed a notebook and set them on his rolling office chair, then rolled it all to the cage. He was going to ask them questions.  His glasses sat on the bridge of his nose and his hair was tied back into a not so messy bun.  He had a nice black button up shirt on with the first few buttons undone and black slacks.  

He sat down in his chair just out of arm's reach from the bars and crossed one ankle over his knee, notebook and pen ready to go.  His first question was probably something that his mentor had never asked.  ""What are your names?""

""My book, my mementos."" Santiago pauses and pulls his hand away from his throat, exposing the deep cut of his disfigurement. ""My bandages. I had a gun, but-... I think I understand why I can't have that.""

Xavier lead Santiago up the stairs out of the dark cellar that held their work stations, offices and labs along with the holding cells for the prometheans. He was quiet a moment, taking it all in and leaving the two guards with the two left over.   He didn't understand why Santiago would bring anything back for the other two when they didn't say that they were hungry.  Therefore, they must not be.   

He knew that Santiago prefer to eat plants, probably salads and such, but Pizza would have to do for now.  It was the only place in town that he knew of that would deliver.  He was sure there were others, but being a vampire, knowing what they were seemed unimportant.
""Why would you bring food back for the other two?""  He asked finally.

Before asking he debated on why it would be called a Throng. Throng meant thousands, but he supposed it made as much sense as a vampire group being called a Kiss or a Coven.  Vampires weren't exactly witches, so the term is loosely applied. 

He wanted to ask what the other man had meant by Fire told him, but his phone started ringing.  That got his mind wondering if the guards had already ratted him out for taking Santiago out of the cage. And dear god, the other man could really use a shower and some clean clothes.    Well that got his mind going on something else entirely.  Great.  He shook his head and answered the phone, ""Hello?""  He held a finger to his lips toward santiago, hoping that the promethean would get a clue and not talk while he was on the phone. 

He kept walking toward the door to wait for the Pizza to arrive, while he was on the phone.

He had gotten soda and water as well, for he knew that the Promethean must be thirsty too, if he were hungry.   

The vampire needed those few minutes to think and clear his head. ""He said that the experiment was getting it's plug pulled.  He wanted me to clean up here.""   There were many options on the table, but none of them that he could come up with involved the Doctor to just... let it go.   How could he get them out of here with out the doctor's loyal ghouls knowing that he didn't do the job.  They would rat the moment they got the chance.  And likely, if the ghouls had been around as long as his Elder Mentor, the ghouls would be stronger than he was even at a full vampire.  Decades and Centuries can do that to you. 


He sighed heavily.  It was a human habit, but it had stuck.  ""Do you like the food?""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Xavier didn't have much time to do anything but shrug before the knock at the door.  He collected the pizzas from the delivery boy and thanked him, giving him a couple of twenties and telling him to keep the change.  He brought Santiago into the small kitchen and sat down as he offered the veggie and Mediterranean pizzas to the other man. He had gotten soda and water as well, for he knew that the Promethean must be thirsty too, if he were hungry.   </p><p>The vampire needed those few minutes to think and clear his head. ""He said that the experiment was getting it's plug pulled.  He wanted me to clean up here.""   There were many options on the table, but none of them that he could come up with involved the Doctor to just... let it go.   How could he get them out of here with out the doctor's loyal ghouls knowing that he didn't do the job.  They would rat the moment they got the chance.  And likely, if the ghouls had been around as long as his Elder Mentor, the ghouls would be stronger than he was even at a full vampire.  Decades and Centuries can do that to you. <br><br><br>He sighed heavily.  It was a human habit, but it had stuck.  ""Do you like the food?""</p>

Santiago pauses a moment, before opening the box of the Mediterranean pizza and grabbing a slice. Once he digs in, he doesn't stop, displaying next-to-no table manners as he eats.

""Getting-... Its plug pulled?"" He spoke as he ate, not understanding the euphemism at first, but gradually putting two and two together. ""You mean-...""

He stops eating, leaving a little more than half of the pizza left in the box.

""You're not-... He's-... It's Disquiet."" The Galateid spoke after a moment's consideration, eyeing Xavier up and down to make sure he wasn't suffering from the same condition. ""Humans go crazy around us, I saw it in Mexico. Guess you guys ain't immune.""

""You have a good heart. You let us go and the Doctor will punish you-..."" He looks the Vampire in the eyes, his own eyes watered with tears, even as his smile remains. ""... Unless you come with us.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Santiago pauses a moment, before opening the box of the Mediterranean pizza and grabbing a slice. Once he digs in, he doesn't stop, displaying next-to-no table manners as he eats.</p><p>""Getting-... Its plug pulled?"" He spoke as he ate, not understanding the euphemism at first, but gradually putting two and two together. The Galateid spoke after a moment's consideration, eyeing Xavier up and down to make sure he wasn't suffering from the same condition. ""Humans go crazy around us, I saw it in Mexico. Guess you guys ain't immune.""</p><p>""You have a good heart. You let us go and the Doctor will punish you-..."" He looks the Vampire in the eyes, his own eyes watered with tears, even as his smile remains. ""... Unless you come with us.""</p>

Xavier was curious about the Promethean's response to all that , but he was distracted by the way the thing ate.  ""I don't think that he is crazy.  I just think someone higher up than he said to stop doing what he was doing. He is a very smart man. "" 

""Why are you...crying?""  That was something he wasn't really prepared for at all. The vampire was even less prepared for the Promethean to suggest that he follow them out.  ""It is much harder for me to just up and travel around.  I can't just get a hotel room and be ok for the day. It doesn't work like that for me. And I don't know how you would get out of here alive with those ghouls watching over you. Ghouls aren't exactly a waste of space.  Especially ghouls for an Elder vampire. I don't even know how old they are.  Besides the two down stairs barely talk.  I am sure they would rather eat a bullet than hang out with me.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Xavier was curious about the Promethean's response to all that , but he was distracted by the way the thing ate.  ""I don't think that he is crazy.  I just think someone higher up than he said to stop doing what he was doing. Ghouls aren't exactly a waste of space.  Especially ghouls for an Elder vampire. I don't even know how old they are.  Besides the two down stairs barely talk.  I am sure they would rather eat a bullet than hang out with me.""</p>

""I-..."" Santiago wipes his tears away, thinking a while for his answer to that question. The anger and sorrow he had been suppressing was coming to the fore, but was accompanied by so many other emotions. ""... I-I don't want to die!""

""We're stronger than Human, we can fight them, we can protect you-... We can find a way."" He tries to maintain his determination, despite the emotions surging in his blood. He can feel the fire burning inside him, yearning for the chance to become something more.  ""But you have to choose quickly-... Are you with us, or will you let us all die?""

Xavier frowned and nodded.   ""I think that is really nice of you to offer, but I dont think the other two down there want anything to do with me.   When you are finished eating. I really think that you should shower and put on some nice fresh clean clothes. "" 

He wasn't sure why Santiago was in such a hurry.  He figured that the doctor wanted him to do the killing and cleaning up all the mess because he didnt want to do it himself. Which means he would be gone for hours at least.  ""I am not going to let you all die.  Well at least, I am not going to be the one to do it.  You cant find anything out like that. Studying the living is vastly more interesting than studying a corpse.""

""I have two more ideas. Firstly,I'll try to access the Refinement of Torment. Perhaps with the mastery of electricity I can control the door,but the door would have to be powered of eletricty for it to work.""

""If that doesn't work,Roxy I'm gonna need you to hit me with lightning again. Enough to kill me. They probably dump my body somewhere else while my soul descends to the underworld. When I return I'll be hopefully out,then I'll go back and free you. Even if I had to burn this place down""

E meditated with his eye closed. He thinks about Stannun. The refinement of Torment. All of his anger,all of his despair start to flow through him. He remembers his mentor Lucas,and wonders if he would like this. He prays to God silently. And then,he sheds his old trasmutations in search of new ones. And he suceeds.

""I'm ready"" he says and starts to control the machine.

Roxy looked on as the Originist’s face contorted in pain. Stannum, Suffering, the Path of Tin- her path. She knew the burden Emmanuel was taking on to his shoulders. Being intimate with your torment hurt, hurt deeper than you imagined it could. She hoped the Ulgan was strong enough to bear that burden. Tin needed strong hands to work it. 

She watched on as Emmanuel rose to make his attempt. She played with her little spark, hoping against hope, knowing deep down how foolish such things are. 

She would die here. Never having lived. 

If Emmanuel was right though, maybe she could make sure he got his chance.

""... Will I have to go back to the cell after?"" He hangs his head somewhat, trying to figure out if there was any way out of this. ""Can you show me to the shower?""

“Follow me.”  He said before leading Santiago down a hallway to a very sparse bathroom.  As he walked he spoke, “Don’t you want to go back to your friends?”

The trip was short,  so when they arrived he opened the door, “you do know how to shower? Yes? I mean.. soap and how it works?   You will find everything you need in there.  I will get you clean clothes as you shower.”

""Last chance-..."" He sighs, waiting until he was sure that Xavier wasn't on the immediate other side, before opening the door. He wastes no time, immediately leaving and trying to sneak his way out of the facility.

column3: Chapter Eight: Dark Deeds, and Dark Words

column4:
Gror turns toward Ailinel and the others, ""You wish to talk, fine. Than speak quickly.""

""Quick I will be if you answer truthfully and directly Gror."" Nár's voice is stern and his tone gruff.  ""Why did you and these sell swords attack us just now rather speak to us about your intent?""

Ailinel adds; ""It is you who have the greater need for talk, not us. You have wrongfully and unprovoked attacked us in the wild. It is you that need to convince us to talk, not the other way around. So speak, and be swift about it. Why should we spare you?""

""You wish to know why I did what I did? I knew from the moment I met you."" He says glaring at Ailinel and then Nár. ""That you had already made up your minds. You let you prejudice color your view of me. Elves and friends of Elves cannot be trusted. They betrayed my folk at the Battle of Five Armies and have been doing so for far longer."" His voice is layered with anger.

""Still waiting for a reason to talk with you..."" Ailinel says sarcastically.

Gror's tirade begins to make Nár think the Dwarf is unhinged and he feels an anger rise in him. ""You dare to presume to know our hearts and our minds without bothering to know us. Gror, I perceive that for too long you have entertained dark thoughts so that you can no longer distinguish between good or ill. If you continue on this road, you shall come to rue it. None of us are your enemies Gror unless you make us so. We are giving you a second chance if you will take it.""

""He has already made us his enemies, Nár. And two people are dead because of it. He might save his life by talking, but he'd better start talking soon.""

Grór considers his options, ""I may have been hasty in my actions. But it is true what I said, she did judge me on our first meeting. For that I do not wish to see her again. Young Tom is at the camp, he is bound, but safe. I will claim my share from the Troll horde as the only claim for my brother's death. This barrow I have lost. I will claim only the treasure of the Troll for my due rewards, and you shall see me no more."" 

Tolerance: 0/1

Base TN for rolls: 16 (could be modified.)

Encounter Goal: End the fight, get information from Gror.

What is the goal that you are trying to get out of Gror here?

Successes: 2

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-282371""><div class=""row"">

You deeply mistake your bargaining position Gror.

We are four and you are alone now.

Not one silver coin will you leave here with!

The only question is, do we lead you off in chains or do we fight?

And as for judging in advance. We met you in the south and I treated you with respect and friendship. And even though I soon got suspicious, I never hurt or sought to hurt you.

You may claim an evil word to be said in haste. You can not claim to have ambushed someone in haste. You knew us, and still you attacked.

Your greed has made you blind, and possibly also mad...

Grór holds his hand up, ""I am speaking to Ryn.""

After a pause, Gròr speaks up once again. ""So what is it fellow wanderers? I do not wish to see you no longer than I have to. And I am sure you will be glad to be rid of me. I forfeit my claim on the treasure horde, and will return young Tom to his home. All I ask is for Ryn to give me the treasure of the troll horde. And I will be off, returning wanderering these forsaken lands.""

Gror crosses his arms and looks at the warrior. ""I will give you three answers, to three questions. As long as Ryn gives me a share as my weregild. My claim is forfeit upon the Black Barrow.""

You can ask three questions. Roll Riddle or Persuade both TN 14 if you wish for each question. A success on either means you get more information out of Gror either by tricking him into divulging more information (Riddle). Or giving him a good reason to divulge more information (Persuade). A great or extraordinary success will impart an additional piece of information.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Gror crosses his arms and looks at the warrior. ""I will give you three answers, to three questions. As long as Ryn gives me a share as my weregild. My claim is forfeit upon the Black Barrow.""</p><hr><p>You can ask three questions. Roll <strong>Riddle </strong>or <strong>Persuade </strong>both TN 14 if you wish for each question. A success on either means you get more information out of Gror either by tricking him into divulging more information (<strong>Riddle</strong>). Or giving him a good reason to divulge more information (<strong>Persuade</strong>). A great or extraordinary success will impart an additional piece of information.  </p>

Something of note: Using the same reason or tactic for each roll when RPing your rolls will result in the TN being raised. So giving ""Give us more information or we will take you to meet justice from the Reeve."" The second time that is used or something close to it will make the second roll TN 16.

What will you have him swear upon?</em></p><p><em>Will we let him leave with all of his gear, armour and weapons?</em></p>

Nár's blade knocks Grór to the ground, and he moves no more. Rising, the pain returns to his shoulder, greater than before. His legs grow weak, and the Dwarf slumps back to the ground to catch his breathe. Finally, able to speak once more, he responds to Ailinel. 

Let us take his weapons and have him swear an oath upon them. We shall take his mattock to Bree and leave them with someone we trust. Gror may collect them later. I believe we should empty the barrow as best we can so he cannot return to claim the treasure. I would be loath to let him have any of it now. What do you think?

As the sun sets Nár strips off his armour and inspects his shoulder, which is now varying shades of black, purple and brown. Wincing, he dabs at it with a warm cloth. You are deadly with that mattock, or nearly so, he finally says to Gror, ignoring his earlier comment. Resting against a tree, he feels the need to smoke and pulls out his pipe and pouch of pipe weed.  Drawing on it quietly for a few minutes, he  holds out the stem to Gror. Care for some?

Nár unfolds the packet, removes a bit of stale bread and nibbles at the corners as he watches Gror stump off into the marshes until he disappears into the darkness. Sighing heavily, he rejoins his companions. This place, this ruin of men long vanished, has put me in a melancholy mood, he says plucking at his harp. He begins to sing in a low and resonant voice.

Wondrous is this

wall-stead, wasted by fate.

Battlements broken, giant’s

work shattered.

Roofs are in ruin, towers

destroyed,

Broken the barred gate,

rime on the plaster,


Walls gape, torn up,

holds

the proud builders,

departed, long lost,

and the hard grasp of the

grave, until a hundred generations

of people have passed.

Often this wall outlasted,


hoary with lichen,

red-stained, withstanding the storm,

one reign after another;

the high arch has now fallen.

The wall-stone still

stands, hacked by weapons,

by grim-ground files.


Mood quickened mind, and

the mason,

skilled in round-building,

bound the wall-base,


wondrously with iron.

Bright were the halls, many

the baths,

High the gables, great the

joyful noise,

many the mead-hall full of

pleasures.

Until fate the mighty

overturned it all.


Slaughter spread wide, pestilence

arose,

and death took all those

brave men away.

Their bulwarks were broken,

their halls laid waste,

the cities crumbled, those

who would repair it

laid in the earth. And so

these halls are empty,


and the curved arch sheds

its tiles,

torn from the roof. Decay

has brought it down,

broken it to rubble. Where

once many a warrior,

high of heart, gold-bright,

gleaming in splendour,

proud and wine-flushed,

shone in armour,


looked on a treasure of

silver, on precious gems,

on riches of pearl...

in that bright city of

broad rule.

Stone courts once stood

there, and hot streams gushed forth,

wide floods of water,

surrounded by a wall,


in its bright bosom, there

where the baths were,

hot in the middle.

Hot streams ran over hoary

stone

into the ring


Setting down the harp, he sips at a tin of hot tea and stares into the fire.

these halls are empty,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;""><br></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">and the curved arch sheds

its tiles,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">torn from the roof. Decay

has brought it down,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">broken it to rubble. Where

once many a warrior,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">high of heart, gold-bright,

gleaming in splendour,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">proud and wine-flushed,

shone in armour,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;""><br></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">looked on a treasure of

silver, on precious gems,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">on riches of pearl...</span><p></p></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">in that bright city of

broad rule.</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">Stone courts once stood

there, and hot streams gushed forth,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">wide floods of water,

surrounded by a wall,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;""><br></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">in its bright bosom, there

where the baths were,</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">hot in the middle. </span><p></p></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">Hot streams ran over hoary

stone</span><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana; color: black;"">into the ring</span><p></p></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p><br></p></span></p><p class=""MsoNormal""><span style=""font-size: 10.5pt; font-family: Verdana;""><p>Setting down the harp, he sips at a tin of hot tea and stares into the fire.  </p></span></p><p>
Nick has awoke after some time, and he tends to his son as Nár's voice carries a solemn but beautiful melody through the marshes. ""I only hope to leave this place soon.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Nick has awoke after some time, and he tends to his son as Nár's voice carries a solemn but beautiful melody through the marshes. ""I only hope to leave this place soon."" </p>
Oswald still stands near the fire, ""I will help you with your efforts here, if I can take a share of the treasure.""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Oswald still stands near the fire, ""I will help you with your efforts here, if I can take a share of the treasure.""</p>
Oswald, you joined Gror in attacking us. You get nothing.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><strong>Oswald, you joined Gror in attacking us. You get nothing.</strong> </p>
""That is a bold lie! I did not draw my blade against you or your folk! So I offer again, I will help you with clearing the barrow!""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""That is a bold lie! I did not draw my blade against you or your folk! So I offer again, I will help you with clearing the barrow!""</p>

If you help us it will pay for the debt you owe is in travelling with people who attacked us. Help, and I will forgive you. That is it. If you dont find that enough, then return to your village. The Reeve will learn of what has happened here.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><em>If you help us it will pay for the debt you owe is in travelling with people who attacked us. Help, and I will forgive you. That is it. If you dont find that enough, then return to your village. The Reeve will learn of what has happened here.</em></p>
""I knew nothing. My brother was killed because of Gror's lie, I will only help if I receive a share to bring to his family!""
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>""I knew nothing. My brother was killed because of Gror's lie, I will only help if I receive a share to bring to his family!""</p>
Be off then! But swiftly before I change my mind! We shall see how your village treat you when they learn of what has befallen here...
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><em>Be off then! But swiftly before I change my mind! We shall see how your village treat you when they learn of what has befallen here...</em></p>
Oswald gather his things, ""A forigner from the south knows nothing."" He gathers his things and purposfully pushes past Ailinel.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Oswald gather his things, ""A forigner from the south knows nothing."" He gathers his things and purposfully pushes past Ailinel.</p>

Alright is anyone stopping Oswald, Ed and Larry the two surviving members from the fight will also follow Oswald.

Anyone else doing anything specfically tonight?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Alright is anyone stopping Oswald, Ed and Larry the two surviving members from the fight will also follow Oswald.</p><p>Anyone else doing anything specfically tonight?</p>
I presume that we are well supplied? If so, nothing.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>I presume that we are well supplied? If so, nothing.</p>

You are well enough supplied for a few more days at least. But you will need to be hunting shortly. I will skip to the next morning, on a journey characters are allowed two rolls per day for tasks. So To finish this drain everyone can roll craft in the morning and one in evening.

prevent the drain from collapsing. Though he prefers metal craft, the close
fitting of stone gives him an understanding and appreciation of the

By the end of Nár's work the drain has been built to handle a large flow of water. The water will be sent towards one of the large ponds some ways away from the barrow. All that remains now is to tunnel into the barrow to allow the water to pour out.

6 out of 8 successes.

After having spent the first part of the day ineffectively, Ailinel feels the frustration welling inside her. Remembering her captains word back in Minas Tirith ’if frustration is boiling inside, try to channel it into determination’. She goes to Nár who explaines exactly where she should be digging to finish the tunnel.

Early in the evening, she is done. And the water begin puoring out, almost knocking her down but she gets a foothold and nimbly jump aside.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>After having spent the first part of the day ineffectively, Ailinel feels the frustration welling inside her. Remembering her captains word back in Minas Tirith ’if frustration is boiling inside, try to channel it into determination’. She goes to Nár who explaines exactly where she should be digging to finish the tunnel.</p><p>Early in the evening, she is done. And the water begin puoring out, almost knocking her down but she gets a foothold and nimbly jump aside.</p>

As the day ends Ailinel finishes digging through to the barrow, allowing the water to rush out down the hill towards the pond. Inside the barrow Ryn and Wes work to take the gold and treasure. The total hoard values at 150* Treasure. Among these is the pearls of great worth that Ryn found,  (20 treasure)

A lordly chain of gold bearing the emblem of Arthedain (20 treasure) (Treasure of Duindain)

A golden crown, bearing seven shining sapphires (50 treasure) (Treasure of Dunindain)

A jeweled sword-hilt (20 treasure) (Treasure of Duindain)

Ring of silver, studded with a fine emerald (10 treasure)

Casket of coins (25 treasure)

A small gold ring (5 treasure)

And various other coins, gems, pearls ect. Plus the 30 treasure worth of coins from the upper barrow.

In total the treasure is worth 180*

And the total treasure that is not clearly of Duindain make is 90* treasure.

It is already late evening, so you will have to spend one more night in the Marshes. But you can head back to Bree at first light.

Plus the 30 treasure worth of coins from the upper barrow.</p><p>In total the treasure is worth 180*</p><p>And the total treasure that is not clearly of Duindain make is 90* treasure.</p><p>It is already late evening, so you will have to spend one more night in the Marshes. But you can head back to Bree at first light. </p>

You three share the treasures that are not of dunedain make. I will try and find some of the dunedain who live around Bree, and return the chain, crown and sword hilt to them. If any of you wish to join me in this I would gladly have some company.

In the improbabal event that they would let me keep more than 30 gold as a token of thanks you have my word that I will share it equally among us, though I do not think this will be so.

Everyone can also roll a magical treasure roll.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Everyone can also roll a magical treasure roll.</p>
dice roll
dice roll
dice roll

Nár yelps with delight when a great gush of water drenches him as the barrow begins to empty. Dripping wet he grins at his companions. Soon Ailinel, soon the treasures of your forbearers will be revealed. May it bring you joy. If you recover anything from the treasure, then you should keep it for yourself Ailinel. You cannot live on air and water. 

Looking at the well lined channel, Nár feels the deep sense of contentment that comes with making something of worth. He would be happier had his handiwork been put to better use than the recovery of treasure, but the labour felt good after the strife with Gror.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p><span style=""font-size: 13px;"">Nár yelps with delight when a great gush of water drenches him as the barrow begins to empty. He would be happier had his handiwork been put to better use than the recovery of treasure, but the labour felt good after the strife with Gror. </p>
So Nar can now bid a number of unspent xp to roll extra d6s looking for tengwars. If he gets anything special than that is his share he won't have 30 treasure.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>So Nar can now bid a number of unspent xp to roll extra d6s looking for tengwars. If he gets anything special than that is his share he won't have 30 treasure.</p>
So I will give out xp for the past few RPs. Everyone can take 4 xp.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>So I will give out xp for the past few RPs. Everyone can take 4 xp.</p>
dice roll
dice roll
dice roll

Within the barrows hoarde Nár finds an Adamant Armband made by the Elves of Eregion, judging the fine quality it appears to be worth 160 treasure. It seems to glow and even emit a strange light all on it's own.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Within the barrows hoarde Nár finds an Adamant Armband made by the Elves of Eregion, judging the fine quality it appears to be worth 160 treasure. It seems to glow and even emit a strange light all on it's own.  </p>
So you can use an undertaking to find out what this item does by picking the Go see a Lore-Master undertaking or just discover the blessing on your own.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>So you can use an undertaking to find out what this item does by picking the Go see a Lore-Master undertaking or just discover the blessing on your own.</p>

Magical treasure works two ways it will give you a bonus equal to your wisdom score (x2 wisdom for a greater blessing). In addition to this on a successful roll you may spend a point of hope to turn it into a magical result.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Magical treasure works two ways it will give you a bonus equal to your wisdom score (x2 wisdom for a greater blessing). In addition to this on a successful roll you may spend a point of hope to turn it into a magical result. </p>
So Wes failed the magical treasure roll. So Ryn and Wes each get 45 treasure each.
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>So Wes failed the magical treasure roll. So Ryn and Wes each get 45 treasure each.</p>

Picking up the armband, Nár turns it in his hand admiring the craftsmanship and recalls how its maker, an Elf of Eregion had once been neighbours and friends of the Dwarves of Khazad-dum. Those had been happier times. The adamant glows with an inner light that cuts the darkness of the barrow. Twice now I have been blessed by Adamant. I shall take this and it will become an heirloom of my house.  When he returns to the surface, Nár offers up the rest of his treasure to Ryn and Wes.  I cannot keep both the armband and the treasure. He places the band on his arm to test its fit and to see whether any properties become clear to him.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Picking up the armband, Nár turns it in his hand admiring the craftsmanship and recalls how its maker, an Elf of Eregion had once been neighbours and friends of the Dwarves of Khazad-dum. Those had been happier times. The adamant glows with an inner light that cuts the darkness of the barrow. <strong>Twice now I have been blessed by Adamant. I shall take this and it will become an heirloom of my house.</strong>  When he returns to the surface, Nár offers up the rest of his treasure to Ryn and Wes.  <strong>I cannot keep both the armband and the treasure. </strong>He places the band on his arm to test its fit and to see whether any properties become clear to him.</p>
Is anyone else doing anything tonight, or just heading back to camp?
<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Is anyone else doing anything tonight, or just heading back to camp?</p>

A sudden weariness overcomes Nár. I wish only to attend to  food and drink this evening. He rotates his injured soldier and winces with pain. But we must be cautious tonight. We now have a small fortune and Gror and Oswald may still be nearby. Let us mount a guard. I will take first shift.  

Nar will don his armour during guard duty. Do we gain 2 Endurance points again tonight for resting?

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>A sudden weariness overcomes Nár. <strong>I wish only to attend to  food and drink this evening. </strong>He rotates his injured soldier and winces with pain. <strong>But we must be cautious tonight. We now have a small fortune and Gror and Oswald may still be nearby. Let us mount a guard. I will take first shift.  </strong></p><hr><p>Nar will don his armour during guard duty. Do we gain 2 Endurance points again tonight for resting?</p>

The next morning you wake early to set off from the Black Barrow, opting this time to avoid the marshes the company heads north and than west for a ways before heading south to meet the East Road. The entire journey will take you 7 days and one fatigue test at TN 14.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>The next morning you wake early to set off from the Black Barrow, opting this time to avoid the marshes the company heads north and than west for a ways before heading south to meet the East Road. The entire journey will take you 7 days and one fatigue test at TN 14.</p>
dice roll

Nár slings his pack and turns his back on the dismal scene. As the barrow recedes in the distance, and firmer ground lay up ahead, his heart lifts and, with Adamant lumbering at his side, he whistles a jaunty walking song.
dice roll

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Nár slings his pack and turns his back on the dismal scene. As the barrow recedes in the distance, and firmer ground lay up ahead, his heart lifts and, with Adamant lumbering at his side, he whistles a jaunty walking song. </p>

Ailinel is almost back at full strength, but her muscels are sore from all the digging yesterday. Yet they have accomplished something marvellous and worthy so her spirit is high!

That is a beautiful piece Nár. You earned it yesterday, taking on Gror though he was clearly the most experienced fighter of the two of you. You have great honour, and I am proud to call you my comrade at arms!

Travel roll

column1: <div id=""messages-region"" class=""roleplay-messages span_12""><div><div class=""message-list""><div class=""message"" id=""message-282623""><div class=""row"">

Südessen was exactly none of the things Alleria had hoped for, the company made it slightly more palpable. She wanted to forget today... but would settle for the next best thing. 

She sat on the small table in the room. 

""I didn't expect this is what it would take to have a private conversation ..."", she said to Valentin, closing her eyes for a moment as she let the sentence trail off. 

""So where do you want to start."" she said, her body language clearly slanted towards the conversation they've put off since the bandit attack.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Südessen was exactly none of the things Alleria had hoped for, the company made it slightly more palpable. She wanted to forget today... but would settle for the next best thing. </p><p>She sat on the small table in the room. </p><p><em>""I didn't expect this is what it would take to have a private conversation ..."", </em>she said to Valentin, closing her eyes for a moment as she let the sentence trail off. </p><p>""<em>So where do you want to start."" </em>she said, her body language clearly slanted towards the conversation they've put off since the bandit attack. <br></p>

If there was one thing Valentin was sure of, it was that this was most likely a terrible idea. Alleria was part of the past they wanted no part of, and she had made it clear she wasn’t planning to stay in Südesson longer than her business kept her. If they were smart, they would be keeping a far distance between themself and the elf.

And yet...

They remained standing at a respectful distance from Alleria, keeping their gaze out the window instead of looking at her directly. “I just need to know...”

Valentin trailed off, unsure of how to finish that sentence. They had a million questions running through their head all at once. What must she really think of them, now that there were no witnesses? Was she going to tell anyone about their past? Who knew about the crime they had committed?

“....What did my sisters say when I left?” The question slipped out before Valentin realized what they were asking.

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>If there was one thing Valentin was sure of, it was that this was most likely a terrible idea. Alleria was part of the past they wanted no part of, and she had made it clear she wasn’t planning to stay in Südesson longer than her business kept her. If they were smart, they would be keeping a far distance between themself and the elf.</p><p>And yet... </p><p>They remained standing at a respectful distance from Alleria, keeping their gaze out the window instead of looking at her directly. “I just need to know...”</p><p>Valentin trailed off, unsure of how to finish that sentence. They had a million questions running through their head all at once. What must she really think of them, now that there were no witnesses? Was she going to tell anyone about their past? Who knew about the crime they had committed?</p><p>“....What did my sisters say when I left?” The question slipped out before Valentin realized what they were asking. </p>

Alleria focused on Valentin for a moment. She'd never been able to read Valentin that well, which was frustrating and a little bit scary for someone in her line of work. She had no idea what he was looking to get from that question...

""Pretty much as you'd expect, asking questions between sobs. It's a tragedy to loose one member of the family, but they effectively lost two at once."", it was a more direct answer than she would have liked to give.

""I stayed with them as long as I could, but being a dead man's mistress isn't sustainable ... and what they needed I couldn't give them."" her voice trailed off with subtle tone of sadness. 

""I've got to admit I'm intrigued ..."" 

Her first inclination was to ask what actually happened, she had her own thoughts ... and the speculation of others in the aftermath... but the truth was still very much a mystery. However, that question was undeniably painful. 

""... how you've managed since then.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Alleria focused on Valentin for a moment. She'd never been able to read Valentin that well, which was frustrating and a little bit scary for someone in her line of work. She had no idea what he was looking to get from that question...</p><p><em>""Pretty much as you'd expect, asking questions between sobs. It's a tragedy to loose one member of the family, but they effectively lost two at once."", </em>it was a more direct answer than she would have liked to give.</p><p>""<em>I stayed with them as long as I could, but being a dead man's mistress isn't sustainable ... and what they needed I couldn't give them."" </em>her voice trailed off with subtle tone of sadness. </p><p>""<em>I've got to admit I'm intrigued ..."" </em></p><p>Her first inclination was to ask what actually happened, she had her own thoughts ... and the speculation of others in the aftermath... but the truth was still very much a mystery. However, that question was undeniably painful. </p><p>""<em>... how you've managed since then.""</em></p>

Valentin winced as Alleria spoke of their sisters. It was probably fitting, how much hearing about their family's woe felt like a blade through Valentin's heart. They had never wanted this fate for their family, and the guilt of their past weighed on them like the lifeless body of their father had weighed upon their blade.

The question that followed came as surprise, enough so that Valentin looked at the elf directly for the first time. Alleria's tone seemed genuine, which was only more puzzling to the sellsword.

""How I've managed?"" they repeated somewhat dubiously before shrugging. ""About as well as you would expect for someone living on the run after killing their own —""

They paused for a moment. This was something they had never spoken of aloud, save for the sleepless nights they whispered it to themself endlessly in an attempt to process what had happened on that horrible night. The words felt like they were stuck in Valentin's throat, stopped by an invisible gatekeeper who refused to let them pass, as if speaking them out loud would solidify the realness of them and make it impossible for Valentin to hide from them any longer.

""...I cannot imagine what you must think of me now."" Valentin said after a pause. ""But please believe me when I say that I never intended for any of this to happen.""

<textarea class=""message-content-editor""><p>Valentin winced as Alleria spoke of their sisters. It was probably fitting, how much hearing about their family's woe felt like a blade through Valentin's heart. They had never wanted this fate for their family, and the guilt of their past weighed on them like the lifeless body of their father had weighed upon their blade.</p><p>The question that followed came as surprise, enough so that Valentin looked at the elf directly for the first time. Alleria's tone seemed genuine, which was only more puzzling to the sellsword.</p><p>""How I've managed?"" they repeated somewhat dubiously before shrugging. ""About as well as you would expect for someone living on the run after killing their own —""</p><p>They paused for a moment. This was something they had never spoken of aloud, save for the sleepless nights they whispered it to themself endlessly in an attempt to process what had happened on that horrible night. The words felt like they were stuck in Valentin's throat, stopped by an invisible gatekeeper who refused to let them pass, as if speaking them out loud would solidify the realness of them and make it impossible for Valentin to hide from them any longer.</p><p>""...I cannot imagine what you must think of me now."" Valentin said after a pause. ""But please believe me when I say that I never intended for any of this to happen."" </p>

""I believe you."", she said without even bothering to look Valentin in the eye. 

She turned her gaze toward them, ""I'm pretty good at reading people ... and you never struck me as the type of person capable of such things. Even after, although I've got to admit I'm a bit spotty when it comes to you.""

""I might be a bit wide of the mark again, but seems like you're planning to hang around here a bit ... correct?"" She said, knowing her business could be as intended might be concluded soon. The town was in pretty bleak shape although she'd never say that.  She had no intention to start a prolonged relationship with the Duke or anyone else at this point. 

It handn't even been a full day, and felt the tug of this town's people needing her. Top of mind, was a young girl who desperately need a mother ... or at least a responsible adult in her life.

Even after, although I've got to admit I'm a bit spotty when it comes to you.""<br></em></p><p><em>""I might be a bit wide of the mark again, but seems like you're planning to hang around here a bit ... correct?"" </em>She said, knowing her business could be as intended might be concluded soon. The town was in pretty bleak shape although she'd never say that.  She had no intention to start a prolonged relationship with the Duke or anyone else at this point. </p><p>It handn't even been a full day, and felt the tug of this town's people needing her. Top of mind, was a young girl who desperately need a mother ... or at least a responsible adult in her life.</p>

If Valentin was trying to hide their relief, they were doing a very poor job of it. Perhaps it was silly of them — Alleria was not their family, nor did she have any real personal stake in the crime Valentin had committed. But all the same, the fact that somebody believed that they were telling the truth was a relief beyond words. If nothing else, it made the elf less threatening. If she believed them, it was less likely that she would turn them over to the Reichsrennfahne.

Less likely, yes, but still not an invalid threat.

Grateful for what seemed to be a change of tone in the conversation, the sellsword nodded. ""That is my plan, yes,"" they responded. ""Südesson is... less than perfect, as I am sure you have noticed, but it is a chance at a new beginning. That is not something I can afford to pass up."" 

As they said the words, Valentin could not help but remember that what they considered to be a fresh start, Alleria seemed to view as a business opportunity and nothing more. She had not become a citizen, after all, and did not seem to have any intention of doing so. It was odd — while Valentin had many a reason to fear the elvish courtesan, the thought of her leaving Südesson and the likelihood that they would never see her again after that was unpleasant, to say the least. While she was a reminder of the mistakes they had made, Valentin also found Alleria's presence to be something of a comfort. She was familiar, like a piece of the home they had left behind. 

Needless to say, it was complicated. 

""Forgive me if I am mistaken,"" they continued, ""but I take it that you are not planning to stay here long after your business with the Gutted Fräulein is complete?""

That is not something I can afford to pass up."" </p><p>As they said the words, Valentin could not help but remember that what they considered to be a fresh start, Alleria seemed to view as a business opportunity and nothing more. She had not become a citizen, after all, and did not seem to have any intention of doing so. It was odd — while Valentin had many a reason to fear the elvish courtesan, the thought of her leaving Südesson and the likelihood that they would never see her again after that was unpleasant, to say the least. While she was a reminder of the mistakes they had made, Valentin also found Alleria's presence to be something of a comfort. She was familiar, like a piece of the home they had left behind. </p><p>Needless to say, it was complicated. </p><p>""Forgive me if I am mistaken,"" they continued, ""but I take it that you are not<em> </em>planning to stay here long after your business with the <em>Gutted Fräulein</em> is complete?""</p>

""I ... ... don't know."", she said in a tone seemed oddly passive for her.

""My business with the Gutted Fräulein won't last much longer, unless I want it to. The madame ... Abigail I believe her name was, seems invested in the current state of things. I honestly can't say she's wrong ... one courtesan in this town seems to be one too many. I'm infinitely more useful to her as a slightly more expensive whore... and we both know that."" She paused for a moment realizing that she may have said more than originally intended, the last thing she wanted at this point was pity. 

""I know what I am, and she wouldn't be asking me to do anything I've not already done willingly.""

She paused for a moment, the feeling in her stomach reminded her all to well of the time she parted from Valinten's sisters. She was empathic by nature, it made her an effective courtesan. However, when that empathy was turned on a dead benefactor's daughters, or a town steeped with problems ... it tore her up inside.  She could stay here, and make it work ... but that would mean giving up on reclaiming her Grand Mother's Title.

Alleria's uncharacteristic passiveness was not lost on Valentin. They had known the elf for some time now, and had always admired her confidence.  The indecision and turmoil they saw in her was all too familiar; their childhood memories were tainted with it as they had tried to carry the burden their father had placed on their shoulders. To see Alleria in a place of conflict like this stirred something inside the sellsword, a protectiveness and indignation that anything should make their companion feel this way.

Approaching Alleria, Valentin placed a hand on her shoulder and looked her in her eyes. ""If that is what the madame sees you as,"" they said gently, ""then that is her mistake.""

""If there is anything I have learned in my time since our last meeting, it is this: the world we live in may be cruel, but we decide our own fates in it. Everybody will want you to be something — my father only ever wanted for me the be a perfect son to carry out his legacy. But it was not who I am, and for that reason it was not sustainable.""

""Things... may not have resolved the way I would have wanted them to, for which I have my regrets."" They continued, looking down for a moment. This was proving to be more difficult to discuss than they had thought it would be. When they looked up again, their gaze was filled with resolve. ""But now? I am free. Who other people want us to be and what they want us to do is not relevant. We decide our own fates. If you want to stay... then stay."" In a soft tone, they added, ""I would certainly be glad if you did.""

They had known the elf for some time now, and had always admired her confidence.  The indecision and turmoil they saw in her was all too familiar; their childhood memories were tainted with it as they had tried to carry the burden their father had placed on their shoulders. To see Alleria in a place of conflict like this stirred something inside the sellsword, a protectiveness and indignation that anything should make their companion feel this way.</p><p>Approaching Alleria, Valentin placed a hand on her shoulder and looked her in her eyes. ""If that is what the madame sees you as,"" they said gently, ""then that is her mistake.""</p><p>""If there is anything I have learned in my time since our last meeting, it is this: the world we live in may be cruel, but we decide our own fates in it. Everybody will want you to be something — my father only ever wanted for me the be a perfect son to carry out his legacy. But it was not who I am, and for that reason it was not sustainable.""</p><p>""Things... may not have resolved the way I would have wanted them to, for which I have my regrets."" They continued, looking down for a moment. This was proving to be more difficult to discuss than they had thought it would be. When they looked up again, their gaze was filled with resolve. ""But now? I am free. Who other people want us to be and what they want us to do is not relevant. We decide our own fates. If you want to stay... then stay."" In a soft tone, they added, ""I would certainly be glad if you did.""</p>

She didn't intend to let the chuckle escape her lips, but it managed to get away. 

""Dear Valentin, it seems you've got choice mixed up with freedom. That's what the crowns in our purses afford us. We're better off than say the laborers... working themselves to death for three bits a day, forced to choose between a second drink and a whore to cope with reality."" she said in a hushed tone as to not be overheard. 

""I may choose to stay here for a while, but I've already walked away from life as a merchant because it couldn't offer me what I wanted... or should I say what we wanted. Of course there are things that would change that ... like if you were asking me to stay in a professional capacity."" She didn't expect Valentin would seek such an arrangement with her, but it seemed they wanted the same end.

There were other means to the freedom of course. None of which were practical for her ... or even the pair of them. 

Once she realized she accidentally propositioned, she looked away. She hadn't intended to stay here ... and her encounter with Nina now had her looking for a way to stay long enough to take care of the girl. An arrangement with Valentin would be mutually beneficial ... while she wouldn't be doing much dancing, she clearly had useful skills.
